"score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Pakistan"}, "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Pakistan"}}}], "eventDate": "2024-07-19", "totalArticleCount": 185, "title": {"eng": "Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee, a champion for progressive causes, dies at 74"}, "summary": {"eng": "Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee, D-Texas, who was a leading voice for racial justice and progressive causes during the three decades she served in the House, died Friday. She was 74.\n\nHer death was announced in a statement from her family. She said in June that she had been diagnosed with pancreatic cancer.\n\n\"By God's grace, I will be back at full strength soon,\" she told constituents.\n\nThe Congressional Black Caucus, in a statement released late Friday, called Jackson Lee \"a titan\" and \"a fierce advocat"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Texas"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}, "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Death/In_Memoriam", "label": "dmoz/Society/Death/In Memoriam", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "news/Politics", "label": "news/Politics", "wgt": 91}], "articleCounts": {"eng": 185}, "sentiment": 0.03529411764705892}
{"uri": "8235170852", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "15:55:48", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T15:55:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T15:54:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8705882430076599, "url": "https://www.yakimaherald.com/news/nation_and_world/nation/biden-praises-longtime-us-rep-sheila-jackson-lee-of-texas-who-died-of-cancer/article_21c60f6e-44a0-53ed-92fa-b7186d64f26e.html", "title": "Biden praises longtime US Rep Sheila Jackson Lee of Texas, who died of cancer", "body": "FILE - Mayoral candidate U.S. Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee speaks to supporters during an election watch party, Nov. 7, 2023, at Bayou Place in Houston. Longtime U.S. Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee, who helped lead federal efforts to protect women from domestic violence and recognize Juneteenth as a national holiday, has died Friday, July 19, 2024, after battling pancreatic cancer, according to her chief of staff.\n\nLongtime U.S. Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee of Texas, who helped lead federal efforts to protect women from domestic violence and recognize Juneteenth as a national holiday, has died. She was 74.\n\nLillie Conley, her chief of staff, confirmed that Jackson Lee, who had pancreatic cancer, died in Houston Friday night with her family around her.\n\nThe Democrat had represented her Houston-based district and the nation's fourth-largest city since 1995. She had previously had breast cancer and announced the pancreatic cancer diagnosis on June 2.\n\n\"The road ahead will not be easy, but I stand in faith that God will strengthen me,\" Jackson Lee said in a statement then.\n\nJackson Lee was \"a towering figure in our politics,\" President Joe Biden said in a statement Saturday. \"Always fearless, she spoke truth to power and represented the power of the people of her district in Houston with dignity and grace.\"\n\nBiden said Jackson Lee's spirit was unbreakable.\n\n\"I had the honor of working with her during her nearly 30 years in Congress,\" Biden said. \"No matter the issue -- from delivering racial justice to building an economy for working people -- she was unrelenting in her leadership.\"\n\nBishop James Dixon, a longtime friend in Houston who visited Jackson Lee earlier this week, said he will remember her as a fighter.\n\n\"She was just a rare, rare jewel of a person who relentlessly gave everything she had to make sure others had what they needed. That was Sheila,\" he said.\n\nJackson Lee had just been elected to the Houston district once represented by Barbara Jordan, the first Black woman elected to Congress from a Southern state since Reconstruction, when she was immediately placed on the high-profile House Judiciary Committee in 1995.\n\n\"They just saw me, I guess through my profile, through Barbara Jordan's work,\" Jackson Lee told the Houston Chronicle in 2022. \"I thought it was an honor because they assumed I was going to be the person they needed.\"\n\nJackson Lee quickly established herself as fierce advocate for women and minorities, and a leader for House Democrats on many social justice issues, from policing reform to reparations for descendants of enslaved people. She led the first rewrite of the Violence Against Women Act in nearly a decade, which included protections for Native American, transgender and immigrant women.\n\nJackson Lee was also among the lead lawmakers behind the effort in 2021 to have Juneteenth recognized as the first new federal holiday since Martin Luther King, Jr. Day was established in 1986. The holiday marks the day in 1865 that the last enslaved African Americans in Galveston, Texas, finally learned of their freedom.\n\nA native of Queens, New York, Jackson Lee graduated from Yale and earned her law degree at the University of Virginia. She was a judge in Houston before she was elected to Houston City Council in 1989, then ran for Congress in 1994. She was an advocate for gay rights and an early opponent of the Iraq War in 2003.\n\nTop congressional Democrats reacted quickly to the news Friday night, praising her commitment and work ethic.\n\nRep. James Clyburn of South Carolina called her \"a tenacious advocate for civil rights and a tireless fighter, improving the lives of her constituents.\"\n\nRep. Jamie Raskin of Maryland said he had never known a harder-working lawmaker than Jackson Lee, saying she \"studied every bill and every amendment with exactitude and then told Texas and America exactly where she stood.\"\n\nFormer House Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California cited Jackson Lee's \"relentless determination\" in getting Juneteenth declared a national holiday.\n\n\"As a powerful voice in the Congress for our Constitution and human rights, she fought tirelessly to advance fairness, equity and justice for all,\" Pelosi said.\n\nRepublican Texas Gov. Greg Abbott said he and his wife Cecilia will always remember Jackson Lee, calling her a \"tireless advocate for the people of Houston.\"\n\n\"Her legacy of public service and dedication to Texas will live on,\" he said.\n\nJackson Lee routinely won reelection to Congress with ease. The few times she faced a challenger, she never carried less than two-thirds of the vote. Jackson Lee considered leaving Congress in 2023 in a bid to become Houston's first female Black mayor but was defeated in a runoff. She then easily won the Democratic nomination for the 2024 general election.\n\nDuring the mayoral campaign, Jackson Lee expressed regret and said \"everyone deserves to be treated with dignity and respect\" following the release of an unverified audio recording purported to be of the lawmaker berating staff members.\n\nIn 2019, Jackson Lee stepped down from two leadership positions on the House Judiciary Committee and Congressional Black Caucus Foundation, the fundraising of the Congressional Black Caucus, following a lawsuit from a former employee who said her sexual assault complaint was mishandled.\n\nIn a statement, Jackson Lee's family said she had been a beloved wife, sister, mother and grandmother known as Bebe.\n\n\"She will be dearly missed, but her legacy will continue to inspire all who believe in freedom, justice, and democracy,\" the statement said. \"God bless you Congresswoman and God bless the United States of America.\"\n\nAssociated Press writer Lou Kesten contributed to this story from Washington.", "source": {"uri": "yakimaherald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yakima Herald-Republic"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@yakimaherald.com", {"uri": "8235132216", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "15:15:00", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T15:15:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T15:14:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8666666746139526, "url": "https://www.breitbart.com/news/longtime-us-rep-sheila-jackson-lee-of-texas-who-had-pancreatic-cancer-has-died/", "title": "Longtime US Rep Sheila Jackson Lee of Texas, who had pancreatic cancer, has died - Breitbart", "body": "Longtime U.S. Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee of Texas has died\n\nLongtime US Rep Sheila Jackson Lee of Texas, who had pancreatic cancer, has diedBy JIM VERTUNOAssociated PressThe Associated Press\n\nLongtime U.S. Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee of Texas, who helped lead federal efforts to protect women from domestic violence and recognize Juneteenth as a national holiday, has died. She was 74.\n\nLillie Conley, her chief of staff, confirmed that Jackson Lee, who had pancreatic cancer, died in Houston Friday night with her family around her.\n\nThe Democrat had represented her Houston-based district and the nation's fourth-largest city since 1995. She had previously had breast cancer and announced the pancreatic cancer diagnosis on June 2.\n\n\"The road ahead will not be easy, but I stand in faith that God will strengthen me,\" Jackson Lee said in a statement then.\n\nBishop James Dixon, a longtime friend in Houston who visited Jackson Lee earlier this week, said he will remember her as a fighter.\n\n\"She was just a rare, rare jewel of a person who relentlessly gave everything she had to make sure others had what they needed. That was Sheila,\" he said.\n\nJackson Lee had just been elected to the Houston district once represented by Barbara Jordan, the first Black woman elected to Congress from a Southern state since Reconstruction, when she was immediately placed on the high-profile House Judiciary Committee in 1995.\n\n\"They just saw me, I guess through my profile, through Barbara Jordan's work,\" Jackson Lee told the Houston Chronicle in 2022. \"I thought it was an honor because they assumed I was going to be the person they needed.\"\n\nJackson Lee quickly established herself as fierce advocate for women and minorities, and a leader for House Democrats on many social justice issues, from policing reform to reparations for descendants of enslaved people. She led the first rewrite of the Violence Against Women Act in nearly a decade, which included protections for Native American, transgender and immigrant women.\n\nJackson Lee was also among the lead lawmakers behind the effort in 2021 to have Juneteenth recognized as the first new federal holiday since Martin Luther King, Jr. Day was established in 1986. The holiday marks the day in 1865 that the last enslaved African Americans in Galveston, Texas, finally learned of their freedom.\n\nA native of Queens, New York, Jackson Lee graduated from Yale and earned her law degree at the University of Virginia. She was a judge in Houston before she was elected to Houston City Council in 1989, then ran for Congress in 1994. She was an advocate for gay rights and an early opponent of the Iraq War in 2003.\n\nTop congressional Democrats reacted quickly to the news Friday night, praising her commitment and work ethic.\n\nRep. James Clyburn of South Carolina called her \"a tenacious advocate for civil rights and a tireless fighter, improving the lives of her constituents.\"\n\nRep. Jamie Raskin of Maryland said he had never known a harder-working lawmaker than Jackson Lee, saying she \"studied every bill and every amendment with exactitude and then told Texas and America exactly where she stood.\"\n\nFormer House Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California cited Jackson Lee's \"relentless determination\" in getting Juneteenth declared a national holiday.\n\n\"As a powerful voice in the Congress for our Constitution and human rights, she fought tirelessly to advance fairness, equity and justice for all,\" Pelosi said.\n\nRepublican Texas Gov. Greg Abbott said he and his wife Cecilia will always remember Jackson Lee, calling her a \"tireless advocate for the people of Houston.\"\n\n\"Her legacy of public service and dedication to Texas will live on,\" he said.\n\nJackson Lee routinely won reelection to Congress with ease. The few times she faced a challenger, she never carried less than two-thirds of the vote. Jackson Lee considered leaving Congress in 2023 in a bid to become Houston's first female Black mayor but was defeated in a runoff. She then easily won the Democratic nomination for the 2024 general election.\n\nDuring the mayoral campaign, Jackson Lee expressed regret and said \"everyone deserves to be treated with dignity and respect\" following the release of an unverified audio recording purported to be of the lawmaker berating staff members.\n\nIn 2019, Jackson Lee stepped down from two leadership positions on the House Judiciary Committee and Congressional Black Caucus Foundation, the fundraising of the Congressional Black Caucus, following a lawsuit from a former employee who said her sexual assault complaint was mishandled.\n\nIn a statement, Jackson Lee's family said she had been a beloved wife, sister, mother and grandmother known as Bebe.\n\n\"She will be dearly missed, but her legacy will continue to inspire all who believe in freedom, justice, and democracy,\" the statement said. \"God bless you Congresswoman and God bless the United States of America.\"\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writer Lou Kesten contributed to this story from Washington.", "source": {"uri": "breitbart.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Breitbart"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@breitbart.com", "name": {"uri": "8234893010", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "11:24:27", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T11:24:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T11:23:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "url": "https://www.wkyc.com/article/news/nation-world/rep-sheila-jackson-lee-dies/285-7300edab-222d-4b40-9f63-c565c097275b", "title": "Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee dies at 74, her family announces", "body": "\"With incredible grief for our loss yet deep gratitude for the life she shared with us, we announce the passing of United States Representative Sheila Jackson Lee of the 18th Congressional District of Texas,\" her family said in a statement.\n\nKnown by her constituents as simply, \"Congresswoman,\" Jackson Lee served the public for more than 30 years.\n\n\"A local, national, and international humanitarian, she was acknowledged worldwide for her courageous fights for racial justice, criminal justice, and human rights, with a special emphasis on women and children,\" a statement from her family said.\n\nLast month, Jackson Lee announced she was fighting pancreatic cancer. In a statement at the time of the announcement, Jackson Lee said she was undergoing treatment to battle the disease \"that impacts tens of thousands of Americans every year.\"\n\nRELATED: 'I stand in faith that God will strengthen me' | US Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee announces pancreatic cancer diagnosis\n\n\"She will be dearly missed, but her legacy will continue to inspire all who believe in freedom, justice, and democracy. God bless you Congresswoman and God bless the United States of America,\" Jackson Lee's family said.\n\nRELATED: Houston-area leaders react to Congresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee's pancreatic cancer diagnosis\n\nJackson Lee had just been elected to the Houston district once represented by Barbara Jordan, the first Black woman elected to Congress from a Southern state since Reconstruction, when she was immediately placed on the high-profile House Judiciary Committee in 1995.\n\nShe quickly established herself as fierce advocate for women and minorities, and a leader for House Democrats on many social justice issues, from policing reform to reparations for descendants of enslaved people. She led the first rewrite of the Violence Against Women Act in nearly a decade, which included protections for Native American, transgender and immigrant women.\n\nJackson Lee was also among the lead lawmakers behind the effort in 2021 to have Juneteenth recognized as the first new federal holiday since Martin Luther King, Jr. Day was established in 1986. The holiday marks the day in 1865 that the last enslaved African Americans in Galveston, Texas, finally learned of their freedom.\n\nA native of Queens, New York, Jackson Lee graduated from Yale and earned her law degree at the University of Virginia. She was a judge in Houston before she was elected to Houston City Council in 1989, then ran for Congress in 1994. She was an advocate for gay rights and an early opponent of the Iraq War in 2003.\n\nIn March, she beat Amanda Edwards in the Democratic primary. The Houston lawmaker was on three Congressional committees. She was a senior member of the House Committee on the Judiciary, Homeland Security and the Budget Committee.\n\nFuneral arrangements are pending.\n\nRep. Al Green spoke to KHOU 11 anchors Len Cannon and Mia Gradney after learning of Jackson Lee's passing:\n\nBishop James Dixon, a longtime friend in Houston who visited Jackson Lee earlier this week, said he will remember her as a fighter.\n\n\"She was just a rare, rare jewel of a person who relentlessly gave everything she had to make sure others had what they needed. That was Sheila,\" he said.\n\nFormer House Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California cited Jackson Lee's \"relentless determination\" in getting Juneteenth declared a national holiday.\n\n\"As a powerful voice in the Congress for our Constitution and human rights, she fought tirelessly to advance fairness, equity and justice for all,\" Pelosi said.\n\nRepublican Texas Gov. Greg Abbott said he and his wife Cecilia will always remember Jackson Lee, calling her a \"tireless advocate for the people of Houston.\"\n\n\"Her legacy of public service and dedication to Texas will live on,\" he said.\n\nFormer Houston Mayor Sylvester Turner issued this statement after learning of Jackson Lee's death:\n\n\"I am deeply saddened by the death of my dear friend and colleague, Congresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee. From City Hall to the Halls of Congress, Sheila Jackson Lee has served her constituents well. She has written and passed key legislation and has stood on the floor of the United States House of Representatives speaking passionately for the interests of her district and the country she loved. She has worked with and advised Presidents of our great country, met with global leaders, and has been embraced by world renowned artists. But her work on the ground, in some of the poorest and under-resourced communities; the channeling of billions of federal dollars back to her district; her presence at someone's bedside, giving words of comfort to families who lost loved ones; her appearances at places of worship and events showcasing the global diversity of our City; and her uncanny ability to be everywhere, working every day for those who needed a champion, made her truly exceptional.\n\n\"When she was elected to the United States House of Representatives she stood in the shadow of Barbara Jordan, Mickey Leland and Craig Washington. Without question, she rose to the occasion and served with great distinction. Even if you disagreed with her politics, you had to respect her work ethic. We can honestly say Sheila Jackson Lee left it all on the field. Rest in peace my sister. Thank you for all you gave us. And, thank you to her family for sharing her with us. We will not forget her sacrifice or yours. Sheila - to God be the glory for the good you have done. It was truly a job well done!\"\n\nRep. Wesley Hunt released this statement on Jackson Lee's death:\n\n\"It is with profound sadness that I acknowledge the passing of Congresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee, a devoted leader, a proud-fellow Houstonian, and someone who I was proud to call a friend.\n\n\"Although we had our political disagreements, there were many moments with her, both public and private, that showed me that bipartisanship and service to country first can still bring members of Congress together.\n\n\"In these divided times, Congresswoman Lee and I were able to partner on several legislative initiatives for the city of the Houston. Her steadfast commitment to serving the people of Houston and her tireless work have left an indelible mark on our community and our nation.", "source": {"uri": "wkyc.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "2024-07-427854059", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "07:30:27", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T07:30:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T05:04:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8588235378265381, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/longtime-us-rep-sheila-jackson-lee-of-texas-who-had-pancreatic-cancer-has-died/article_0237fdb5-bf1f-5d20-abdd-d119d12b04f3.html", "title": "Longtime US Rep Sheila Jackson Lee of Texas, who had pancreatic cancer, has died", "body": "FILE - Mayoral candidate U.S. Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee speaks to supporters during an election watch party, Nov. 7, 2023, at Bayou Place in Houston. Longtime U.S. Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee, who helped lead federal efforts to protect women from domestic violence and recognize Juneteenth as a national holiday, has died Friday, July 19, 2024, after battling pancreatic cancer, according to her chief of staff.\n\nLongtime U.S. Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee of Texas, who helped lead federal efforts to protect women from domestic violence and recognize Juneteenth as a national holiday, has died. She was 74.\n\nLillie Conley, her chief of staff, confirmed that Jackson Lee, who had pancreatic cancer, died in Houston Friday night with her family around her.\n\nThe Democrat had represented her Houston-based district and the nation's fourth-largest city since 1995. She had previously had breast cancer and announced the pancreatic cancer diagnosis on June 2.\n\n\"The road ahead will not be easy, but I stand in faith that God will strengthen me,\" Jackson Lee said in a statement then.\n\nBishop James Dixon, a longtime friend in Houston who visited Jackson Lee earlier this week, said he will remember her as a fighter.\n\n\"She was just a rare, rare jewel of a person who relentlessly gave everything she had to make sure others had what they needed. That was Sheila,\" he said.\n\nJackson Lee had just been elected to the Houston district once represented by Barbara Jordan, the first Black woman elected to Congress from a Southern state since Reconstruction, when she was immediately placed on the high-profile House Judiciary Committee in 1995.\n\n\"They just saw me, I guess through my profile, through Barbara Jordan's work,\" Jackson Lee told the Houston Chronicle in 2022. \"I thought it was an honor because they assumed I was going to be the person they needed.\"\n\nJackson Lee quickly established herself as fierce advocate for women and minorities, and a leader for House Democrats on many social justice issues, from policing reform to reparations for descendants of enslaved people. She led the first rewrite of the Violence Against Women Act in nearly a decade, which included protections for Native American, transgender and immigrant women.\n\nJackson Lee was also among the lead lawmakers behind the effort in 2021 to have Juneteenth recognized as the first new federal holiday since Martin Luther King, Jr. Day was established in 1986. The holiday marks the day in 1865 that the last enslaved African Americans in Galveston, Texas, finally learned of their freedom.\n\nA native of Queens, New York, Jackson Lee graduated from Yale and earned her law degree at the University of Virginia. She was a judge in Houston before she was elected to Houston City Council in 1989, then ran for Congress in 1994. She was an advocate for gay rights and an early opponent of the Iraq War in 2003.\n\nTop congressional Democrats reacted quickly to the news Friday night, praising her commitment and work ethic.\n\nRep. James Clyburn of South Carolina called her \"a tenacious advocate for civil rights and a tireless fighter, improving the lives of her constituents.\"\n\nRep. Jamie Raskin of Maryland said he had never known a harder-working lawmaker than Jackson Lee, saying she \"studied every bill and every amendment with exactitude and then told Texas and America exactly where she stood.\"\n\nFormer House Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California cited Jackson Lee's \"relentless determination\" in getting Juneteenth declared a national holiday.\n\n\"As a powerful voice in the Congress for our Constitution and human rights, she fought tirelessly to advance fairness, equity and justice for all,\" Pelosi said.\n\nRepublican Texas Gov. Greg Abbott said he and his wife Cecilia will always remember Jackson Lee, calling her a \"tireless advocate for the people of Houston.\"\n\n\"Her legacy of public service and dedication to Texas will live on,\" he said.\n\nJackson Lee routinely won reelection to Congress with ease. The few times she faced a challenger, she never carried less than two-thirds of the vote. Jackson Lee considered leaving Congress in 2023 in a bid to become Houston's first female Black mayor but was defeated in a runoff. She then easily won the Democratic nomination for the 2024 general election.\n\nDuring the mayoral campaign, Jackson Lee expressed regret and said \"everyone deserves to be treated with dignity and respect\" following the release of an unverified audio recording purported to be of the lawmaker berating staff members.\n\nIn 2019, Jackson Lee stepped down from two leadership positions on the House Judiciary Committee and Congressional Black Caucus Foundation, the fundraising of the Congressional Black Caucus, following a lawsuit from a former employee who said her sexual assault complaint was mishandled.\n\nIn a statement, Jackson Lee's family said she had been a beloved wife, sister, mother and grandmother known as Bebe.\n\n\"She will be dearly missed, but her legacy will continue to inspire all who believe in freedom, justice, and democracy,\" the statement said. \"God bless you Congresswoman and God bless the United States of America.\"\n\nAssociated Press writer Lou Kesten {"uri": "8235166418", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "15:49:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T15:49:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T15:49:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/ap/national/biden-praises-longtime-us-rep-sheila-jackson-lee-of-texas-who-died-of-cancer/article_f938916a-cd0c-5cc5-883b-53e82d1c93e8.html", "title": "Biden praises longtime US Rep Sheila Jackson Lee of Texas, who died of cancer", "body": "Longtime U.S. Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee of Texas, who helped lead federal efforts to protect women from domestic violence and recognize Juneteenth as a national holiday, has died. She was 74.\n\nLillie Conley, her chief of staff, confirmed that Jackson Lee, who had pancreatic cancer, died in Houston Friday night with her family around her.\n\nThe Democrat had represented her Houston-based district and the nation's fourth-largest city since 1995. She had previously had breast cancer and announced the pancreatic cancer diagnosis on June 2.\n\n\"The road ahead will not be easy, but I stand in faith that God will strengthen me,\" Jackson Lee said in a statement then.\n\nJackson Lee was \"a towering figure in our politics,\" President Joe Biden said in a statement Saturday. \"Always fearless, she spoke truth to power and represented the power of the people of her district in Houston with dignity and grace.\"\n\nBiden said Jackson Lee's spirit was unbreakable.\n\n\"I had the honor of working with her during her nearly 30 years in Congress,\" Biden said. \"No matter the issue -- from delivering racial justice to building an economy for working people -- she was unrelenting in her leadership.\"\n\nBishop James Dixon, a longtime friend in Houston who visited Jackson Lee earlier this week, said he will remember her as a fighter.\n\n\"She was just a rare, rare jewel of a person who relentlessly gave everything she had to make sure others had what they needed. That was Sheila,\" he said.\n\nJackson Lee had just been elected to the Houston district once represented by Barbara Jordan, the first Black woman elected to Congress from a Southern state since Reconstruction, when she was immediately placed on the high-profile House Judiciary Committee in 1995.\n\n\"They just saw me, I guess through my profile, through Barbara Jordan's work,\" Jackson Lee told the Houston Chronicle in 2022. \"I thought it was an honor because they assumed I was going to be the person they needed.\"\n\nJackson Lee quickly established herself as fierce advocate for women and minorities, and a leader for House Democrats on many social justice issues, from policing reform to reparations for descendants of enslaved people. She led the first rewrite of the Violence Against Women Act in nearly a decade, which included protections for Native American, transgender and immigrant women.\n\nJackson Lee was also among the lead lawmakers behind the effort in 2021 to have Juneteenth recognized as the first new federal holiday since Martin Luther King, Jr. Day was established in 1986. The holiday marks the day in 1865 that the last enslaved African Americans in Galveston, Texas, finally learned of their freedom.\n\nA native of Queens, New York, Jackson Lee graduated from Yale and earned her law degree at the University of Virginia. She was a judge in Houston before she was elected to Houston City Council in 1989, then ran for Congress in 1994. She was an advocate for gay rights and an early opponent of the Iraq War in 2003.\n\nTop congressional Democrats reacted quickly to the news Friday night, praising her commitment and work ethic.\n\nRep. James Clyburn of South Carolina called her \"a tenacious advocate for civil rights and a tireless fighter, improving the lives of her constituents.\"\n\nRep. Jamie Raskin of Maryland said he had never known a harder-working lawmaker than Jackson Lee, saying she \"studied every bill and every amendment with exactitude and then told Texas and America exactly where she stood.\"\n\nFormer House Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California cited Jackson Lee's \"relentless determination\" in getting Juneteenth declared a national holiday.\n\n\"As a powerful voice in the Congress for our Constitution and human rights, she fought tirelessly to advance fairness, equity and justice for all,\" Pelosi said.\n\nRepublican Texas Gov. Greg Abbott said he and his wife Cecilia will always remember Jackson Lee, calling her a \"tireless advocate for the people of Houston.\"\n\n\"Her legacy of public service and dedication to Texas will live on,\" he said.\n\nJackson Lee routinely won reelection to Congress with ease. The few times she faced a challenger, she never carried less than two-thirds of the vote. Jackson Lee considered leaving Congress in 2023 in a bid to become Houston's first female Black mayor but was defeated in a runoff. She then easily won the Democratic nomination for the 2024 general election.\n\nDuring the mayoral campaign, Jackson Lee expressed regret and said \"everyone deserves to be treated with dignity and respect\" following the release of an unverified audio recording purported to be of the lawmaker berating staff members.\n\nIn 2019, Jackson Lee stepped down from two leadership positions on the House Judiciary Committee and Congressional Black Caucus Foundation, the fundraising of the Congressional Black Caucus, following a lawsuit from a former employee who said her sexual assault complaint was mishandled.\n\nIn a statement, Jackson Lee's family said she had been a beloved wife, sister, mother and grandmother known as Bebe.\n\n\"She will be dearly missed, but her legacy will continue to inspire all who believe in freedom, justice, and democracy,\" the statement said. \"God bless you Congresswoman and God bless the United States of America.\"\n\nAssociated Press writer Lou Kesten contributed to this story from Washington.", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Brattleboro Reformer"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@reformer.com", "name": {"uri": "8235159359", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "15:42:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T15:42:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T15:41:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://www.pbs.org/newshour/politics/longtime-texas-rep-sheila-jackson-lee-who-had-pancreatic-cancer-has-died-at-74", "title": "Longtime Texas Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee, who had pancreatic cancer, has died at 74", "body": "Longtime U.S. Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee of Texas, who helped lead federal efforts to protect women from domestic violence and recognize Juneteenth as a national holiday, has died. She was 74.\n\nLillie Conley, her chief of staff, confirmed that Jackson Lee, who had pancreatic cancer, died in Houston Friday night with her family around her.\n\nThe Democrat had represented her Houston-based district and the nation's fourth-largest city since 1995. She had previously had breast cancer and announced the pancreatic cancer diagnosis on June 2.\n\n\"The road ahead will not be easy, but I stand in faith that God will strengthen me,\" Jackson Lee said in a statement then.\n\nBishop James Dixon, a longtime friend in Houston who visited Jackson Lee earlier this week, said he will remember her as a fighter.\n\n\"She was just a rare, rare jewel of a person who relentlessly gave everything she had to make sure others had what they needed. That was Sheila,\" he said.\n\nJackson Lee had just been elected to the Houston district once represented by Barbara Jordan, the first Black woman elected to Congress from a Southern state since Reconstruction, when she was immediately placed on the high-profile House Judiciary Committee in 1995.\n\nJudge Ketanji Brown Jackson (right) is greeted by U.S. Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee, D-Texas, at a Senate Judiciary Committee confirmation hearing on Jackson's nomination to the U.S. Supreme Court, on Capitol Hill in Washington, D.C., March 21, 2022. Photo by Evelyn Hockstein/Reuters\n\n\"They just saw me, I guess through my profile, through Barbara Jordan's work,\" Jackson Lee told the Houston Chronicle in 2022. \"I thought it was an honor because they assumed I was going to be the person they needed.\"\n\nJackson Lee quickly established herself as fierce advocate for women and minorities, and a leader for House Democrats on many social justice issues, from policing reform to reparations for descendants of enslaved people. She led the first rewrite of the Violence Against Women Act in nearly a decade, which included protections for Native American, transgender and immigrant women.\n\nWATCH: President Biden remarks on the reauthorization of the Violence Against Women Act\n\nJackson Lee was also among the lead lawmakers behind the effort in 2021 to have Juneteenth recognized as the first new federal holiday since Martin Luther King, Jr. Day was established in 1986. The holiday marks the day in 1865 that the last enslaved African Americans in Galveston, Texas, finally learned of their freedom.\n\nA native of Queens, New York, Jackson Lee graduated from Yale and earned her law degree at the University of Virginia. She was a judge in Houston before she was elected to Houston City Council in 1989, then ran for Congress in 1994. She was an advocate for gay rights and an early opponent of the Iraq War in 2003.\n\nTop congressional Democrats reacted quickly to the news Friday night, praising her commitment and work ethic.\n\nRep. James Clyburn of South Carolina called her \"a tenacious advocate for civil rights and a tireless fighter, improving the lives of her constituents.\"\n\nRep. Jamie Raskin of Maryland said he had never known a harder-working lawmaker than Jackson Lee, saying she \"studied every bill and every amendment with exactitude and then told Texas and America exactly where she stood.\"\n\nFormer House Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California cited Jackson Lee's \"relentless determination\" in getting Juneteenth declared a national holiday.\n\n\"As a powerful voice in the Congress for our Constitution and human rights, she fought tirelessly to advance fairness, equity and justice for all,\" Pelosi said.\n\nRepublican Texas Gov. Greg Abbott said he and his wife Cecilia will always remember Jackson Lee, calling her a \"tireless advocate for the people of Houston.\"\n\n\"Her legacy of public service and dedication to Texas will live on,\" he said.\n\nJackson Lee routinely won reelection to Congress with ease. The few times she faced a challenger, she never carried less than two-thirds of the vote. Jackson Lee considered leaving Congress in 2023 in a bid to become Houston's first female Black mayor but was defeated in a runoff. She then easily won the Democratic nomination for the 2024 general election.\n\nDuring the mayoral campaign, Jackson Lee expressed regret and said \"everyone deserves to be treated with dignity and respect\" following the release of an unverified audio recording purported to be of the lawmaker berating staff members.\n\nIn 2019, Jackson Lee stepped down from two leadership positions on the House Judiciary Committee and Congressional Black Caucus Foundation, the fundraising of the Congressional Black Caucus, following a lawsuit from a former employee who said her sexual assault complaint was mishandled.\n\nIn a statement, Jackson Lee's family said she had been a beloved wife, sister, mother and grandmother known as Bebe.\n\n\"She will be dearly missed, but her legacy will continue to inspire all who believe in freedom, justice, and democracy,\" the statement said. \"God bless you Congresswoman and God bless the United States of America.\"\n\nAssociated Press writer Lou Kesten contributed to this story from Washington.", "source": {"uri": "pbs.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "PBS.org"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@pbs.org", "name": "Associated Press", "type": {"uri": "2024-07-427869619", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "07:54:44", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T07:54:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T04:23:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://tribtown.com/2024/07/20/longtime-us-rep-sheila-jackson-lee-of-texas-who-had-pancreatic-cancer-has-died/", "title": "Longtime US Rep Sheila Jackson Lee of Texas, who had pancreatic cancer, has died", "body": "FILE - Rep. Shelia Jackson Lee, D-Texas, speaks during a House Judiciary Committee meeting, Dec. 13, 2019, on Capitol Hill in Washington. Longtime U.S. Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee, who helped lead federal efforts to protect women from domestic violence and recognize Juneteenth as a national holiday, has died Friday, July 19, 2024, after battling pancreatic [...]\n\nLongtime U.S. Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee of Texas, who helped lead federal efforts to protect women from domestic violence and recognize Juneteenth as a national holiday, has died. She was 74.\n\nLillie Conley, her chief of staff, confirmed that Jackson Lee, who had pancreatic cancer, died in Houston Friday night with her family around her.\n\nThe Democrat had represented her Houston-based district and the nation's fourth-largest city since 1995. She had previously had breast cancer and announced the pancreatic cancer diagnosis on June 2.\n\n\"The road ahead will not be easy, but I stand in faith that God will strengthen me,\" Jackson Lee said in a statement then.\n\nBishop James Dixon, a longtime friend in Houston who visited Jackson Lee earlier this week, said he will remember her as a fighter.\n\n\"She was just a rare, rare jewel of a person who relentlessly gave everything she had to make sure others had what they needed. That was Sheila,\" he said.\n\nJackson Lee had just been elected to the Houston district once represented by Barbara Jordan, the first Black woman elected to Congress from a Southern state since Reconstruction, when she was immediately placed on the high-profile House Judiciary Committee in 1995.\n\n\"They just saw me, I guess through my profile, through Barbara Jordan's work,\" Jackson Lee told the Houston Chronicle in 2022. \"I thought it was an honor because they assumed I was going to be the person they needed.\"\n\nJackson Lee quickly established herself as fierce advocate for women and minorities, and a leader for House Democrats on many social justice issues, from policing reform to reparations for descendants of enslaved people. She led the first rewrite of the Violence Against Women Act in nearly a decade, which included protections for Native American, transgender and immigrant women.\n\nJackson Lee was also among the lead lawmakers behind the effort in 2021 to have Juneteenth recognized as the first new federal holiday since Martin Luther King, Jr. Day was established in 1986. The holiday marks the day in 1865 that the last enslaved African Americans in Galveston, Texas, finally learned of their freedom.\n\nA native of Queens, New York, Jackson Lee graduated from Yale and earned her law degree at the University of Virginia. She was a judge in Houston before she was elected to Houston City Council in 1989, then ran for Congress in 1994. She was an advocate for gay rights and an early opponent of the Iraq War in 2003.\n\nTop congressional Democrats reacted quickly to the news Friday night, praising her commitment and work ethic.\n\nRep. James Clyburn of South Carolina called her \"a tenacious advocate for civil rights and a tireless fighter, improving the lives of her constituents.\"\n\nRep. Jamie Raskin of Maryland said he had never known a harder-working lawmaker than Jackson Lee, saying she \"studied every bill and every amendment with exactitude and then told Texas and America exactly where she stood.\"\n\nFormer House Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California cited Jackson Lee's \"relentless determination\" in getting Juneteenth declared a national holiday.\n\n\"As a powerful voice in the Congress for our Constitution and human rights, she fought tirelessly to advance fairness, equity and justice for all,\" Pelosi said.\n\nRepublican Texas Gov. Greg Abbott said he and his wife Cecilia will always remember Jackson Lee, calling her a \"tireless advocate for the people of Houston.\"\n\n\"Her legacy of public service and dedication to Texas will live on,\" he said.\n\nJackson Lee routinely won reelection to Congress with ease. The few times she faced a challenger, she never carried less than two-thirds of the vote. Jackson Lee considered leaving Congress in 2023 in a bid to become Houston's first female Black mayor but was defeated in a runoff. She then easily won the Democratic nomination for the 2024 general election.\n\nDuring the mayoral campaign, Jackson Lee expressed regret and said \"everyone deserves to be treated with dignity and respect\" following the release of an unverified audio recording purported to be of the lawmaker berating staff members.\n\nIn 2019, Jackson Lee stepped down from two leadership positions on the House Judiciary Committee and Congressional Black Caucus Foundation, the fundraising of the Congressional Black Caucus, following a lawsuit from a former employee who said her sexual assault complaint was mishandled.\n\nIn a statement, Jackson Lee's family said she had been a beloved wife, sister, mother and grandmother known as Bebe.\n\n\"She will be dearly missed, but her legacy will continue to inspire all who believe in freedom, justice, and democracy,\" the statement said. \"God bless you Congresswoman and God bless the United States of America.\"\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writer Lou Kesten contributed to this story from Washington.", "source": {"uri": "tribtown.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Tribune"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@tribtown.com", "name": {"uri": "8235161257", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "15:44:18", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T15:44:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T15:43:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://www.whas11.com/article/news/nation-world/rep-sheila-jackson-lee-dies/285-7300edab-222d-4b40-9f63-c565c097275b", "title": "Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee dies at 74, her family announces", "body": "\"With incredible grief for our loss yet deep gratitude for the life she shared with us, we announce the passing of United States Representative Sheila Jackson Lee of the 18th Congressional District of Texas,\" her family said in a statement.\n\nKnown by her constituents as simply, \"Congresswoman,\" Jackson Lee served the public for more than 30 years.\n\n\"A local, national, and international humanitarian, she was acknowledged worldwide for her courageous fights for racial justice, criminal justice, and human rights, with a special emphasis on women and children,\" a statement from her family said.\n\nLast month, Jackson Lee announced she was fighting pancreatic cancer. In a statement at the time of the announcement, Jackson Lee said she was undergoing treatment to battle the disease \"that impacts tens of thousands of Americans every year.\"\n\nRELATED: 'I stand in faith that God will strengthen me' | US Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee announces pancreatic cancer diagnosis\n\n\"She will be dearly missed, but her legacy will continue to inspire all who believe in freedom, justice, and democracy. God bless you Congresswoman and God bless the United States of America,\" Jackson Lee's family said.\n\nRELATED: Houston-area leaders react to Congresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee's pancreatic cancer diagnosis\n\nJackson Lee had a hand in several legislative victories over the decades, including establishing the Juneteenth Federal Holiday and reauthorizing the Violence Against Women Act.\n\nJackson Lee was born on Jan. 12, 1950, in Queens, New York. She served on the Houston City Council from 1989 to 1994 and was elected to the United States House of Representatives in 1995.\n\nIn March, she beat Amanda Edwards in the Democratic primary. The Houston lawmaker was on three Congressional committees. She was a senior member of the House Committee on the Judiciary, Homeland Security and the Budget Committee.\n\nFuneral arrangements are pending.\n\nRep. Al Green spoke to KHOU 11 anchors Len Cannon and Mia Gradney after learning of Jackson Lee's passing:\n\nBishop James Dixon, a longtime friend in Houston who visited Jackson Lee earlier this week, said he will remember her as a fighter.\n\n\"She was just a rare, rare jewel of a person who relentlessly gave everything she had to make sure others had what they needed. That was Sheila,\" he said.\n\nFormer House Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California cited Jackson Lee's \"relentless determination\" in getting Juneteenth declared a national holiday.\n\n\"As a powerful voice in the Congress for our Constitution and human rights, she fought tirelessly to advance fairness, equity and justice for all,\" Pelosi said.\n\nRepublican Texas Gov. Greg Abbott said he and his wife Cecilia will always remember Jackson Lee, calling her a \"tireless advocate for the people of Houston.\"\n\n\"Her legacy of public service and dedication to Texas will live on,\" he said.\n\nFormer Houston Mayor Sylvester Turner issued this statement after learning of Jackson Lee's death:\n\n\"I am deeply saddened by the death of my dear friend and colleague, Congresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee. From City Hall to the Halls of Congress, Sheila Jackson Lee has served her constituents well. She has written and passed key legislation and has stood on the floor of the United States House of Representatives speaking passionately for the interests of her district and the country she loved. She has worked with and advised Presidents of our great country, met with global leaders, and has been embraced by world renowned artists. But her work on the ground, in some of the poorest and under-resourced communities; the channeling of billions of federal dollars back to her district; her presence at someone's bedside, giving words of comfort to families who lost loved ones; her appearances at places of worship and events showcasing the global diversity of our City; and her uncanny ability to be everywhere, working every day for those who needed a champion, made her truly exceptional.\n\n\"When she was elected to the United States House of Representatives she stood in the shadow of Barbara Jordan, Mickey Leland and Craig Washington. Without question, she rose to the occasion and served with great distinction. Even if you disagreed with her politics, you had to respect her work ethic. We can honestly say Sheila Jackson Lee left it all on the field. Rest in peace my sister. Thank you for all you gave us. And, thank you to her family for sharing her with us. We will not forget her sacrifice or yours. Sheila - to God be the glory for the good you have done. It was truly a job well done!\"\n\nRep. Wesley Hunt released this statement on Jackson Lee's death:\n\n\"It is with profound sadness that I acknowledge the passing of Congresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee, a devoted leader, a proud-fellow Houstonian, and someone who I was proud to call a friend.\n\n\"Although we had our political disagreements, there were many moments with her, both public and private, that showed me that bipartisanship and service to country first can still bring members of Congress together.\n\n\"In these divided times, Congresswoman Lee and I were able to partner on several legislative initiatives for the city of the Houston. Her steadfast commitment to serving the people of Houston and her tireless work have left an indelible mark on our community and our nation.", "source": {"uri": "whas11.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8235053086", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "13:56:11", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T13:56:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T13:55:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.pressherald.com/2024/07/20/longtime-u-s-rep-sheila-jackson-lee-of-texas-who-had-pancreatic-cancer-has-died/", "title": "Longtime U.S. Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee of Texas, who had pancreatic cancer, has died", "body": "U.S. Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee, center, D-Texas, speaks during an immigration rally April 10, 2006, in Guadalupe Plaza in Houston, Texas. Donna Carson/Associated Press\n\nLongtime U.S. Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee of Texas, who helped lead federal efforts to protect women from domestic violence and recognize Juneteenth as a national holiday, has died. She was 74.\n\nLillie Conley, her chief of staff, confirmed that Jackson Lee, who had pancreatic cancer, died in Houston Friday night with her family around her.\n\nThe Democrat had represented her Houston-based district and the nation's fourth-largest city since 1995. She had previously had breast cancer and announced the pancreatic cancer diagnosis on June 2.\n\n\"The road ahead will not be easy, but I stand in faith that God will strengthen me,\" Jackson Lee said in a statement then.\n\nBishop James Dixon, a longtime friend in Houston who visited Jackson Lee earlier this week, said he will remember her as a fighter.\n\n\"She was just a rare, rare jewel of a person who relentlessly gave everything she had to make sure others had what they needed. That was Sheila,\" he said.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nJackson Lee had just been elected to the Houston district once represented by Barbara Jordan, the first Black woman elected to Congress from a Southern state since Reconstruction, when she was immediately placed on the high-profile House Judiciary Committee in 1995.\n\n\"They just saw me, I guess through my profile, through Barbara Jordan's work,\" Jackson Lee told the Houston Chronicle in 2022. \"I thought it was an honor because they assumed I was going to be the person they needed.\"\n\nJackson Lee quickly established herself as fierce advocate for women and minorities, and a leader for House Democrats on many social justice issues, from policing reform to reparations for descendants of enslaved people. She led the first rewrite of the Violence Against Women Act in nearly a decade, which included protections for Native American, transgender and immigrant women.\n\nJackson Lee was also among the lead lawmakers behind the effort in 2021 to have Juneteenth recognized as the first new federal holiday since Martin Luther King, Jr. Day was established in 1986. The holiday marks the day in 1865 that the last enslaved African Americans in Galveston, Texas, finally learned of their freedom.\n\nA native of Queens, New York, Jackson Lee graduated from Yale and earned her law degree at the University of Virginia. She was a judge in Houston before she was elected to Houston City Council in 1989, then ran for Congress in 1994. She was an advocate for gay rights and an early opponent of the Iraq War in 2003.\n\nTop congressional Democrats reacted quickly to the news Friday night, praising her commitment and work ethic.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nRep. James Clyburn of South Carolina called her \"a tenacious advocate for civil rights and a tireless fighter, improving the lives of her constituents.\"\n\nRep. Jamie Raskin of Maryland said he had never known a harder-working lawmaker than Jackson Lee, saying she \"studied every bill and every amendment with exactitude and then told Texas and America exactly where she stood.\"\n\nRep. Shelia Jackson Lee, D-Texas, speaks during a House Judiciary Committee meeting, Dec. 13, 2019, on Capitol Hill in Washington. Patrick Semansky/Associated Press\n\nFormer House Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California cited Jackson Lee's \"relentless determination\" in getting Juneteenth declared a national holiday.\n\n\"As a powerful voice in the Congress for our Constitution and human rights, she fought tirelessly to advance fairness, equity and justice for all,\" Pelosi said.\n\nRepublican Texas Gov. Greg Abbott said he and his wife Cecilia will always remember Jackson Lee, calling her a \"tireless advocate for the people of Houston.\"\n\n\"Her legacy of public service and dedication to Texas will live on,\" he said.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nJackson Lee routinely won reelection to Congress with ease. The few times she faced a challenger, she never carried less than two-thirds of the vote. Jackson Lee considered leaving Congress in 2023 in a bid to become Houston's first female Black mayor but was defeated in a runoff. She then easily won the Democratic nomination for the 2024 general election.\n\nDuring the mayoral campaign, Jackson Lee expressed regret and said \"everyone deserves to be treated with dignity and respect\" following the release of an unverified audio recording purported to be of the lawmaker berating staff members.\n\nIn 2019, Jackson Lee stepped down from two leadership positions on the House Judiciary Committee and Congressional Black Caucus Foundation, the fundraising of the Congressional Black Caucus, following a lawsuit from a former employee who said her sexual assault complaint was mishandled.\n\nIn a statement, Jackson Lee's family said she had been a beloved wife, sister, mother and grandmother known as Bebe.\n\n\"She will be dearly missed, but her legacy will continue to inspire all who believe in freedom, justice, and democracy,\" the statement said. \"God bless you Congresswoman and God bless the United States of America.\"\n\nCopy the Story Link\n\nSend questions/comments to the editors.\n\nRelated Stories Latest Articles", "source": {"uri": "pressherald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Portland Press Herald"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8234543367", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "05:50:35", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T05:50:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T05:50:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://www.npr.org/2024/07/20/g-s1-12457/sheila-jackson-lee-dies-74", "title": "Longtime U.S. Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee of Texas has died at age 74", "body": "Rep. Shelia Jackson Lee, D-Texas, speaks during a House Judiciary Committee meeting on Dec. 13, 2019 on Capitol Hill in Washington, D.C. Patrick Semansky/AP Pool hide caption\n\nLongtime U.S. Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee of Texas, who helped lead federal efforts to protect women from domestic violence and recognize Juneteenth as a national holiday, has died. She was 74.\n\nLillie Conley, her chief of staff, confirmed that Jackson Lee, who had pancreatic cancer, died in Houston Friday night with her family around her.\n\nThe Democrat had represented her Houston-based district and the nation's fourth-largest city since 1995. She had previously had breast cancer and announced the pancreatic cancer diagnosis on June 2.\n\n\"The road ahead will not be easy, but I stand in faith that God will strengthen me,\" Jackson Lee said in a statement then.\n\nBishop James Dixon, a longtime friend in Houston who visited Jackson Lee earlier this week, said he will remember her as a fighter.\n\n\"She was just a rare, rare jewel of a person who relentlessly gave everything she had to make sure others had what they needed. That was Sheila,\" he said.\n\nJackson Lee had just been elected to the Houston district once represented by Barbara Jordan, the first Black woman elected to Congress from a Southern state since Reconstruction, when she was immediately placed on the high-profile House Judiciary Committee in 1995.\n\n\"They just saw me, I guess through my profile, through Barbara Jordan's work,\" Jackson Lee told the Houston Chronicle in 2022. \"I thought it was an honor because they assumed I was going to be the person they needed.\"\n\nJackson Lee quickly established herself as fierce advocate for women and minorities, and a leader for House Democrats on many social justice issues, from policing reform to reparations for descendants of enslaved people. She led the first rewrite of the Violence Against Women Act in nearly a decade, which included protections for Native American, transgender and immigrant women.\n\nJackson Lee was also among the lead lawmakers behind the effort in 2021 to have Juneteenth recognized as the first new federal holiday since Martin Luther King, Jr. Day was established in 1986. The holiday marks the day in 1865 that the last enslaved African Americans in Galveston, Texas, finally learned of their freedom.\n\nA native of Queens, New York, Jackson Lee graduated from Yale and earned her law degree at the University of Virginia. She was a judge in Houston before she was elected to Houston City Council in 1989, then ran for Congress in 1994. She was an advocate for gay rights and an early opponent of the Iraq War in 2003.\n\nTop congressional Democrats reacted quickly to the news Friday night, praising her commitment and work ethic.\n\nRep. James Clyburn of South Carolina called her \"a tenacious advocate for civil rights and a tireless fighter, improving the lives of her constituents.\"\n\nRep. Jamie Raskin of Maryland said he had never known a harder-working lawmaker than Jackson Lee, saying she \"studied every bill and every amendment with exactitude and then told Texas and America exactly where she stood.\"\n\nFormer House Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California cited Jackson Lee's \"relentless determination\" in getting Juneteenth declared a national holiday.\n\n\"As a powerful voice in the Congress for our Constitution and human rights, she fought tirelessly to advance fairness, equity and justice for all,\" Pelosi said.\n\nRepublican Texas Gov. Greg Abbott said he and his wife Cecilia will always remember Jackson Lee, calling her a \"tireless advocate for the people of Houston.\"\n\n\"Her legacy of public service and dedication to Texas will live on,\" he said.\n\nJackson Lee routinely won reelection to Congress with ease. The few times she faced a challenger, she never carried less than two-thirds of the vote. Jackson Lee considered leaving Congress in 2023 in a bid to become Houston's first female Black mayor but was defeated in a runoff. She then easily won the Democratic nomination for the 2024 general election.\n\nDuring the mayoral campaign, Jackson Lee expressed regret and said \"everyone deserves to be treated with dignity and respect\" following the release of an unverified audio recording purported to be of the lawmaker berating staff members.\n\nIn 2019, Jackson Lee stepped down from two leadership positions on the House Judiciary Committee and Congressional Black Caucus Foundation, the fundraising of the Congressional Black Caucus, following a lawsuit from a former employee who said her sexual assault complaint was mishandled.\n\nIn a statement, Jackson Lee's family said she had been a beloved wife, sister, mother and grandmother known as Bebe.\n\n\"She will be dearly missed, but her legacy will continue to inspire all who believe in freedom, justice, and democracy,\" the statement said. \"God bless you Congresswoman and God bless the United States of America.\"", "source": {"uri": "npr.org", "dataType": {"uri": "8234434573", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "03:42:51", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T03:42:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T03:42:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/rep-sheila-jackson-lee-dead-033712477.html", "title": "Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee Dead at 74, 6 Weeks After Revealing Pancreatic Cancer Diagnosis", "body": "The Texas Democrat, who represented Houston in Congress for three decades, warned that \"the road ahead will not be easy\" as she disclosed her cancer diagnosis in June 2024\n\nTexas Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee, who previously revealed her pancreatic cancer diagnosis, has died, her family announced on Friday, July 19. She was 74.\n\n\"Today, with incredible grief for our loss yet deep gratitude for the life she shared with us, we announce the passing of United States Representative Sheila Jackson Lee of the 18th Congressional District of Texas,\" the statement began.\n\nSaluting Jackson Lee as \"a fierce champion for the people,\" who was \"affectionately and simply known as 'Congresswoman' by her constituents,\" her loved ones noted that she served for over three decades.\n\n\"A local, national, and international humanitarian, she was acknowledged worldwide for her courageous fights for racial justice, criminal justice, and human rights, with a special emphasis on women on children.\"\n\nRelated: Congresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee Reveals Pancreatic Cancer Diagnosis: 'The Road Ahead Will Not Be Easy'\n\nThroughout her time in office, Jackson Lee garnered \"legislative victories\" that \"impacted millions,\" from solidifying Juneteenth as a Federal Holiday to her work with the Violence Against Women Act, her family continued.\n\nStill, she was also a staple and matriarch in her family unit as a wife, sister mother and grandmother, known as Bebe.\n\n\"She will be dearly missed, but her legacy will continue to inspire all who believe in freedom, justice, and democracy. God bless you Congresswoman and God bless the United States of America.\n\nJackson Lee, who represented the 18th Congressional District of Texas since 1995, announced her cancer diagnosis in a statement on June 2, 2024. She warned that she would be \"occasionally absent from Congress\" but would continue to fight for her constituents.\n\n\"I am committed to working with our Congressional Leadership, including Leader Hakeem Jeffries and the Speaker of House, to serve this nation and be present for votes on legislation that is critical for the prosperity and security of the American people,\" she said. \"By God's grace, I will be back at full strength soon.\"\n\nJackson Lee survived breast cancer more than a decade earlier, announcing in 2012 that she had fully recovered following a year of treatment.\n\nJackson Lee was born in Queens, New York City, on Jan. 12, 1950, and lived there through high school. She studied political science at Yale University before earning her J.D. from the University of Virginia School of Law in 1975.\n\nIn the late '70s, Jackson Lee aided the U.S. House Select Committee on Assassinations, serving as staff counsel to the task force that investigated Martin Luther King Jr.'s murder. She and her husband then relocated to Houston, where he'd accepted a teaching job.\n\nIn Texas, Jackson Lee proved eager to get involved. She was appointed to a municipal judgeship in 1987, then elected to the Houston City Council in 1989 as one of the first Black and female at-Large members.\n\nShe soon set her sights on Congress, handily winning the 1994 Democratic primary against four-time incumbent Rep. Craig Washington and gliding to victory in the general election.\n\nThrough her decades in Congress, Jackson Lee was instrumental in making Juneteenth a national holiday and pushing for legislation related to police misconduct, wage discrimination on the basis of sex, and accommodations for pregnant workers among other initiatives.\n\nJackson Lee ran for mayor of Houston in 2023, though her campaign was plagued by scandal after unverified audio leaked where Jackson Lee was allegedly heard berating her staff with profanity. Jackson Lee issued a statement and apologized, saying, \"I know that I am not perfect.\"\n\nThough she advanced to a runoff in the general election, she lost the race in a landslide to prominent state Sen. John Whitmire. She filed for reelection to the House two days later.\n\nNever miss a story -- sign up for PEOPLE's free daily newsletter to stay up-to-date on the best of what PEOPLE has to offer.\n\nDuring Jackson Lee's 2024 congressional campaign, President Joe Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris commended her career in a joint endorsement.\n\n\"We've witnessed her devotion to her constituents, inspiring grit, and invaluable experience deliver an unmatched record of success,\" they wrote. \"She has been a strong ally for hard working American families -- in Houston and across the country.\"\n\nJackson Lee is survived by her husband, Elwyn Lee, and their two children.", "source": {"uri": "ca.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8235050110", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "13:52:56", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T13:52:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T13:52:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "http://amsterdamnews.com/news/2024/07/20/sheila-jackson-lee/", "title": "Longtime US Rep Sheila Jackson Lee of Texas, who had pancreatic cancer, has died", "body": "Get the top Racial Equity stories of the day from America's most influential oldest continuously published Black newspaper, serving the nation's largest Black and brown community. Sign up to stay connected.\n\nLongtime U.S. Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee of Texas, who helped lead federal efforts to protect women from domestic violence and recognize Juneteenth as a national holiday, has died. She was 74.\n\nLillie Conley, her chief of staff, confirmed that Jackson Lee, who had pancreatic cancer, died in Houston Friday night with her family around her.\n\nThe Democrat had represented her Houston-based district and the nation's fourth-largest city since 1995. She had previously had breast cancer and announced the pancreatic cancer diagnosis on June 2.\n\n\"The road ahead will not be easy, but I stand in faith that God will strengthen me,\" Jackson Lee said in a statement then.\n\nBishop James Dixon, a longtime friend in Houston who visited Jackson Lee earlier this week, said he will remember her as a fighter.\n\n\"She was just a rare, rare jewel of a person who relentlessly gave everything she had to make sure others had what they needed. That was Sheila,\" he said.\n\nJackson Lee had just been elected to the Houston district once represented by Barbara Jordan, the first Black woman elected to Congress from a Southern state since Reconstruction, when she was immediately placed on the high-profile House Judiciary Committee in 1995.\n\n\"They just saw me, I guess through my profile, through Barbara Jordan's work,\" Jackson Lee told the Houston Chronicle in 2022. \"I thought it was an honor because they assumed I was going to be the person they needed.\"\n\nJackson Lee quickly established herself as a fierce advocate for women and minorities, and a leader for House Democrats on many social justice issues, from policing reform to reparations for descendants of enslaved people. She led the first rewrite of the Violence Against Women Act in nearly a decade, which included protections for Native American, transgender and immigrant women.\n\nJackson Lee was also among the lead lawmakers behind the effort in 2021 to have Juneteenth recognized as the first new federal holiday since Martin Luther King, Jr. Day was established in 1986. The holiday marks the day in 1865 that the last enslaved African Americans in Galveston, Texas, finally learned of their freedom.\n\nA native of Queens, New York, Jackson Lee graduated from Yale and earned her law degree at the University of Virginia. She was a judge in Houston before she was elected to Houston City Council in 1989, then ran for Congress in 1994. She was an advocate for gay rights and an early opponent of the Iraq War in 2003.\n\nTop congressional Democrats reacted quickly to the news Friday night, praising her commitment and work ethic.\n\nRep. James Clyburn of South Carolina called her \"a tenacious advocate for civil rights and a tireless fighter, improving the lives of her constituents.\"\n\nRep. Jamie Raskin of Maryland said he had never known a harder-working lawmaker than Jackson Lee, saying she \"studied every bill and every amendment with exactitude and then told Texas and America exactly where she stood.\"\n\nFormer House Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California cited Jackson Lee's \"relentless determination\" in getting Juneteenth declared a national holiday.\n\n\"As a powerful voice in the Congress for our Constitution and human rights, she fought tirelessly to advance fairness, equity and justice for all,\" Pelosi said.\n\nRepublican Texas Gov. Greg Abbott said he and his wife Cecilia will always remember Jackson Lee, calling her a \"tireless advocate for the people of Houston.\"\n\n\"Her legacy of public service and dedication to Texas will live on,\" he said.\n\nJackson Lee routinely won reelection to Congress with ease. The few times she faced a challenger, she never carried less than two-thirds of the vote. Jackson Lee considered leaving Congress in 2023 in a bid to become Houston's first female Black mayor but was defeated in a runoff. She then easily won the Democratic nomination for the 2024 general election.\n\nDuring the mayoral campaign, Jackson Lee expressed regret and said \"everyone deserves to be treated with dignity and respect\" following the release of an unverified audio recording purported to be of the lawmaker berating staff members.\n\nIn 2019, Jackson Lee stepped down from two leadership positions on the House Judiciary Committee and Congressional Black Caucus Foundation, the fundraising of the Congressional Black Caucus, following a lawsuit from a former employee who said her sexual assault complaint was mishandled.\n\nIn a statement, Jackson Lee's family said she had been a beloved wife, sister, mother and grandmother known as Bebe.\n\n\"She will be dearly missed, but her legacy will continue to inspire all who believe in freedom, justice, and democracy,\" the statement said. \"God bless you Congresswoman and God bless the United States of America.\"\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writer Lou Kesten contributed to this story from Washington.", "source": {"uri": "amsterdamnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "amsterdamnews.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sheila_Jackson_Lee", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Sheila Jackson Lee"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pancreatic_cancer", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Pancreatic cancer"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)", "type": "org", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Democratic Party (United States)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Houston", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Houston"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Houston"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jackson,_Mississippi", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Jackson, Mississippi"}, "location": {"type": {"uri": "8234435791", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "03:45:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T03:45:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T03:44:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://people.com/sheila-jackson-lee-dead-at-74-texas-congresswoman-8657888", "title": "Sheila Lee Jackson, Texas Congresswoman, Dies at 74", "body": "Texas Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee, who previously revealed her pancreatic cancer diagnosis, has died, her family announced on Friday, July 19. She was 74.\n\n\"Today, with incredible grief for our loss yet deep gratitude for the life she shared with us, we announce the passing of United States Representative Sheila Jackson Lee of the 18th Congressional District of Texas,\" the statement began.\n\nSaluting Jackson Lee as \"a fierce champion for the people,\" who was \"affectionately and simply known as 'Congresswoman' by her constituents,\" her loved ones noted that she served for over three decades.\n\n\"A local, national, and international humanitarian, she was acknowledged worldwide for her courageous fights for racial justice, criminal justice, and human rights, with a special emphasis on women on children.\"\n\nThroughout her time in office, Jackson Lee garnered \"legislative victories\" that \"impacted millions,\" from solidifying Juneteenth as a Federal Holiday to her work with the Violence Against Women Act, her family continued.\n\nStill, she was also a staple and matriarch in her family unit as a wife, sister mother and grandmother, known as Bebe.\n\n\"She will be dearly missed, but her legacy will continue to inspire all who believe in freedom, justice, and democracy. God bless you Congresswoman and God bless the United States of America.\n\nFuneral arrangements are currently pending.\n\nJackson Lee, who represented the 18th Congressional District of Texas since 1995, announced her cancer diagnosis in a statement on June 2, 2024. She warned that she would be \"occasionally absent from Congress\" but would continue to fight for her constituents.\n\n\"I am committed to working with our Congressional Leadership, including Leader Hakeem Jeffries and the Speaker of House, to serve this nation and be present for votes on legislation that is critical for the prosperity and security of the American people,\" she said. \"By God's grace, I will be back at full strength soon.\"\n\nJackson Lee survived breast cancer more than a decade earlier, announcing in 2012 that she had fully recovered following a year of treatment.\n\nJackson Lee was born in Queens, New York City, on Jan. 12, 1950, and lived there through high school. She studied political science at Yale University before earning her J.D. from the University of Virginia School of Law in 1975.\n\nIn the late '70s, Jackson Lee aided the U.S. House Select Committee on Assassinations, serving as staff counsel to the task force that investigated Martin Luther King Jr.'s murder. She and her husband then relocated to Houston, where he'd accepted a teaching job.\n\nIn Texas, Jackson Lee proved eager to get involved. She was appointed to a municipal judgeship in 1987, then elected to the Houston City Council in 1989 as one of the first Black and female at-Large members.\n\nShe soon set her sights on Congress, handily winning the 1994 Democratic primary against four-time incumbent Rep. Craig Washington and gliding to victory in the general election.\n\nThrough her decades in Congress, Jackson Lee was instrumental in making Juneteenth a national holiday and pushing for legislation related to police misconduct, wage discrimination on the basis of sex, and accommodations for pregnant workers among other initiatives.\n\nJackson Lee ran for mayor of Houston in 2023, though her campaign was plagued by scandal after unverified audio leaked where Jackson Lee was allegedly heard berating her staff with profanity. Jackson Lee issued a statement and apologized, saying, \"I know that I am not perfect.\"\n\nThough she advanced to a runoff in the general election, she lost the race in a landslide to prominent state Sen. John Whitmire. She filed for reelection to the House two days later.\n\nNever miss a story -- sign up for PEOPLE's free daily newsletter to stay up-to-date on the best of what PEOPLE has to offer.\n\nDuring Jackson Lee's 2024 congressional campaign, President Joe Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris commended her career in a joint endorsement.\n\n\"We've witnessed her devotion to her constituents, inspiring grit, and invaluable experience deliver an unmatched record of success,\" they wrote. \"She has been a strong ally for hard working American families -- in Houston and across the country.\"\n\nJackson Lee is survived by her husband, Elwyn Lee, and their two children.", "source": {"uri": "people.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "PEOPLE.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri":
