{"uri": "2024-07-427853429", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "07:29:01", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T07:29:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T05:04:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/longtime-us-rep-sheila-jackson-lee-of-texas-who-had-pancreatic-cancer-has-died/article_7db1f478-f60e-558d-a9bd-8725231f5814.html", "title": "Longtime US Rep Sheila Jackson Lee of Texas, who had pancreatic cancer, has died", "body": "Longtime U.S. Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee of Texas, who helped lead federal efforts to protect women from domestic violence and recognize Juneteenth as a national holiday, has died. She was 74.\n\nLillie Conley, her chief of staff, confirmed that Jackson Lee, who had pancreatic cancer, died in Houston Friday night with her family around her.\n\nThe Democrat had represented her Houston-based district and the nation's fourth-largest city since 1995. She had previously had breast cancer and announced the pancreatic cancer diagnosis on June 2.\n\n\"The road ahead will not be easy, but I stand in faith that God will strengthen me,\" Jackson Lee said in a statement then.\n\nBishop James Dixon, a longtime friend in Houston who visited Jackson Lee earlier this week, said he will remember her as a fighter.\n\n\"She was just a rare, rare jewel of a person who relentlessly gave everything she had to make sure others had what they needed. That was Sheila,\" he said.\n\nJackson Lee had just been elected to the Houston district once represented by Barbara Jordan, the first Black woman elected to Congress from a Southern state since Reconstruction, when she was immediately placed on the high-profile House Judiciary Committee in 1995.\n\n\"They just saw me, I guess through my profile, through Barbara Jordan's work,\" Jackson Lee told the Houston Chronicle in 2022. \"I thought it was an honor because they assumed I was going to be the person they needed.\"\n\nJackson Lee quickly established herself as fierce advocate for women and minorities, and a leader for House Democrats on many social justice issues, from policing reform to reparations for descendants of enslaved people. She led the first rewrite of the Violence Against Women Act in nearly a decade, which included protections for Native American, transgender and immigrant women.\n\nJackson Lee was also among the lead lawmakers behind the effort in 2021 to have Juneteenth recognized as the first new federal holiday since Martin Luther King, Jr. Day was established in 1986. The holiday marks the day in 1865 that the last enslaved African Americans in Galveston, Texas, finally learned of their freedom.\n\nA native of Queens, New York, Jackson Lee graduated from Yale and earned her law degree at the University of Virginia. She was a judge in Houston before she was elected to Houston City Council in 1989, then ran for Congress in 1994. She was an advocate for gay rights and an early opponent of the Iraq War in 2003.\n\nTop congressional Democrats reacted quickly to the news Friday night, praising her commitment and work ethic.\n\nRep. James Clyburn of South Carolina called her \"a tenacious advocate for civil rights and a tireless fighter, improving the lives of her constituents.\"\n\nRep. Jamie Raskin of Maryland said he had never known a harder-working lawmaker than Jackson Lee, saying she \"studied every bill and every amendment with exactitude and then told Texas and America exactly where she stood.\"\n\nFormer House Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California cited Jackson Lee's \"relentless determination\" in getting Juneteenth declared a national holiday.\n\n\"As a powerful voice in the Congress for our Constitution and human rights, she fought tirelessly to advance fairness, equity and justice for all,\" Pelosi said.\n\nRepublican Texas Gov. Greg Abbott said he and his wife Cecilia will always remember Jackson Lee, calling her a \"tireless advocate for the people of Houston.\"\n\n\"Her legacy of public service and dedication to Texas will live on,\" he said.\n\nJackson Lee routinely won reelection to Congress with ease. The few times she faced a challenger, she never carried less than two-thirds of the vote. Jackson Lee considered leaving Congress in 2023 in a bid to become Houston's first female Black mayor but was defeated in a runoff. She then easily won the Democratic nomination for the 2024 general election.\n\nDuring the mayoral campaign, Jackson Lee expressed regret and said \"everyone deserves to be treated with dignity and respect\" following the release of an unverified audio recording purported to be of the lawmaker berating staff members.\n\nIn 2019, Jackson Lee stepped down from two leadership positions on the House Judiciary Committee and Congressional Black Caucus Foundation, the fundraising of the Congressional Black Caucus, following a lawsuit from a former employee who said her sexual assault complaint was mishandled.\n\nIn a statement, Jackson Lee's family said she had been a beloved wife, sister, mother and grandmother known as Bebe.\n\n\"She will be dearly missed, but her legacy will continue to inspire all who believe in freedom, justice, and democracy,\" the statement said. \"God bless you Congresswoman and God bless the United States of America.\"\n\nAssociated Press writer Lou Kesten contributed to this story from Washington.\n\nMore from this section\n\n[NEW] 2024 Best Pok\u00e9mon GO Spoofer for iPhone and Android | Tenorshare iAnyGo\n\nLuvme Hair Celebrates Success with Atlanta Pop-Up Shop\n\nNational Nonprofit Petco Love Invests in Sacramento SPCA to Save and Improve the Lives of Pets in the Sacramento Region", "source": {"uri": "kulr8.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "2024-07-427772697", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "05:06:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T05:06:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T22:51:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.firstcoastnews.com/article/news/local/rep-sheila-jackson-lee-dies/285-7300edab-222d-4b40-9f63-c565c097275b", "title": "Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee dies at 74, her family announces", "body": "\"With incredible grief for our loss yet deep gratitude for the life she shared with us, we announce the passing of United States Representative Sheila Jackson Lee of the 18th Congressional District of Texas,\" her family said in a statement.\n\nKnown by her constituents as simply, \"Congresswoman,\" Jackson Lee served the public for more than 30 years.\n\n\"A local, national, and international humanitarian, she was acknowledged worldwide for her courageous fights for racial justice, criminal justice, and human rights, with a special emphasis on women and children,\" a statement from her family said.\n\nLast month, Jackson Lee announced she was fighting pancreatic cancer. In a statement at the time of the announcement, Jackson Lee said she was undergoing treatment to battle the disease \"that impacts tens of thousands of Americans every year.\"\n\nRELATED: 'I stand in faith that God will strengthen me' | US Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee announces pancreatic cancer diagnosis\n\n\"She will be dearly missed, but her legacy will continue to inspire all who believe in freedom, justice, and democracy. God bless you Congresswoman and God bless the United States of America,\" Jackson Lee's family said.\n\nRELATED: Houston-area leaders react to Congresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee's pancreatic cancer diagnosis\n\nJackson Lee had a hand in several legislative victories over the decades, including establishing the Juneteenth Federal Holiday and reauthorizing the Violence Against Women Act.\n\nRead the family's full statement below:\n\nJackson Lee was born on Jan. 12, 1950, in Queens, New York. She served on the Houston City Council from 1989 to 1994 and was elected to the United States House of Representatives in 1995.\n\nIn March, she beat Amanda Edwards in the Democratic primary. The Houston lawmaker was on three Congressional committees. She was a senior member of the House Committee on the Judiciary, Homeland Security and the Budget Committee, according to her online bio.\n\nFuneral arrangements are pending.\n\nRep. Al Green spoke to KHOU 11 anchors Len Cannon and Mia Gradney after learning of Jackson Lee's passing:\n\nFormer Houston Mayor Sylvester Turner issued this statement after learning of Jackson Lee's death:\n\n\"I am deeply saddened by the death of my dear friend and colleague, Congresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee. From City Hall to the Halls of Congress, Sheila Jackson Lee has served her constituents well. She has written and passed key legislation and has stood on the floor of the United States House of Representatives speaking passionately for the interests of her district and the country she loved. She has worked with and advised Presidents of our great country, met with global leaders, and has been embraced by world renowned artists. But her work on the ground, in some of the poorest and under-resourced communities; the channeling of billions of federal dollars back to her district; her presence at someone's bedside, giving words of comfort to families who lost loved ones; her appearances at places of worship and events showcasing the global diversity of our City; and her uncanny ability to be everywhere, working every day for those who needed a champion, made her truly exceptional.\n\n\"When she was elected to the United States House of Representatives she stood in the shadow of Barbara Jordan, Mickey Leland and Craig Washington. Without question, she rose to the occasion and served with great distinction. Even if you disagreed with her politics, you had to respect her work ethic. We can honestly say Sheila Jackson Lee left it all on the field. Rest in peace my sister. Thank you for all you gave us. And, thank you to her family for sharing her with us. We will not forget her sacrifice or yours. Sheila - to God be the glory for the good you have done. It was truly a job well done!\"\n\nRep. Wesley Hunt released this statement on Jackson Lee's death:\n\n\"It is with profound sadness that I acknowledge the passing of Congresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee, a devoted leader, a proud-fellow Houstonian, and someone who I was proud to call a friend.\n\n\"Although we had our political disagreements, there were many moments with her, both public and private, that showed me that bipartisanship and service to country first can still bring members of Congress together.\n\n\"In these divided times, Congresswoman Lee and I were able to partner on several legislative initiatives for the city of the Houston. Her steadfast commitment to serving the people of Houston and her tireless work have left an indelible mark on our community and our nation.", "source": {"uri": "firstcoastnews.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8235125104", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "15:09:32", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T15:09:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T15:07:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/politics/3024281-update-6-us-representative-sheila-jackson-lee-fighter-for-racial-criminal-justice-dies-at-74", "title": "UPDATE 6-US Representative Sheila Jackson Lee, fighter for racial, criminal justice, dies at 74 | Politics", "body": "U.S. Representative Sheila Jackson Lee, a prominent progressive voice in the Democratic Party who was outspoken on African American and women's rights, has died, her family said late on Friday. Jackson Lee of Texas announced last month she had pancreatic cancer and was undergoing treatment. She was 74.\n\n\"The road ahead will not be easy, but I stand in faith that God will strengthen me,\" Jackson Lee, the chief deputy whip in the House of Representatives, said in announcing the diagnosis. Her family said in a statement that she was a local, national and international humanitarian, who fought for racial and criminal justice. \"A fierce champion of the people, she was affectionately and simply known as 'Congresswoman' by her constituents in recognition of her near-ubiquitous presence and service to their daily lives for more than 30 years.\"\n\nPresident Joe Biden, a fellow Democrat, said: \"Always fearless, she spoke truth to power and represented the power of the people of her district in Houston with dignity and grace.\" The 15-term representative, a graduate of Yale College and the University of Virginia Law School, promoted legislation addressing social justice, economic inequality and public health.\n\nJackson Lee, who represented parts of Houston, introduced legislation in the House to make \"Juneteenth\" a federal holiday commemorating the end of the legal enslavement of Black Americans. She was a vocal proponent of police reform in the face of congressional roadblocks after the 2020 police killing of George Floyd, a Black man whose death sparked nationwide protests.\n\nJackson Lee also led legislation in 2022 that re-authorized the Violence Against Women Act, which had expired in 2019. Fellow Democrat Brendan Boyle, ranking member of the House Budget Committee on which she served, called her \"a fierce advocate for the people of Houston and for racial and economic justice everywhere.\"\n\n\"The Congresswoman will be truly missed by all of us who served alongside her,\" he said in a statement. Jackson Lee also served on the U.S. House Judiciary and Homeland Security committees.\n\nJasmine Crockett, like Jackson Lee an African American representative from Texas but in her first term, posted on X: \"I'm at a loss for words so I'll just say rest easy, my friend, Congresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee.\" There were also tributes for Jackson Lee from some politicians at the other end of the political spectrum.\n\n\"While we rarely agreed on policy, I always enjoyed our spirited debates about law and policy, and I counted her as a friend,\" U.S. House of Representatives Speaker Mike Johnson, a Republican who served with her on the judiciary committee for seven years, said in a statement. Governor Greg Abbott, a conservative Republican, posted on X that his wife \"Cecilia and I will forever remember Congresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee,\" adding that \"her legacy of public service and dedication to Texas will live on.\"\n\nU.S. Senator Ted Cruz posted: \"I'm deeply saddened by the passing of my friend & colleague Sheila Jackson Lee. She was a tireless advocate for Houston.\" Jackson Lee considered leaving Congress in 2023 in a bid to become Houston's first female Black mayor, but was defeated in a run-off.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Devdiscourse"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "8234480534", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "04:38:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T04:38:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T04:37:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://lasvegassun.com/news/2024/jul/19/longtime-us-rep-sheila-jackson-lee-of-texas-who-ha/", "title": "Longtime US Rep Sheila Jackson Lee of Texas, who had pancreatic cancer, has died", "body": "Patrick Semansky / AP, file\n\nRep. Shelia Jackson Lee, D-Texas, speaks during a House Judiciary Committee meeting, Dec. 13, 2019, on Capitol Hill in Washington. Longtime U.S. Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee, who helped lead federal efforts to protect women from domestic violence and recognize Juneteenth as a national holiday, has died Friday, July 19, 2024, after battling pancreatic cancer, according to her chief of staff.\n\nBy Jim Vertuno, Associated Press\n\nFriday, July 19, 2024 | 9:26 p.m.\n\nLongtime U.S. Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee of Texas, who helped lead federal efforts to protect women from domestic violence and recognize Juneteenth as a national holiday, has died. She was 74.\n\nLillie Conley, her chief of staff, confirmed Friday night that Jackson Lee, who had pancreatic cancer, had died.\n\nThe Democrat had represented her Houston-based district and the nation's fourth-largest city since 1995. She had previously had breast cancer and announced the pancreatic cancer diagnosis on June 2.\n\n\"The road ahead will not be easy, but I stand in faith that God will strengthen me,\" Jackson Lee said in a statement then.\n\nJackson Lee had just been elected to the Houston district once represented by Barbara Jordan, the first Black woman elected to Congress from a Southern state since Reconstruction, when she was immediately placed on the high-profile House Judiciary Committee in 1995.\n\n\"They just saw me, I guess through my profile, through Barbara Jordan's work,\" Jackson Lee told the Houston Chronicle in 2022. \"I thought it was an honor because they assumed I was going to be the person they needed.\"\n\nJackson Lee quickly established herself as fierce advocate for women and minorities, and a leader for House Democrats on many social justice issues, from policing reform to reparations for descendants of enslaved people. She led the first rewrite of the Violence Against Women Act in nearly a decade, which included protections for Native American, transgender and immigrant women.\n\nJackson Lee was also among the lead lawmakers behind the effort in 2021 to have Juneteenth recognized as the first new federal holiday since Martin Luther King, Jr. Day was established in 1986. The holiday marks the day in 1865 that the last enslaved African Americans in Galveston, Texas, finally learned of their freedom.\n\nA native of Queens, New York, Jackson Lee graduated from Yale and earned her law degree at the University of Virginia. She was a judge in Houston before she was elected to Houston City Council in 1989, then ran for Congress in 1994. She was an advocate for gay rights and an early opponent of the Iraq War in 2003.\n\nJackson Lee routinely won reelection to Congress with ease. The few times she faced a challenger, she never carried less than two-thirds of the vote. Jackson Lee considered leaving Congress in 2023 in a bid to become Houston's first female Black mayor but was defeated in a runoff. She then easily won the Democratic nomination for the 2024 general election.\n\nDuring the mayoral campaign, Jackson Lee expressed regret and said \"everyone deserves to be treated with dignity and respect\" following the release of an unverified audio recording purported to be of the lawmaker berating staff members.\n\nIn 2019, Jackson Lee stepped down from two leadership positions on the House Judiciary Committee and Congressional Black Caucus Foundation, the fundraising of the Congressional Black Caucus, following a lawsuit from a former employee who said her sexual assault complaint was {"uri": "8234846848", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "10:41:27", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T10:41:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T10:40:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://gazette.com/news/us-world/sheila-jackson-lee-strong-democratic-voice-in-us-congress-dies-at-74/article_c20a3fa2-d8db-5d8a-ae1a-886886026f9d.html", "title": "Sheila Jackson Lee, strong Democratic voice in US Congress, dies at 74", "body": "By Surbhi Misra\n\n(Reuters) -U.S. Representative Sheila Jackson Lee, a prominent progressive voice in the Democratic Party who was outspoken on African American and women's rights, has died, her family posted on X late on Friday.\n\nJackson Lee of Texas announced last month she had pancreatic cancer and was undergoing treatment. She was 74, according to U.S. media.\n\n\"The road ahead will not be easy, but I stand in faith that God will strengthen me,\" Jackson Lee, the chief deputy whip in the House of Representatives, said in announcing the diagnosis.\n\n\"A fierce champion of the people, she was affectionately and simply known as 'Congresswoman' by her constituents in recognition of her near-ubiquitous presence and service to their daily lives for more than 30 years,\" her family said in the statement.\n\nThe 15-term representative, a graduate of Yale College and the University of Virginia Law School, was active throughout her career in promoting legislation aimed at addressing social justice, economic inequality and public health concerns.\n\nJackson Lee, who represented parts of Houston, introduced legislation in the House to make \"Juneteenth\" a federal holiday commemorating the end of the legal enslavement of Black Americans.\n\nThe holiday marks the day in 1865 when a Union general informed a group of enslaved people in Texas that they had been made free two years earlier by President Abraham Lincoln's Emancipation Proclamation during the Civil War.\n\nJackson Lee was a vocal proponent of police reform in the face of congressional roadblocks after the 2020 police killing of George Floyd, a Black man whose death sparked nationwide protests.\n\nFellow Democrat Brendan Boyle, ranking member of the House Budget Committee on which she served, called her \"a fierce advocate for the people of Houston and for racial and economic justice everywhere.\"\n\n\"The Congresswoman will be truly missed by all of us who served alongside her,\" he said in a statement.\n\nJackson Lee also served on the judiciary and homeland security committees.\n\nJasmine Crockett, like Jackson Lee an African American representative from Texas but in her first term, posted on X: \"I'm at a loss for words so I'll just say rest easy, my friend, Congresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee.\"\n\nThere were also tributes for Jackson Lee from some Texans at the other end of the political spectrum.\n\nGovernor Greg Abbott, a conservative Republican, posted on X that his wife \"Cecilia and I will forever remember Congresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee,\" adding that \"her legacy of public service and dedication to Texas will live on.\"\n\nU.S. Senator Ted Cruz posted: \"I'm deeply saddened by the passing of my friend & colleague Sheila Jackson Lee. She was a tireless advocate for Houston.\"\n\nJackson Lee considered leaving Congress in 2023 in a bid to become Houston's first female Black mayor, but was defeated in a run-off.\n\n(Reporting by Surbhi Misra in Bengaluru; Editing by William Mallard and Helen Popper)\n\nCLICK HERE TO READ MORE FROM THE GAZETTE", "source": {"uri": "gazette.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Colorado Springs {"uri": "2024-07-427764325", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "04:48:50", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T04:48:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T04:24:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.timesunion.com/news/politics/article/longtime-us-rep-sheila-jackson-lee-of-texas-who-19585431.php", "title": "Longtime US Rep Sheila Jackson Lee of Texas, who had pancreatic cancer, has died", "body": "Longtime U.S. Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee of Texas, who helped lead federal efforts to protect women from domestic violence and recognize Juneteenth as a national holiday, has died. She was 74.\n\nLillie Conley, her chief of staff, confirmed Friday night that Jackson Lee, who had pancreatic cancer, had died.\n\nThe Democrat had represented her Houston-based district and the nation's fourth-largest city since 1995. She had previously had breast cancer and announced the pancreatic cancer diagnosis on June 2.\n\n\"The road ahead will not be easy, but I stand in faith that God will strengthen me,\" Jackson Lee said in a statement then.\n\nJackson Lee had just been elected to the Houston district once represented by Barbara Jordan, the first Black woman elected to Congress from a Southern state since Reconstruction, when she was immediately placed on the high-profile House Judiciary Committee in 1995.\n\n\"They just saw me, I guess through my profile, through Barbara Jordan's work,\" Jackson Lee told the Houston Chronicle in 2022. \"I thought it was an honor because they assumed I was going to be the person they needed.\"\n\nJackson Lee quickly established herself as fierce advocate for women and minorities, and a leader for House Democrats on many social justice issues, from policing reform to reparations for descendants of enslaved people. She led the first rewrite of the Violence Against Women Act in nearly a decade, which included protections for Native American, transgender and immigrant women.\n\nJackson Lee was also among the lead lawmakers behind the effort in 2021 to have Juneteenth recognized as the first new federal holiday since Martin Luther King, Jr. Day was established in 1986. The holiday marks the day in 1865 that the last enslaved African Americans in Galveston, Texas, finally learned of their freedom.\n\nA native of Queens, New York, Jackson Lee graduated from Yale and earned her law degree at the University of Virginia. She was a judge in Houston before she was elected to Houston City Council in 1989, then ran for Congress in 1994. She was an advocate for gay rights and an early opponent of the Iraq War in 2003.\n\nJackson Lee routinely won reelection to Congress with ease. The few times she faced a challenger, she never carried less than two-thirds of the vote. Jackson Lee considered leaving Congress in 2023 in a bid to become Houston's first female Black mayor but was defeated in a runoff. She then easily won the Democratic nomination for the 2024 general election.\n\nDuring the mayoral campaign, Jackson Lee expressed regret and said \"everyone deserves to be treated with dignity and respect\" following the release of an unverified audio recording purported to be of the lawmaker berating staff members.\n\nIn 2019, Jackson Lee stepped down from two leadership positions on the House Judiciary Committee and Congressional Black Caucus Foundation, the fundraising of the Congressional Black Caucus, following a lawsuit from a former employee who said her sexual assault complaint was mishandled.", "source": {"uri": "timesunion.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Times Union"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sheila_Jackson_Lee", "type": "person", {"uri": "8234518231", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "05:31:02", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T05:31:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T05:21:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/texas-rep-sheila-jackson-lee-050943986.html", "title": "Texas Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee dies at age 74", "body": "Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee, a Houston Democrat who had served in Congress since 1995, has died.\n\nHer family announced her death on Friday evening: \"With incredible grief for our loss yet deep gratitude for the life she shared with us, we announce the passing of United States Representative Sheila Jackson Lee of the 18th Congressional District of Texas.\" Jackson Lee's death was confirmed by Lillie Conley, her chief of staff.\n\nJackson Lee was known as a strong advocate for women and minorities, serving in the same Texas district once represented by Barbara Jordan, the first African American woman elected to Congress from the South since the Reconstruction era of the 19th century,\n\nA vocal presence in the Congressional Black Caucus, Jackson Lee was known for her efforts to combat domestic violence through an expansion of the Violence Against Woman Act and also to have Juneteenth recognized as federal holiday, which occurred in 2021.\n\nThe holiday marks the day in 1865 that the last enslaved African Americans in Galveston, Texas, finally learned of their freedom.\n\nIn 2019, following in the footsteps of the late Rep. John Conyers (D-Mich.), she offered a proposal to study the idea of reparations for descendants of former slaves.\n\n\"We want to be responsive to all Americans and we know how diverse this country has become,\" Jackson Lee said in an interview at the time. \"We have consistently, as Democrats, wanted to say to the American people that we are for the people.\"\n\nThe proposal, however, did not advance.\n\nIn its obituary, the Texas Tribune noted how hard she had fought for Houston: \"She often used her trademark chutzpah to fight for federal funds to be sent to Houston. In 2009, she secured $1 billion for the city's light system after cornering then-Transportation Secretary Ray LaHood ahead of then-President Barack Obama's first joint address to Congress. She could reliably be found in the aisle ahead of the State of the Union address, among the few members to directly meet with the president on his way to the dais.\"\n\nTransportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg wrote on X: \"She was an extraordinary advocate for her district and her values, and her impact and achievements will be long remembered.\"\n\nFellow lawmakers in Texas saluted her legacy Friday night.\n\nRep. Colin Allred (D-Texas) wrote on X: \"Congresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee was a fierce advocate for Houston and her constituents. No one worked harder for her community and if Houston needed something, she got it done.\"\n\nAllred also said her death was a blow to the city of Houston, a remark echoed by Rep. Wesley Hunt (R-Texas) in a statement Friday night.\n\n\"It is with profound sadness that I acknowledge the passing of Congresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee, a devoted leader, a proud-fellow Houstonian, and someone who I was proud to call a friend,\" Hunt said.\n\nHe added: \"Although we had our political disagreements, there were many moments with her, both public and private, that showed me that bipartisanship and service to country first can still bring members of Congress together.\"\n\nSen. Ted Cruz also noted her advocacy for her home city. He wrote on X: \"I will always cherish our friendship & the laughs we shared throughout the years.\"\n\nA native of Queens, New York, who was born on Jan. 12, 1950, Jackson Lee graduated from Yale and earned her law degree at the University of Virginia.\n\nShe was a judge in Houston before she was elected to Houston City Council in 1989, then ran for Congress in 1994. She was an advocate for gay rights and an early opponent of the Iraq War in 2003.\n\nJackson Lee routinely won reelection to Congress with ease. The few times she faced a challenger, she never carried less than two-thirds of the vote. But last year, she ran for mayor of Houston only to be defeated by Democratic state Sen. John Whitmire in a runoff in December.\n\nAt her election night party in December, Jackson Lee thanked her supporters, congratulated Whitmire and said she was committed to working with him. \"It's sweeter to be saying what a sweet victory it is. It's equally as sweet to acknowledge we put up a good fight,\" Jackson Lee said.\n\nAlso, in 2019, Jackson Lee stepped down from two leadership positions on the House Judiciary Committee and Congressional Black Caucus Foundation, the fundraising of the Congressional Black Caucus, following a lawsuit from a former employee who said her sexual assault complaint was mishandled.\n\nIn June, Jackson Lee, who was seeking another term in Congress, announced that she has been diagnosed with pancreatic cancer and was undergoing treatment.\n\nThe 74-year-old said in a statement at the time that as a member of Congress, she has been honored to be a leader in the fight for justice and equality and will approach this more personal fight with faith and courage.\"\n\n\"I am confident that my doctors have developed the best possible plan to target my specific disease,\" Jackson Lee said. \"The road ahead will not be easy, but I stand in faith that God will strengthen me.\"", "source": {"uri": "2024-07-427763845", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "04:47:42", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T04:47:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T00:23:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/texas/articles/2024-07-20/longtime-us-rep-sheila-jackson-lee-of-texas-who-had-pancreatic-cancer-has-died", "title": "Longtime US Rep Sheila Jackson Lee of Texas, Who Had Pancreatic Cancer, Has Died", "body": "Longtime U.S. Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee of Texas, who helped lead federal efforts to protect women from domestic violence and recognize Juneteenth as a national holiday, has died. She was 74.\n\nLillie Conley, her chief of staff, confirmed Friday night that Jackson Lee, who had pancreatic cancer, had died.\n\nThe Democrat had represented her Houston-based district and the nation's fourth-largest city since 1995. She had previously had breast cancer and announced the pancreatic cancer diagnosis on June 2.\n\n\"The road ahead will not be easy, but I stand in faith that God will strengthen me,\" Jackson Lee said in a statement then.\n\nJackson Lee had just been elected to the Houston district once represented by Barbara Jordan, the first Black woman elected to Congress from a Southern state since Reconstruction, when she was immediately placed on the high-profile House Judiciary Committee in 1995.\n\n\"They just saw me, I guess through my profile, through Barbara Jordan's work,\" Jackson Lee told the Houston Chronicle in 2022. \"I thought it was an honor because they assumed I was going to be the person they needed.\"\n\nJackson Lee quickly established herself as fierce advocate for women and minorities, and a leader for House Democrats on many social justice issues, from policing reform to reparations for descendants of enslaved people. She led the first rewrite of the Violence Against Women Act in nearly a decade, which included protections for Native American, transgender and immigrant women.\n\nJackson Lee was also among the lead lawmakers behind the effort in 2021 to have Juneteenth recognized as the first new federal holiday since Martin Luther King, Jr. Day was established in 1986. The holiday marks the day in 1865 that the last enslaved African Americans in Galveston, Texas, finally learned of their freedom.\n\nA native of Queens, New York, Jackson Lee graduated from Yale and earned her law degree at the University of Virginia. She was a judge in Houston before she was elected to Houston City Council in 1989, then ran for Congress in 1994. She was an advocate for gay rights and an early opponent of the Iraq War in 2003.\n\nJackson Lee routinely won reelection to Congress with ease. The few times she faced a challenger, she never carried less than two-thirds of the vote. Jackson Lee considered leaving Congress in 2023 in a bid to become Houston's first female Black mayor but was defeated in a runoff. She then easily won the Democratic nomination for the 2024 general election.\n\nDuring the mayoral campaign, Jackson Lee expressed regret and said \"everyone deserves to be treated with dignity and respect\" following the release of an unverified audio recording purported to be of the lawmaker berating staff members.\n\nIn 2019, Jackson Lee stepped down from two leadership positions on the House Judiciary Committee and Congressional Black Caucus Foundation, the fundraising of the Congressional Black Caucus, following a lawsuit from a former employee who said her sexual assault complaint was mishandled.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "8235020646", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "13:25:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T13:25:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T13:24:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/politics-news/rep-sheila-jackson-lee-longtime-congresswoman-houston-dead-obituary-1235064526/", "title": "Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee, Longtime Congresswoman From Houston, Dead at 74", "body": "United States Representative Sheila Jackson Lee of Texas, who represented her Houston district in Congress for nearly 30 years, during which time she led the effort to make Juneteenth a federal holiday and helped author the Violence Against Women Act, has died at the age of 74.\n\nThe congresswoman's family confirmed Jackson Lee's death Friday in a statement; in June, Jackson Lee revealed that she had been diagnosed with pancreatic cancer.\n\n\"Today, with incredible grief for our loss yet deep gratitude for the life she shared with us, we announce the passing of United States Representative Sheila Jackson Lee of the 18th Congressional District of Texas,\" her family said in a statement.\n\n\"A fierce champion of the people, she was affectionately and simply known as 'Congresswoman' by her constituents in recognition of her near-ubiquitous presence and service to their daily lives for more than 30 years.\"\n\nJackson Lee, a Democrat, was born and raised in Queens, New York before moving with her husband Elwyn Lee to Houston. After spending five years on the Houston city council, Jackson Lee ran for the district's House of Representative seat in 1994, winning easily. She officially began representing the district in January 1995, and remained in that position until her death Friday.\n\nThe family's statement continued, \"Her legislative victories impacted millions, from establishing the Juneteenth Federal Holiday to reauthorizing the Violence Against Women Act. However, she impacted us most as our beloved wife, sister, mother, and Bebe (grandmother). She will be dearly missed, but her legacy will continue to inspire all who believe in freedom, justice, and democracy. God bless you Congresswoman and God bless the United States of America.\"\n\nBill and Hillary Clinton said in a statement Saturday following Jackson Lee's death that she was \"a fearless fight for the people of Houston, one of country's most effective leaders, and a wonderful friend to Hillary and me. Throughout her nearly 30 years in Congress, she was an unwavering champion for women and children, a staunch advocate for sensible gun reform, a relentless defender of the Constitution and the cause of justice, an important leader with the Congressional Black Caucus, and so much more.\"\n\nSpeaker of the House Nancy Pelosi added of her \"dear friend\" in a statement, \"Congresswoman Jackson Lee achieved a remarkable legislative record in the Congress for Houston and for our country. As a powerful voice in the Congress for our Constitution and human rights, she fought tirelessly to advance fairness, equity and justice for all. In a testament to her relentless determination, Congresswoman Jackson Lee was the author and lead sponsor of legislation that established Juneteenth as the first new federal holiday in 38 years. And as an author of the Violence Against Women Act, she was a champion for the rights of women.\"", "source": {"uri": "rollingstone.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Rolling Stone"}, "authors": {"uri": "8235091075", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "14:33:52", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T14:33:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T14:32:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.newson6.com/story/669bc4b3c0f5da69c2315af5/longtime-texas-congresswoman-sheila-jackson-lee-dies-at-74", "title": "Longtime Texas Congresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee, Dies At 74", "body": "Democratic Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee of Texas has died, her office announced Friday evening. She was 74 years old.\n\nA cause of death was not immediately disclosed. Last month, however, Jackson Lee revealed that she had been diagnosed with pancreatic cancer.\n\n\"A fierce champion of the people, she was affectionately and simply known as 'Congresswoman' by her constituents in recognition of her near-ubiquitous presence and service to their daily lives for more than 30 years,\" her office said in a statement.\n\nJackson Lee represented the 18th Congressional District, which included portions of Houston.\n\nShe was born in Queens, New York, and graduated from Yale University in 1972 and received her law degree from the University of Virginia Law School. She was a municipal judge before beginning her political career as a member of the Houston City Council in the late 1980s, then made the jump to Congress in 1995. She lost a closely-watched Houston mayoral race last December.\n\nIn a statement, the Congressional Black Caucus praised Jackson Lee as a \"titan and stalwart\" who was a \"fierce advocate for social and economic justice, national and homeland security, energy independence, and children and working families.\"\n\nJackson Lee was lead the sponsor of legislation that was signed into law by President Biden in June 2021 to make Juneteenth a federal holiday.\n\n\"The potential of having this national holiday opens a whole world of discussion for America, a whole reckoning with racism and the systemic racism that permeates the nation,\" she told CBS Mornings in a June 2020 interview.\n\n\"Known for proudly wearing her braided crown, Congresswoman Jackson Lee fought every day for the least, the lost and the left behind, and was a warrior for racial and economic justice,\" House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries said in a statement late Friday, noting that Jackson Lee was also the first woman to ever serve as chair of the House Judiciary Committee's crime subcommittee.\n\nIn confirming her pancreatic cancer diagnosis last month, Jackson Lee said that she was \"undergoing treatment to battle this disease that impacts tens of thousands of Americans every year.\"\n\nBack in 2012, Jackson Lee revealed that she had undergone treatment for breast cancer and made a full recovery. She then worked in Congress to secure millions of dollars in funding for breast cancer research.\n\n\"This is a tremendous loss,\" Sen. Majority Leader Chuck Schumer said in a social media post Friday of her passing. \"Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee fought so hard throughout her life to make our country a better place for all. May her memory be a blessing.\"", "source": {"uri": "newson6.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "News On 6"}, "authors": [{"uri": "griffin_media@newson6.com", "name": "Griffin Media", "type": {"uri": "8234991456", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "12:56:31", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T12:56:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T12:55:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://chicago.suntimes.com/obituaries/2024/07/20/sheila-jackson-lee-congress-juneteenth-domestic-violence-houston-texas-pancreatic-cancer-jason-lee", "title": "U.S. Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee of Texas has died of pancreatic cancer at 74", "body": "Longtime U.S. Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee of Texas, who helped lead federal efforts to protect women from domestic violence and recognize Juneteenth as a national holiday, has died at 74.\n\nLillie Conley, her chief of staff, said Jackson Lee, who had pancreatic cancer, died in Houston Friday night with her family around her.\n\nThe Democrat had represented her Houston-based district and the nation's fourth-largest city since 1995.\n\nShe previously had breast cancer and announced the pancreatic cancer diagnosis on June 2.\n\n\"She was just a rare, rare jewel of a person who relentlessly gave everything she had to make sure others had what they needed,\" said Bishop James Dixon, a longtime friend in Houston who visited her in recent days. \"That was Sheila.\"\n\nJackson Lee had just been elected to the Houston district once represented by Barbara Jordan, the first Black woman elected to Congress from a Southern state since Reconstruction, when she was immediately placed on the high-profile House Judiciary Committee in 1995.\n\n\"They just saw me, I guess through my profile, through Barbara Jordan's work,\" Jackson Lee told the Houston Chronicle in 2022. \"I thought it was an honor because they assumed I was going to be the person they needed.\"\n\nJackson Lee quickly established herself as an advocate for women and minorities and a leader for House Democrats on social justice issues that included policing reform and reparations for descendants of enslaved people. She led the first rewrite of the Violence Against Women Act in nearly a decade, which included protections for Native American, transgender and immigrant women.\n\nJackson Lee was among the lead lawmakers behind the effort in 2021 to recognize Juneteenth as the first new federal holiday since Martin Luther King, Jr. Day was established in 1986. The holiday marks the day in 1865 that the last enslaved African Americans in Galveston, Texas, finally learned of their freedom.\n\nA native of Queens, New York, Jackson Lee graduated from Yale and got a law degree from the University of Virginia. She was a judge in Houston before being elected to the Houston City Council in 1989, then ran for Congress in 1994.\n\nShe was an advocate for gay rights and an early opponent of the Iraq War in 2003.\n\nU.S. Rep. James Clyburn, D-South Carolina, called her \"a tenacious advocate for civil rights and a tireless fighter, improving the lives of her constituents.\"\n\nU.S. Rep. Jamie Raskin, D-Maryland, said she \"studied every bill and every amendment with exactitude and then told Texas and America exactly where she stood.\"\n\nFormer House Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California cited Jackson Lee's \"relentless determination\" in getting Juneteenth declared a national holiday.\n\n\"As a powerful voice in the Congress for our Constitution and human rights, she fought tirelessly to advance fairness, equity and justice for all,\" Pelosi said.\n\nRepublican Texas Gov. Greg Abbott called her a \"tireless advocate for the people of Houston.\"\n\nJackson Lee routinely won reelection to Congress with ease. The few times she faced a challenger, she never carried less than two-thirds of the vote. Jackson Lee considered leaving Congress in 2023 in a bid to become Houston's first female Black mayor but was defeated in a runoff.\n\nShe then easily won the Democratic nomination for the 2024 general election.\n\nDuring the mayoral campaign, Jackson Lee expressed regret and said \"everyone deserves to be treated with dignity and respect\" following the release of an unverified audio recording purported to be of her berating staff members.\n\nIn 2019, Jackson Lee stepped down from two leadership positions on the House Judiciary Committee and Congressional Black Caucus Foundation, the fundraising arm of the Congressional Black Caucus, after a lawsuit from a former employee who said her sexual assault complaint was mishandled.\n\n\"She will be dearly missed, but her legacy will continue to inspire all who believe in freedom, justice, and democracy,\" a written statement from her family said.", "source": {"uri": "chicago.suntimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Chicago {"uri": "8234542891", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "05:53:54", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T05:53:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T05:49:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13653845/Longtime-US-Rep-Sheila-Jackson-Lee-Texas-pancreatic-cancer-died.html", "title": "Longtime US Rep Sheila Jackson Lee of Texas, who had pancreatic...", "body": "Longtime U.S. Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee of Texas, who helped lead federal efforts to protect women from domestic violence and recognize Juneteenth as a national holiday, has died. She was 74.\n\nLillie Conley, her chief of staff, confirmed Friday night that Jackson Lee, who had pancreatic cancer, had died.\n\nThe Democrat had represented her Houston-based district and the nation\u00b4s fourth-largest city since 1995. She had previously had breast cancer and announced the pancreatic cancer diagnosis on June 2.\n\n\"The road ahead will not be easy, but I stand in faith that God will strengthen me,\" Jackson Lee said in a statement then.\n\nJackson Lee had just been elected to the Houston district once represented by Barbara Jordan, the first Black woman elected to Congress from a Southern state since Reconstruction, when she was immediately placed on the high-profile House Judiciary Committee in 1995.\n\n\"They just saw me, I guess through my profile, through Barbara Jordan\u00b4s work,\" Jackson Lee told the Houston Chronicle in 2022. \"I thought it was an honor because they assumed I was going to be the person they needed.\"\n\nFILE - Rep. Shelia Jackson Lee, D-Texas, speaks during a House Judiciary Committee meeting, Dec. 13, 2019, on Capitol Hill in Washington. Longtime U.S. Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee, who helped lead federal efforts to protect women from domestic violence and recognize Juneteenth as a national holiday, has died Friday, July 19, 2024, after battling pancreatic cancer, according to her chief of staff. (AP Photo/Patrick Semansky, Pool, File)\n\nJackson Lee quickly established herself as fierce advocate for women and minorities, and a leader for House Democrats on many social justice issues, from policing reform to reparations for descendants of enslaved people. She led the first rewrite of the Violence Against Women Act in nearly a decade, which included protections for Native American, transgender and immigrant women.\n\nJackson Lee was also among the lead lawmakers behind the effort in 2021 to have Juneteenth recognized as the first new federal holiday since Martin Luther King, Jr. Day was established in 1986. The holiday marks the day in 1865 that the last enslaved African Americans in Galveston, Texas, finally learned of their freedom.\n\nA native of Queens, New York, Jackson Lee graduated from Yale and earned her law degree at the University of Virginia. She was a judge in Houston before she was elected to Houston City Council in 1989, then ran for Congress in 1994. She was an advocate for gay rights and an early opponent of the Iraq War in 2003.\n\nJackson Lee routinely won reelection to Congress with ease. The few times she faced a challenger, she never carried less than two-thirds of the vote. Jackson Lee considered leaving Congress in 2023 in a bid to become Houston\u00b4s first female Black mayor but was defeated in a runoff. She then easily won the Democratic nomination for the 2024 general election.\n\nDuring the mayoral campaign, Jackson Lee expressed regret and said \"everyone deserves to be treated with dignity and respect\" following the release of an unverified audio recording purported to be of the lawmaker berating staff members.\n\nIn 2019, Jackson Lee stepped down from two leadership positions on the House Judiciary Committee and Congressional Black Caucus Foundation, the fundraising of the Congressional Black Caucus, following a lawsuit from a former employee who said her sexual assault complaint was mishandled.\n\nFILE - U.S. Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee, center, D-Texas, speaks during an immigration rally in Guadalupe Plaza in Houston, Texas, April 10, 2006. Longtime U.S. Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee, who helped lead federal efforts to protect women from domestic violence and recognize Juneteenth as a national holiday, has died Friday, July 19, 2024, after battling pancreatic cancer, according to her chief of staff. (AP Photo/Donna Carson, File)\n\nFILE - Supreme Court nominee Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson, right, talks with Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee, D-Texas, during a break in Jackson's confirmation hearing before the Senate Judiciary Committee, March 21, 2022, on Capitol Hill in Washington. Longtime U.S. Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee, who helped lead federal efforts to protect women from domestic violence and recognize Juneteenth as a national holiday, has died Friday, July 19, 2024, after battling pancreatic cancer, according to her chief of staff. (AP Photo/Jacquelyn Martin, File)\n\nFILE - Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee, D-Texas, speaks in support of Democratic gun control measures, called the Protecting Our Kids Act, in response to mass shootings in Texas and New York, at the Capitol in Washington, June 2, 2022. Longtime U.S. Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee, who helped lead federal efforts to protect women from domestic violence and recognize Juneteenth as a national holiday, has died Friday, July 19, 2024, after battling pancreatic cancer, according to her chief of staff. (AP Photo/J. Sheila Jackson Lee, a stalwart Democratic congresswoman from Texas, has passed away at the age of 74 following a battle with pancreatic cancer, her family announced on Friday.\n\n\"Today, with incredible grief for our loss yet deep gratitude for the life she shared with us, we announce the passing of United States Representative Sheila Jackson Lee of the 18th Congressional District of Texas,\" her family said in a statement shared on X.\n\n\"A local, national, and international humanitarian, she was acknowledged worldwide for her courageous fights for racial justice, criminal justice, and human rights, with a special emphasis on women and children,\" the statement added.\n\nIn June, Jackson Lee disclosed her diagnosis of pancreatic cancer and began undergoing treatment.\n\nHaving served in the House of Representatives since 1995, Jackson Lee leaves behind a formidable legacy of championing civil rights legislation. She was the lead sponsor of the Juneteenth National Independence Day Act, instrumental in the passage of the Sentencing Reform Act of 2015, and a driving force behind the George Floyd Law Enforcement Trust and Integrity Act.\n\nThe Texas Democrat also played a pivotal role in reauthorizing the Violence Against Women Act, which President Joe Biden signed in 2022.\n\nBorn in Queens, New York, Jackson Lee graduated from Yale University and the University of Virginia Law School. She started her career as a lawyer in private practice and as staff counsel for the House Select Committee on Assassinations. She went on to serve in Houston's government as a City Council member and municipal judge before her election to Congress. During her tenure, she sat on the Judiciary, Homeland Security, and Budget committees.\n\nIn 2023, Jackson Lee ran for mayor of Houston but lost in a runoff to state Sen. John Whitmire. She was subsequently reelected to her House seat.\n\nFuneral arrangements for the congresswoman are pending, according to her family. \"She will be dearly missed, but her legacy will continue to inspire all who believe in freedom, justice, and democracy,\" their statement concluded. \"God bless you, Congresswoman, and God bless the United States of America.\"\n\nCongresswoman Sheila Jackson Sheila Jackson Lee dies at 74", "body": "House Democratic Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee of Texas has died, according to a statement issued Friday night from her family.\n\nThe congresswoman died at the age of 74.\n\n\"With incredible grief for our loss yet deep gratitude for the life she shared with us, we announce the passing of United States Representative Sheila Jackson Lee of the 18th Congressional District of Texas,\" her family said in a statement.\n\n\"A local, national, and international humanitarian, she was acknowledged worldwide for her courageous fights for racial justice, criminal justice, and human rights, with a special emphasis on women and children,\" the statement continued.\n\nRep. Jackson Lee was diagnosed with pancreatic cancer in June.\n\n\"She will be dearly missed, but her legacy will continue to inspire all who believe in freedom, justice and democracy,\" her family said.\n\nA member of the Congressional Black Caucus, she has served in Congress for roughly 30 years. Most recently, Jackson Lee reintroduced the George Floyd Justice in Policing Act in May.\n\nJackson Lee, who represented Texas' 18th District, which encompasses parts of Houston, recently won a primary election to regain her seat.", "source": {"uri": "ca.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8234649754", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "07:37:02", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T07:37:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T07:36:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://buffalonews.com/news/national/longtime-us-rep-sheila-jackson-lee-of-texas-who-had-pancreatic-cancer-has-died/article_1695cf3b-aab0-5822-b683-c9a19b036165.html", "title": "Longtime US Rep Sheila Jackson Lee of Texas, who had pancreatic cancer, has died", "body": "By JIM VERTUNO - Associated Press\n\nLongtime U.S. Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee of Texas, who helped lead federal efforts to protect women from domestic violence and recognize Juneteenth as a national holiday, has died. She was 74.\n\nLillie Conley, her chief of staff, confirmed that Jackson Lee, who had pancreatic cancer, died in Houston Friday night with her family around her.\n\nThe Democrat had represented her Houston-based district and the nation's fourth-largest city since 1995. She had previously had breast cancer and announced the pancreatic cancer diagnosis on June 2.\n\n\"The road ahead will not be easy, but I stand in faith that God will strengthen me,\" Jackson Lee said in a statement then.\n\nBishop James Dixon, a longtime friend in Houston who visited Jackson Lee earlier this week, said he will remember her as a fighter.\n\nPeople are also reading... After two years of interest, Bills and DeShawn Williams strike a deal Juicy Burger Bar opening new restaurant on Hamburg waterfront Ex-Buffalo Sabres captain Kyle Okposo's thank-you letter to city, franchise Tops worker in Cheektowaga helps save customer who had medical emergency in parking lot Pit bull attack severs woman's arm the day before dog was to be put down 'A major milestone': Ralph Wilson Park bridge arrives in Buffalo Where to take out-of-town guests to eat around Buffalo First of $23.5 million worth of affordable homes will be built in Cheektowaga Jericho Road 'deeply saddened' but says services will remain uninterrupted after half-million dollar theft Sabres mailbag: Is Ryan McLeod the last offseason addition for Lindy Ruff? Amazon's new Rochester distribution center foreshadows what's coming to Niagara Erie County real estate transactions Judge orders Battaglia Demolition owner to spend 6 months in jail Authorities hunt for clues, but motive of man who tried to assassinate Donald Trump remains elusive Crane at new Bills stadium site damaged during storm that brought tornadoes to area\n\n\"She was just a rare, rare jewel of a person who relentlessly gave everything she had to make sure others had what they needed. That was Sheila,\" he said.\n\nJackson Lee had just been elected to the Houston district once represented by Barbara Jordan, the first Black woman elected to Congress from a Southern state since Reconstruction, when she was immediately placed on the high-profile House Judiciary Committee in 1995.\n\n\"They just saw me, I guess through my profile, through Barbara Jordan's work,\" Jackson Lee told the Houston Chronicle in 2022. \"I thought it was an honor because they assumed I was going to be the person they needed.\"\n\nJackson Lee quickly established herself as fierce advocate for women and minorities, and a leader for House Democrats on many social justice issues, from policing reform to reparations for descendants of enslaved people. She led the first rewrite of the Violence Against Women Act in nearly a decade, which included protections for Native American, transgender and immigrant women.\n\nJackson Lee was also among the lead lawmakers behind the effort in 2021 to have Juneteenth recognized as the first new federal holiday since Martin Luther King, Jr. Day was established in 1986. The holiday marks the day in 1865 that the last enslaved African Americans in Galveston, Texas, finally learned of their freedom.\n\nA native of Queens, New York, Jackson Lee graduated from Yale and earned her law degree at the University of Virginia. She was a judge in Houston before she was elected to Houston City Council in 1989, then ran for Congress in 1994. She was an advocate for gay rights and an early opponent of the Iraq War in 2003.\n\nTop congressional Democrats reacted quickly to the news Friday night, praising her commitment and work ethic.\n\nRep. James Clyburn of South Carolina called her \"a tenacious advocate for civil rights and a tireless fighter, improving the lives of her constituents.\"\n\nRep. Jamie Raskin of Maryland said he had never known a harder-working lawmaker than Jackson Lee, saying she \"studied every bill and every amendment with exactitude and then told Texas and America exactly where she stood.\"\n\nFormer House Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California cited Jackson Lee's \"relentless determination\" in getting Juneteenth declared a national holiday.\n\n\"As a powerful voice in the Congress for our Constitution and human rights, she fought tirelessly to advance fairness, equity and justice for all,\" Pelosi said.\n\nRepublican Texas Gov. Greg Abbott said he and his wife Cecilia will always remember Jackson Lee, calling her a \"tireless advocate for the people of Houston.\"\n\n\"Her legacy of public service and dedication to Texas will live on,\" he said.\n\nJackson Lee routinely won reelection to Congress with ease. The few times she faced a challenger, she never carried less than two-thirds of the vote. Jackson Lee considered leaving Congress in 2023 in a bid to become Houston's first female Black mayor but was defeated in a runoff. She then easily won the Democratic nomination for the 2024 general election.\n\nDuring the mayoral campaign, Jackson Lee expressed regret and said \"everyone deserves to be treated with dignity and respect\" following the release of an unverified audio recording purported to be of the lawmaker berating staff members.\n\nIn 2019, Jackson Lee stepped down from two leadership positions on the House Judiciary Committee and Congressional Black Caucus Foundation, the fundraising of the Congressional Black Caucus, following a lawsuit from a former employee who said her sexual assault complaint was mishandled.\n\nIn a statement, Jackson Lee's family said she had been a beloved wife, sister, mother and grandmother known as Bebe.\n\n\"She will be dearly missed, but her legacy will continue to inspire all who believe in freedom, justice, and democracy,\" the statement said. \"God bless you Congresswoman and God bless the United States of America.\"\n\nAssociated Press writer Lou Kesten contributed to this story from Washington.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.aol.co.uk/news/us-congresswoman-sheila-jackson-lee-042611981.html", "title": "US congresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee dies aged 74", "body": "US congresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee dies aged 74\n\nOur Foreign Staff\n\n20 July 2024 at 6:26 am\n\nUS congresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee, a strong progressive voice in the Democratic Party who was outspoken on African-American and women's rights, has died aged 74.\n\nMs Jackson Lee, who represented parts of Houston, Texas, announced last month she had pancreatic cancer and was undergoing treatment.\n\n\"Today, with incredible grief for our loss yet deep gratitude for the life she shared with us, we announce the passing of United States Representative Sheila Jackson Lee of the 18th Congressional District of Texas,\" her family said in a statement on Friday.\n\n\"A fierce champion of the people, she was affectionately and simply known as 'Congresswoman' by her constituents in recognition of her near-ubiquitous presence and service to their daily lives for more than 30 years.\"\n\nMs Jackson Lee, was active throughout her career in promoting legislation aimed at addressing social justice, economic inequality and public health concerns.\n\nShe introduced a legislation in the House of Representatives to make \"Juneteenth\" a federal holiday commemorating the end of the legal enslavement of Black Americans.\n\nThe holiday marks the day in 1865 when a Union general informed a group of enslaved people in Texas that they had been made free two years earlier by President Abraham Lincoln's Emancipation Proclamation during the Civil War.\n\nMs Jackson Lee served on several House committees, including judiciary, homeland security and budget.", "source": {"uri": Sheila Jackson Lee, has died at 74 \" \u00a1Que Onda Magazine!", "body": "HOUSTON, Texas (KTRK) -- U.S. Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee, a three-decade member of Congress and a voice for a predominantly Hispanic and Black Houston district, has died, the 74-year-old's family said on Friday.\n\n\"Today, with incredible grief of our loss yet deep gratitude for the life she shared with us, we announced the passing of United States Representative Sheila Jackson Lee of the 18th Congressional District of Texas,\" Jackson Lee's family wrote. \"A fierce champion of the people, she was affectionately and simply known as 'Congresswoman' by her constituents in recognition of her near-ubiquitous presence and service to their daily lives for more than 30 years.\n\nThe lawmaker's family said funeral arrangements are pending.\n\nEarly last month, Jackson Lee revealed she was diagnosed with pancreatic cancer and undergoing treatment, adding that she would be occasionally absent from her Congressional duties.\n\n\"I am confident that my doctors have developed the best possible plan to target my specific diseases. The road ahead will not be easy, but I stand in faith that God will strengthen me,\" Jackson Lee said in a statement on June 2.\n\nA prayer and praise vigil was held shortly after in support of her fight. Jackson Lee's family or office didn't disclose whether her cancer was the cause of her death.\n\nThe Democrat's office boasted her accomplishments since she won her seat in 1994, crediting her with establishing the Juneteenth Federal Holiday and reauthorizing the Violence Against Women Act.\n\n\"However, she impacted us most as our beloved wife, sister, mother, and Bebe (grandmother),\" Jackson Lee's representatives said.\n\nJackson Lee is survived by her husband Elwyn Lee and their two children.\n\nWorking in her last days\n\nJust a week prior, Jackson Lee advocated on behalf of CenterPoint Energy customers by calling on the U.S. Department of Justice to investigate the utility company's response to Hurricane Beryl.\n\nJackson Lee was also months away from going for her 16th term in the U.S. House of Representatives after winning her Democratic primary in March.\n\nThe lawmaker fell late last year in her bid to become the next Houston mayor in a runoff against winner John Whitmire.\n\nBefore ascending to the Capitol, she was elected to Houston City Council in 1989, serving the city until her congressional election.", "source": {"uri": "queondamagazine.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8234508677", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "05:11:44", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T05:11:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T05:10:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "http://theatlantavoice.com/us-rep-sheila-jackson-lee-dies/", "title": "U.S. Congresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee passes away after battle with cancer", "body": "U.S. Representative Sheila Jackson Lee passed away Friday evening after battling pancreatic cancer. She was 74. Jackson Lee represented Texas's 18th Congressional District, which includes portions of Houston.\n\nSheila Jackson Lee entered politics after being named to a municipal judge seat in Houston and in 1989, she was elected to the Houston City Council.\n\nJackson Lee was elected to Congress in 1994 after defeating Craig Washington. During her time in the U.S. House of Representatives, Jackson Lee focused on issues of race, social inequality, LGBTQ+ rights and immigration.\n\nNotably on January 3, 2019, Jackson Lee introduced U.S. House Bill 40. The bill was reparations legislation that focuses on truth, racial healing, and transformation.\n\n\"I want to give them the honor that they deserve. And that is to recognize the insurmountable odds that some of them had and how they continue to plant seeds of respect and dignity in their children,\" said Jackson Lee in an interview with the National Newspaper Publishers Association (NNPA). \"Has anyone addressed the question of slavery and its comprehensive impact on Black Americans in this country? This is what H.R. 40 will do.\"\n\nJackson Lee was also on the front lines after every major disaster. She distributed food after Hurricane Ike flooded Houston in 2008 and after Hurricane Harvey dumped fifty inches of rain in 2017. During the COVID-19 outbreak in 2020, Jackson Lee fought for enhanced funding for small, urban and rural hospitals that were fighting to care for afflicted patients.\n\nIn 2023, Jackson Lee was unsuccessful in her effort to become the Mayor of Houston. However in March 2024, she defeated Amanda Edwards in a Democratic primary. Three months later, Jackson Lee announced her diagnosis.\n\n\"My doctors have confirmed my diagnosis of pancreatic cancer,\" she wrote in a statement. \"I am currently undergoing treatment to battle this disease that impacts tens of thousands of Americans every year.\"\n\n\"I am confident that my doctors have developed the best possible plan to target my specific disease,\" she continued. \"The road ahead will not be easy, but I stand in faith that God will strengthen me.\"\n\nJackson Lee was one of the standout members of the Congressional Black Caucus. Caucus chair, U.S. Representative Steven Horsford, D-Nevada, issued the following statement. It reads in part:\n\n\"Representative Jackson Lee was a titan and stalwart member of Congress who served the Houston area and our country honorably for nearly 30 years in the U.S. Congress. From the Houston City Council to the U.S. Congress, Congresswoman Jackson Lee was a fierce advocate for social and economic justice, national and homeland security, energy independence, and children and working families.\n\n\"A former CBC Whip and chair of the Congressional Black Caucus Foundation, Congresswoman Jackson Lee was a devoted and active member of our Caucus who championed many causes including racial equity and improving policing and community safety in America - most recently reintroducing the George Floyd Justice in Policing Act in May 2024.\"\n\nJackson Lee is survived by her husband, Elwyn Lee, and her two children, Jason Lee, a graduate of Harvard University, and Erica Lee, a graduate of Duke University, who is also a Member of the Harris County School Board in Houston. She is also survived by her two grandchildren, Ellison Bennett Carter, and Roy Lee Carter.", "source": {"uri": "theatlantavoice.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Atlanta Voice | Atlanta GA News"}, "authors": [{"uri": "itoro_n_umontuen@theatlantavoice.com", "name": "Itoro N. Sheila Jackson Lee dies at age 74", "body": "Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee, D-Texas, has died at the age of 74 after a battle with cancer, her family announced on Friday.\n\nHer family did not specify a cause of death, but the news comes just over one month after the Congresswoman revealed that she had been diagnosed with pancreatic cancer.\n\nJackson Lee, who has represented Texas' 18th Congressional District for nearly three decades, revealed her battle with pancreatic cancer in June.\n\n\"Today, with incredible grief for our loss yet deep gratitude for the life she shared with us, we announce the passing of United States Representative Sheila Jackson Lee of the 18th Congressional District of Texas,\" her family said in a statement.\n\n\"A local, national, and international humanitarian, she was acknowledged worldwide for her courageous fights for racial justice, criminal justice, and human rights, with a special emphasis on women and children,\" the statement said.\n\nThe longtime congresswoman served in the House since 1995 and leaves a legacy of pushing for legislation related to civil rights. Jackson Lee was the lead sponsor of the Juneteenth National Independence Day Act, and she pushed for the Sentencing Reform Act of 2015, as well as the George Floyd Law Enforcement Trust and Integrity Act.\n\nShe sat on the Judiciary, Homeland Security and Budget committees.\n\nJackson Lee is survived by her husband, Elwyn Lee, and her two children, Jason Lee, a graduate of Harvard University, and Erica Lee, a graduate of Duke University, who is also a Member of the Harris County School Board in Houston. {"uri": "8234434079", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "03:42:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T03:42:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T03:41:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://abc7chicago.com/post/texas-congresswoman-sheila-jackson-lee-mother-jason-lee/15073381/", "title": "Texas Congresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee, mother of top adviser to Chicago mayor, dies at 74", "body": "HOUSTON, Texas -- U.S. Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee, a three-decade member of Congress, has died, the 74-year-old's family said on Friday.\n\n\"Today, with incredible grief of our loss yet deep gratitude for the life she shared with us, we announced the passing of United States Representative Sheila Jackson Lee of the 18th Congressional District of Texas,\" Jackson Lee's family wrote. \"A fierce champion of the people, she was affectionately and simply known as 'Congresswoman' by her constituents in recognition of her near-ubiquitous presence and service to their daily lives for more than 30 years.\n\nShe is the mother of Jason Lee, a top adviser to Chicago Mayor Brandon Johnson.\n\nThe lawmaker's family said funeral arrangements are pending.\n\nEarly last month, Jackson Lee revealed she was diagnosed with pancreatic cancer and undergoing treatment, adding that she would be occasionally absent from her Congressional duties.\n\n\"I am confident that my doctors have developed the best possible plan to target my specific diseases. The road ahead will not be easy, but I stand in faith that God will strengthen me,\" Jackson Lee said in a statement on June 2.\n\nA prayer and praise vigil was held shortly after in support of her fight. Jackson Lee's family or office didn't disclose whether her cancer was the cause of her death.\n\nThe Democrat's office boasted her accomplishments since she won her seat in 1994, crediting her with establishing the Juneteenth Federal Holiday and reauthorizing the Violence Against Women Act.\n\n\"However, she impacted us most as our beloved wife, sister, mother, and Bebe (grandmother),\" Jackson Lee's representatives said.\n\nJackson Lee is survived by her husband Elwyn Lee and their two children.\n\nJust a week prior, Jackson Lee advocated on behalf of CenterPoint Energy customers by calling on the U.S. Department of Justice to investigate the utility company's response to Hurricane Beryl.\n\nJackson Lee was also months away from going for her 16th term in the U.S. House of Representatives after winning her Democratic primary.\n\nThe lawmaker fell last fall in her attempt to become the next Houston mayor in a close race against winner John Whitmire.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-427779167", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "05:16:24", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T05:16:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T01:09:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.politico.com/news/2024/07/20/texas-rep-sheila-jackson-lee-dies-at-age-74-00169909", "title": "Texas Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee dies at age 74", "body": "Her family announced her death on Friday evening: \"With incredible grief for our loss yet deep gratitude for the life she shared with us, we announce the passing of United States Representative Sheila Jackson Lee of the 18th Congressional District of Texas.\" Jackson Lee's death was confirmed by Lillie Conley, her chief of staff.\n\nJackson Lee was known as a strong advocate for women and minorities, serving in the same Texas district once represented by Barbara Jordan, the first African American woman elected to Congress from the South since the 19th century,\n\nShe was known for her efforts to combat domestic violence through an expansion of the Violence Against Woman Act and also to have Juneteenth recognized as federal holiday, which occurred in 2021. The holiday marks the day in 1865 that the last enslaved African Americans in Galveston, Texas, finally learned of their freedom.\n\nIn 2019, following in the footsteps of the late Rep. John Conyers (D-Mich.), she offered a proposal to study the idea of reparations for descendants of former slaves.\n\n\"We want to be responsive to all Americans and we know how diverse this country has become,\" Jackson Lee said in an interview at the time. \"We have consistently, as Democrats, wanted to say to the American people that we are for the people.\"\n\nThe proposal, however, did not advance.\n\nIn its obituary, the Texas Tribune noted how hard she had fought for Houston: \"She often used her trademark chutzpah to fight for federal funds to be sent to Houston. In 2009, she secured $1 billion for the city's light system after cornering then-Transportation Secretary Ray LaHood ahead of then-President Barack Obama's first joint address to Congress. She could reliably be found in the aisle ahead of the State of the Union address, among the few members to directly meet with the president on his way to the dais.\"\n\nTransportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg wrote on X: \"She was an extraordinary advocate for her district and her values, and her impact and achievements will be long remembered.\"\n\nFellow lawmakers in Texas saluted her legacy Friday night.\n\nRep. Colin Allred (D-Texas) wrote on X: \"Congresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee was a fierce advocate for Houston and her constituents. No one worked harder for her community and if Houston needed something, she got it done.\"\n\nAllred also said her death was a blow to the city of Houston, a remark echoed by Rep. Wesley Hunt (R-Texas) in a statement Friday night.\n\n\"It is with profound sadness that I acknowledge the passing of Congresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee, a devoted leader, a proud-fellow Houstonian, and someone who I was proud to call a friend,\" Hunt said.\n\nHe added: \"Although we had our political disagreements, there were many moments with her, both public and private, that showed me that bipartisanship and service to country first can still bring members of Congress together.\"\n\nA native of Queens, New York, Jackson Lee graduated from Yale and earned her law degree at the University of Virginia. She was a judge in Houston before she was elected to Houston City Council in 1989, then ran for Congress in 1994. She was an advocate for gay rights and an early opponent of the Iraq War in 2003.\n\nJackson Lee routinely won reelection to Congress with ease. The few times she faced a challenger, she never carried less than two-thirds of the vote. But last year, she ran for mayor of Houston only to be defeated by Democratic state Sen. John Whitmire in a runoff in December.\n\nAt her election night party in December, Jackson Lee thanked her supporters, congratulated Whitmire and said she was committed to working with him. \"It's sweeter to be saying what a sweet victory it is. It's equally as sweet to acknowledge we put up a good fight,\" Jackson Lee said.\n\nAlso, in 2019, Jackson Lee stepped down from two leadership positions on the House Judiciary Committee and Congressional Black Caucus Foundation, the fundraising of the Congressional Black Caucus, following a lawsuit from a former employee who said her sexual assault complaint was mishandled.\n\nIn June, Jackson Lee, who was seeking another term in Congress, announced that she has been diagnosed with pancreatic cancer and was undergoing treatment.\n\nThe 74-year-old said in a statement at the time that as a member of Congress, she has been honored to be a leader in the fight for justice and equality and will approach this more personal fight with faith and courage.\"\n\n\"I am confident that my doctors have developed the best possible plan to target my specific disease,\" Jackson Lee said. \"The road ahead will not be easy, but I stand in faith that God will strengthen me.\"", "source":
