Jackson Lee's family released a statement on her passing.\n\n\"A fierce champion of the people, she was affectionately and simply known as 'Congresswoman' by her constituents in recognition of her near-ubiquitous presence and service to their daily lives for more than 30 years,\" the statement said. \"A local, national, and international humanitarian, she was acknowledged worldwide for her courageous fights for racial justice, criminal justice, and human rights, with a special emphasis on women and children.\"\n\n\"Her legislative victories impacted millions, from establishing the Juneteenth Federal Holiday to reauthorizing the Violence Against Women Act,\" the statement continued. \"However, she impacted us most as our beloved wife, sister, mother, and Bebe (grandmother). She will be dearly missed, but her legacy will continue to inspire all who believe in freedom, justice, and democracy.\"\n\nIn June 2024, Jackson Lee announced that she was diagnosed with pancreatic cancer. At that time, Jackson Lee said that the road ahead would \"not be easy\" and she had \"faith that God will strengthen me.\"\n\nJackson Lee represented Texas' 18th District and had recently won a primary election to regain her seat, after a failed campaign for Houston mayor. She served in Congress for almost 30 years and was a member of the Congressional Black Caucus.\n\nJackson Lee was also an advocate for public education and called for the education department's Office {"uri": "8234641301", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "07:30:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T07:30:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T07:28:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/rep-sheila-jackson-lee-dies-070711953.html", "title": "Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee dies after battle with cancer", "body": "\"Today, with incredible grief for our loss yet deep gratitude for the life she shared with us, we announce the passing of United States Representative Sheila Jackson Lee of the 18th Congressional District of Texas,\" her family said in a statement.\n\n\"A local, national, and international humanitarian, she was acknowledged worldwide for her courageous fights for racial justice, criminal justice, and human rights, with a special emphasis on women and children,\" the statement said.\n\nJackson Lee announced in June that she had been diagnosed with pancreatic cancer and was undergoing treatment.\n\nThe longtime congresswoman served in the House since 1995 and leaves a legacy of pushing for legislation related to civil rights.\n\nJackson Lee was the lead sponsor of the Juneteenth National Independence Day Act, and she pushed for the Sentencing Reform Act of 2015, as well as the George Floyd Law Enforcement Trust and Integrity Act.\n\n\"This is America's holiday. And America's holiday is not just for Black people,\" Jackson Lee said of Juneteenth in a 2023 MSNBC interview. \"It is about freedom, and it is about democracy.\"\n\nThe Texas Democrat introduced legislation for the reauthorization of the Violence Against Women Act, which President Joe Biden signed in 2022.\n\nJackson Lee was born in Queens, New York. A graduate of Yale University and the University of Virginia Law School, she worked as a lawyer in private practice and as a staff counsel for the House Select Committee on Assassinations.\n\nShe went on to serve in Houston's government as a member of the City Council and municipal judge before being elected to Congress, where she sat on the Judiciary, Homeland Security and Budget committees.\n\nJackson Lee ran for Houston mayor in 2023 but ultimately lost in a runoff to state Sen. John Whitmire. She was later reelected to her House seat.\n\nCongressional colleagues and political figures from both sides of the aisle remembered Jackson Lee and her commitment to her constituents.\n\nTexas Gov. Greg Abbott, a Republican, said in a post that Jackson Lee was \"a proud Texan and a tireless advocate for the people of Houston.\"\n\n\"Her legacy of public service and dedication to Texas will live on,\" he said.\n\nSen. Ted Cruz, R-Texas, said he was \"deeply saddened\" by the death of his friend and colleague. \"I will always cherish our friendship & the laughs we shared throughout the years,\" Cruz said.\n\n\"No one worked harder for her community and if Houston needed something, she got it done,\" Sen. Colin Allred, D-Texas, said.\n\nFormer Houston Mayor Sylvester Turner, whom she ran to succeed last year, wrote that Jackson Lee's work on the ground as well as \"her uncanny ability to be everywhere, working every day for those who needed a champion, made her truly exceptional.\"\n\nJackson Lee's family said that funeral arrangements for the congresswoman are pending.\n\n\"She will be dearly missed, but her legacy will continue to inspire all who believe in freedom, justice, and democracy,\" her family's statement concluded. \"God bless you Congresswoman and God bless the United States of America.\"\n\nShe is survived by her husband, two children and two grandchildren.", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8234641764", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "07:30:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T07:30:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T07:28:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/pa/article-13653941/US-representative-Sheila-Jackson-Lee-dies-aged-74.html", "title": "US representative Sheila Jackson Lee dies aged 74", "body": "Long-standing US representative Sheila Jackson Lee of Texas, who helped lead federal efforts to protect women from domestic violence and recognise Juneteenth as a national holiday, has died aged 74.\n\nMs Jackson Lee, who had pancreatic cancer, died in Houston on Friday night with her family around her, her chief of staff confirmed.\n\nThe Democrat had represented her Houston-based district and America's fourth-largest city since 1995. She had previously had breast cancer and announced the pancreatic cancer diagnosis on June 2.\n\nAt the time, Ms Jackson Lee said: \"The road ahead will not be easy, but I stand in faith that God will strengthen me.\"\n\nBishop James Dixon, a friend in Houston who visited Jackson Lee earlier this week, said he will remember her as a fighter.\n\nSheila Jackson Lee represented one of America\u00b4s largest cities (Houston Chronicle via AP)\n\n\"She was just a rare, rare jewel of a person who relentlessly gave everything she had to make sure others had what they needed. That was Sheila,\" he said.\n\nMs Jackson Lee had just been elected to the Houston district once represented by Barbara Jordan, the first black woman elected to congress from a Southern state since Reconstruction, when she was immediately placed on the high-profile house judiciary committee in 1995.\n\n\"They just saw me, I guess through my profile, through Barbara Jordan's work,\" Ms Jackson Lee told the Houston Chronicle in 2022. \"I thought it was an honour because they assumed I was going to be the person they needed.\"\n\nMs Jackson Lee quickly established herself as fierce advocate for women and minorities, and a leader for House Democrats on many social justice issues, from policing reform to reparations for descendants of enslaved people.\n\nShe led the first rewrite of the Violence Against Women Act in nearly a decade, which included protections for Native American, transgender and immigrant women.\n\nMs Jackson Lee was also among the lead legislators behind the effort in 2021 to have Juneteenth recognised as the first new federal holiday since Martin Luther King, Jr Day was established in 1986.\n\nMs Jackson Lee helped lead federal efforts to protect women from domestic violence and recognise Juneteenth as a national holiday (AP)\n\nThe holiday marks the day in 1865 (June 19) that the last enslaved African Americans in Galveston, Texas, finally learned of their freedom.\n\nA native of Queens, New York, Jackson Lee graduated from Yale and earned her law degree at the University of Virginia. She was a judge in Houston before she was elected to Houston City Council in 1989, then ran for Congress in 1994. She was an advocate for gay rights and an early opponent of the Iraq War in 2003.\n\nTop congressional Democrats reacted quickly to the news, praising her commitment and work ethic.\n\nJames Clyburn of South Carolina called her \"a tenacious advocate for civil rights and a tireless fighter, improving the lives of her constituents\".\n\nJamie Raskin of Maryland said he had never known a harder-working legislators than Ms Jackson Lee, saying she \"studied every bill and every amendment with exactitude and then told Texas and America exactly where she stood\".\n\nFormer House Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California cited Ms Jackson Lee's \"relentless determination\" in getting Juneteenth declared a national holiday.\n\n\"As a powerful voice in the Congress for our Constitution and human rights, she fought tirelessly to advance fairness, equity and justice for all,\" she said.\n\nRepublican Texas governor Greg Abbott said he and his wife Cecilia will always remember Ms Jackson Lee, calling her a \"tireless advocate for the people of Houston\".\n\nHe said: \"Her legacy of public service and dedication to Texas will live on.\"", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", She had previously had breast cancer and announced the pancreatic cancer diagnosis on June 2.\n\n\"The road ahead will not be easy, but I stand in faith that God will strengthen me,\" Jackson Lee said in a statement then.\n\nBishop James Dixon, a longtime friend in Houston who visited Jackson Lee earlier this week, said he will remember her as a fighter.\n\n\"She was just a rare, rare jewel of a person who relentlessly gave everything she had to make sure others had what they needed. That was Sheila,\" he said.\n\nJackson Lee had just been elected to the Houston district once represented by Barbara Jordan, the first Black woman elected to Congress from a Southern state since Reconstruction, when she was immediately placed on the high-profile House Judiciary Committee in 1995.\n\nIn a statement, Jackson Lee's family said she had been a beloved wife, sister, mother and grandmother known as Bebe.\n\n\"She will be dearly missed, but her legacy will continue to inspire all who believe in freedom, justice, and democracy,\" the statement said. \"God bless you Congresswoman and God bless the United States of America.\"\n\nPakistan Consulate General Houston also issued a statement on X on the demise of the Congresswoman by saying,\n\n\"It is with great sadness that we learnt of the passing of Congresswoman [Sheila Jackson Lee]. {"uri": "8234480412", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "04:38:02", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T04:38:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T04:37:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/rep-sheila-jackson-lee-dies-043234556.html", "title": "Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee Dies at 74 After Pancreatic Cancer Diagnosis", "body": "Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee (D-TX), a longtime congresswoman who served three decades in Congress, has died at the age of 74, her family announced in a statement Friday night.\n\n\"Today, with incredible grief for our loss yet deep gratitude for the life she shared with us, we announce the passing of United States Representative Sheila Jackson Lee of the 18th Congressional District of Texas,\" the statement read.\n\nHer family did not note a cause of death, however, Jackson Lee confirmed she was diagnosed with pancreatic cancer just over a month ago, in early June, and was undergoing treatment.\n\nAt the time, she wrote that she would approach her cancer battle \"with the same faith and the same courage\" as the fight for justice and equality for all. She added that \"the road ahead will not be easy\" but had \"faith that God will strengthen me.\"\n\nRep. Sheila Jackson Lee Confirms She Has Pancreatic Cancer\n\nFirst elected to the House in 1994, Jackson would go on to be a serving member of Congress for 30 years. She was also a member of the Congressional Black Caucus and served on the House Judiciary, Homeland Security and Budget Committees.\n\nIn the statement, her family described her as a \"fierce champion of the people,\" as well as a \"local, national and international humanitarian.\"\n\n\"Her legislative victories impacted millions, from establishing the Juneteenth Federal Holiday to reauthorizing the Violence Against Women Act,\" the family added.\n\nJackson Lee, who represented Texas' 18th District, defeated former Houston City Councilwoman Amanda Edwards in a March primary, one of her tightest races to date.\n\nJackson Lee's Democratic colleague, Rep. Adriano Espaillat (D-NY), was on the air with CNN as the news broke, describing her as a \"national hero\" for her work on progressive social and racial issues.\n\nRep. Jasmine Crockett (D-TX) meanwhile said she was at \"a loss for words so I'll just say rest easy,\" in a social media tribute.\n\nFormer mayor of Houston, Sylvester Turner, said he was \"deeply saddened\" at the news while Texas Gov. Greg Abbot (R) wrote, \"She was a proud Texan and a tireless advocate for the people of Houston. Her legacy of public service and dedication to Texas will live on.\"\n\nAlso among the tributes Friday night were Sen. Ted Cruz (R-TX), who said Jackson Lee was \"a tireless advocate for Houston.\" He added he \"will always cherish our friendship & the laughs we shared throughout the years.\"\n\nJackson Lee's family finished their statement by adding how \"she impacted us most as our beloved wife, sister, mother, and Bebe (grandmother).\"\n\nFuneral arrangements are pending. Jackson Lee is survived by her husband Elwyn Lee and their two children.\n\nRead more at The Daily Beast.\n\nGet the Daily Beast's biggest scoops and scandals delivered right to your inbox. Sheila Jackson Lee dies after battle with cancer", "body": "Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee dies after battle with cancerMegan LebowitzJuly 20, 2024 at 5:54 AM\n\nRep. Sheila Jackson Lee, D-Texas, has died at the age of 74 after a battle with cancer, her family announced on Friday.\n\n\"Today, with incredible grief for our loss yet deep gratitude for the life she shared with us, we announce the passing of United States Representative Sheila Jackson Lee of the 18th Congressional District of Texas,\" her family said in a statement.\n\n\"A local, national, and international humanitarian, she was acknowledged worldwide for her courageous fights for racial justice, criminal justice, and human rights, with a special emphasis on women and children,\" the statement said.\n\nJackson Lee announced in June that she had been diagnosed with pancreatic cancer and was undergoing treatment.\n\nThe longtime congresswoman served in the House since 1995 and leaves a legacy of pushing for legislation related to civil rights.\n\nJackson Lee was the lead sponsor of the Juneteenth National Independence Day Act, and she pushed for the Sentencing Reform Act of 2015, as well as the George Floyd Law Enforcement Trust and Integrity Act.\n\nThe Texas Democrat introduced legislation for the reauthorization of the Violence Against Women Act, which President Joe Biden signed in 2022.\n\nJackson Lee was born in Queens, New York. A graduate of Yale University and the University of Virginia Law School, she worked as a lawyer in private practice and as a staff counsel for the House Select Committee on Assassinations.\n\nShe went on to serve in Houston's government as a member of the City Council and municipal judge before being elected to Congress, where she sat on the Judiciary, Homeland Security and Budget committees.\n\n\"She will be dearly missed, but her legacy will continue to inspire all who believe in freedom, justice, and democracy,\" her family's statement concluded. \"God bless you Congresswoman and God bless the United States of America.\"\n\nJackson Lee's family said that funeral arrangements for the congresswoman are pending.", "source": {"uri": "aol.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8234484661", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "04:45:46", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T04:45:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T04:43:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://wtop.com/national/2024/07/longtime-us-rep-sheila-jackson-lee-of-texas-who-had-pancreatic-cancer-has-died/", "title": "Longtime US Rep Sheila Jackson Lee of Texas, who had pancreatic cancer, has died - WTOP News", "body": "Lillie Conley, her chief of staff, confirmed Friday night that Jackson Lee, who had pancreatic cancer, had died.\n\nThe Democrat had represented her Houston-based district and the nation's fourth-largest city since 1995. She had previously had breast cancer and announced the pancreatic cancer diagnosis on June 2.\n\n\"The road ahead will not be easy, but I stand in faith that God will strengthen me,\" Jackson Lee said in a statement then.\n\nJackson Lee had just been elected to the Houston district once represented by Barbara Jordan, the first Black woman elected to Congress from a Southern state since Reconstruction, when she was immediately placed on the high-profile House Judiciary Committee in 1995.\n\n\"They just saw me, I guess through my profile, through Barbara Jordan's work,\" Jackson Lee told the Houston Chronicle in 2022. \"I thought it was an honor because they assumed I was going to be the person they needed.\"\n\nJackson Lee quickly established herself as fierce advocate for women and minorities, and a leader for House Democrats on many social justice issues, from policing reform to reparations for descendants of enslaved people. She led the first rewrite of the Violence Against Women Act in nearly a decade, which included protections for Native American, transgender and immigrant women.\n\nJackson Lee was also among the lead lawmakers behind the effort in 2021 to have Juneteenth recognized as the first new federal holiday since Martin Luther King, Jr. Day was established in 1986. The holiday marks the day in 1865 that the last enslaved African Americans in Galveston, Texas, finally learned of their freedom.\n\nA native of Queens, New York, Jackson Lee graduated from Yale and earned her law degree at the University of Virginia. She was a judge in Houston before she was elected to Houston City Council in 1989, then ran for Congress in 1994. She was an advocate for gay rights and an early opponent of the Iraq War in 2003.\n\nJackson Lee routinely won reelection to Congress with ease. The few times she faced a challenger, she never carried less than two-thirds of the vote. Jackson Lee considered leaving Congress in 2023 in a bid to become Houston's first female Black mayor but was defeated in a runoff. She then easily won the Democratic nomination for the 2024 general election.\n\nDuring the mayoral campaign, Jackson Lee expressed regret and said \"everyone deserves to be treated with dignity and respect\" following the release of an unverified audio recording purported to be of the lawmaker berating staff members.\n\nIn 2019, Jackson Lee stepped down from two leadership positions on the House Judiciary Committee and Congressional Black Caucus Foundation, the fundraising of the Congressional Black Caucus, following a lawsuit from a former employee who said her sexual assault complaint was mishandled.\n\nCopyright \u00a9 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "8234960197", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "12:26:31", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T12:26:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T12:26:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.westernjournal.com/far-left-dem-congresswoman-sheila-jackson-lee-dead/", "title": "Far-Left Dem Congresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee Dead", "body": "Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee, a mainstay of the Democratic Party's far-left flank since she was first elected to Congress almost 30 years ago, died Friday at the age of 74.\n\nAccording to NBC News, Jackson Lee had been battling pancreatic cancer, but an exact cause of death was not stated. She announced her cancer diagnosis in June and was undergoing treatment.\n\n\"Today, with incredible grief for our loss yet deep gratitude for the life she shared with us, we announce the passing of United States Representative Sheila Jackson Lee of the 18th Congressional District of Texas,\" her family said in a statement.\n\nJackson Lee leaves behind a husband and two adult children, Fox News noted.\n\n\"A local, national, and international humanitarian, she was acknowledged worldwide for her courageous fights for racial justice, criminal justice, and human rights, with a special emphasis on women and children,\" the family's statement said.\n\n\"Her legislative victories impacted millions, from establishing the Juneteenth Federal holiday to reauthorizing the Violence Against Women Act,\" the statement continued.\n\n\"However, she impacted us most as our beloved wife, sister, mother, and Bebe (grandmother).\n\n\"She will be dearly missed, but her legacy will continue to inspire all who believe in freedom, justice and democracy.\"\n\nJackson Lee got her undergraduate degree from Yale and her law degree from the University of Virginia, according to her House biography. She held a position at the University of Houston before becoming an associate municipal judge in Houston.\n\nFrom there, she was elected to an at-large seat on the Houston City Council before defeating incumbent Rep. Craig Washington in a 1994 Democratic primary. Given the deep blue nature of the district, the Democratic nomination was tantamount to election and she never faced serious electoral opposition for her seat.\n\nLee was one of the furthest-left members of the House of Representatives by voting record, according to GovTrack.US.\n\nPersonal (and personnel) issues dogged her throughout her career -- ultimately leading to a surprise landslide defeat in a bid to become Houston's mayor in 2023.\n\nAs early as the late 1990s, rumors began circulating that Jackson Lee was a difficult lawmaker to deal with.\n\nOne of the first reports of Jackson Lee's problematic behavior came from the alternative weekly Houston Press, which described how Lee's former Capitol office executive assistant and events scheduler said her \"abrasive ways not only drove off staff members but irritated Continental Airlines staffers to the point where one suggested she fly on a competitor instead.\"\n\n\"You don't understand. I am a queen, and I demand to be treated like a queen,\" the former staffer alleged Lee said during one rant.\n\nTurnover in Lee's office was frequent and reports were rife that former staffers warned prospective employees not to work with the Texas congresswoman.\n\nFurthermore, in 2002, the conservative Weekly Standard alleged that Jackson Lee had broken House ethics rules regarding certain perks and offered more details of the alleged Continental Airlines confrontation:\n\n\"On a flight home to Houston, Jackson Lee became enraged when flight attendants failed to produce the seafood special she liked,\" the publication reported. \"'Don't you know who I am?' she reportedly thundered. 'I'm Congresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee. Where is my seafood meal? I know it was ordered!'\"\n\nWhile these might seem like minor incidents, they came to a head as Jackson Lee sought to become the mayor of Houston.\n\nEntering the 2023 race as a serious contender, her chances disintegrated in the final few weeks of the race as audio emerged of Jackson Lee verbally berating staffers, leaked to the Texas Tribune, a liberal online news site.\n\nIn one recording, she told a staffer he didn't have a \"f***in' brain\" and declared \"nobody knows a G****mned thing in my office - nothing!\" She referred to another staffer as a \"fat-a** stupid idiot\" and said both were \"f***-ups.\"\n\n\"It's the worst s*** that I could have ever had put together,\" Jackson Lee said. \"Two g****mned big-a** children, f***in' idiots who serve no g****mned purpose.\"\n\nWhile her staff didn't acknowledge the veracity of the recording, Jackson Lee's apology seemed to make it clear it was her on the audio.\n\n\"I want to convey to the people of Houston that I strongly believe that everyone deserves to be treated with dignity and respect, and that includes my own staff,\" Jackson Lee said in a statement, according to an October 2023 report by KTRK-TV in Houston.\n\n\"I know that I am not perfect. I recognize that in my zeal to do everything possible to deliver for my constituents I have in the past fallen short of my own standards and there is no excuse for that.\"\n\nShe would lose handily to John Whitmire in the nonpartisan runoff election, 64.4 percent to 35.6 percent, according to Ballotpedia.\n\nIn addition to the mayoral loss, Jackson Lee faced her first serious primary opposition in many years in this March's Democratic primary for her congressional district, ceding over 37 percent of the vote to challenger Amanda Edwards.\n\nWhitmire, who beat Jackson Lee in the Houston mayoral race, said in a statement that his late rival was \"a dedicated public servant and a champion for her constituents,\" according to The New York Times.\n\nFuneral arrangements are pending, the family's statement said.", "source": {"uri": "westernjournal.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Western Journal"}, "authors": [{"uri": "c_douglas_golden@westernjournal.com", "name": "C. congresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee, a strong progressive voice in the Democratic Party who was outspoken on African-American and women's rights, has died aged 74.\n\nThe Democrat had represented her Houston-based district since 1995 and last month announced she had pancreatic cancer and was undergoing treatment.\n\n\"Today, with incredible grief for our loss yet deep gratitude for the life she shared with us, we announce the passing of United States Representative Sheila Jackson Lee of the 18th Congressional District of Texas,\" her family said in a statement on Friday.\n\n\"A fierce champion of the people, she was affectionately and simply known as 'Congresswoman' by her constituents in recognition of her near-ubiquitous presence and service to their daily lives for more than 30 years.\"\n\nA native of Queens, New York, Ms Jackson Lee graduated from Yale and earned her law degree at the University of Virginia.\n\nShe was a judge in Houston before she was elected to Houston City Council in 1989, then ran for Congress in 1994.\n\nShe was active throughout her career in promoting legislation aimed at addressing social justice, economic inequality and public health concerns.\n\nMs Jackson Lee was also among the lead lawmakers behind the effort in 2021 to make \"Juneteenth\" a federal holiday, commemorating the end of the legal enslavement of Black Americans.\n\nThe holiday marks the day in 1865 when a Union general informed a group of enslaved people in Texas that they had been made free two years earlier by President Abraham Lincoln's Emancipation Proclamation during the Civil War.\n\nMs Jackson Lee routinely won re-election to Congress with ease. The few times she faced a challenger, she never carried less than two-thirds of the vote.\n\nShe considered leaving Congress in 2023 in a bid to become Houston's first female Black mayor, but was defeated in a run-off. She then easily won the Democratic nomination for the 2024 general election.\n\nMs Jackson Lee served on several House committees, including judiciary, homeland security and budget.", "source": {"uri": "8234483086", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "04:41:30", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T04:41:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T04:40:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.dallasnews.com/news/obituaries/2024/07/19/texas-congresswoman-sheila-jackson-lee-dies/", "title": "Texas congresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee dies", "body": "Houston Democrat said in June she had been diagnosed with pancreatic cancer\n\nLongtime U.S. Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee of Texas, who helped lead federal efforts to protect women from domestic violence and recognize Juneteenth as a national holiday, has died. She was 74.\n\nLillie Conley, her chief of staff, confirmed Friday night that Jackson Lee, who had pancreatic cancer, had died.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe Democrat had represented her Houston-based district and the nation's fourth-largest city since 1995. She had previously had breast cancer and announced the pancreatic cancer diagnosis on June 2.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"The road ahead will not be easy, but I stand in faith that God will strengthen me,\" Jackson Lee said in a statement then.\n\nBreaking News\n\nGet the latest breaking news from North Texas and beyond.\n\nSIGN UP\n\nOr with:\n\nGoogleFacebook\n\nBy signing up you agree to our Terms of Service and Privacy Policy\n\nJackson Lee had just been elected to the Houston district once represented by Barbara Jordan, the first Black woman elected to Congress from a Southern state since Reconstruction, when she was immediately placed on the high-profile House Judiciary Committee in 1995.\n\n\"They just saw me, I guess through my profile, through Barbara Jordan's work,\" Jackson Lee told the Houston Chronicle in 2022. \"I thought it was an honor because they assumed I was going to be the person they needed.\"\n\nAdvertisement\n\nJackson Lee quickly established herself as fierce advocate for women and minorities, and a leader for House Democrats on many social justice issues, from policing reform to reparations for descendants of enslaved people. She led the first rewrite of the Violence Against Women Act in nearly a decade, which included protections for Native American, transgender and immigrant women.\n\nJackson Lee was also among the lead lawmakers behind the effort in 2021 to have Juneteenth recognized as the first new federal holiday since Martin Luther King, Jr. Day was established in 1986. The holiday marks the day in 1865 that the last enslaved African Americans in Galveston, Texas, finally learned of their freedom.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nA native of Queens, New York, Jackson Lee graduated from Yale and earned her law degree at the University of Virginia. She was a judge in Houston before she was elected to Houston City Council in 1989, then ran for Congress in 1994. She was an advocate for gay rights and an early opponent of the Iraq War in 2003.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nJackson Lee routinely won reelection to Congress with ease. The few times she faced a challenger, she never carried less than two-thirds of the vote. Jackson Lee considered leaving Congress in 2023 in a bid to become Houston's first female Black mayor but was defeated in a runoff. She then easily won the Democratic nomination for the 2024 general election.\n\nDuring the mayoral campaign, Jackson Lee expressed regret and said \"everyone deserves to be treated with dignity and respect\" following the release of an unverified audio recording purported to be of the lawmaker berating staff members.\n\nIn 2019, Jackson Lee stepped down from two leadership positions on the House Judiciary Committee and Congressional Black Caucus Foundation, the fundraising of the Congressional Black Caucus, following a lawsuit from a former employee who said her sexual assault complaint was mishandled.\n\nAdvertisementRelated StoriesView MoreRepublicans criticize Jasmine Crockett for bill that could nix Trump Secret Service detailRussia convicts U.S. journalist Evan Gershkovich of spying with 16-year prison sentenceFort Worth Democrat Marc Veasey joins calls for Biden to quit raceTakeaways from the GOP convention: Trump tees off, Republicans unite, Democrats searching", "source": {"uri": "2024-07-427778332", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "05:15:13", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T05:15:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T03:47:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://theurbandaily.com/3676772/rep-sheila-jackson-lee-dies-at-74/", "title": "Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee Dies At 74", "body": "CLOSE\n\nSource: Earl Gibson III / Getty\n\nRep. Sheila Jackson Lee (D-TX), the beloved Texas congresswoman who has been at the center of U.S.politics for 30 years, died Friday night, KHOU11 reports. She was 74 years old.\n\nJackson Lee's family issued the following statement:\n\n\"With incredible grief for our loss yet deep gratitude for the life she shared with us, we announce the passing of United States Representative Sheila Jackson Lee of the 18th Congressional District of Texas.\n\n\"A local, national, and international humanitarian, she was acknowledged worldwide for her courageous fights for racial justice, criminal justice, and human rights, with a special emphasis on women and children.\n\n\"She will be dearly missed, but her legacy will continue to inspire all who believe in freedom, justice, and democracy. God bless you Congresswoman and God bless the United States of America.\n\nAs NewsOne previously reported, Jackson Lee confirmed her pancreatic cancer diagnosis in June, stating, in part, that she was \"confident\" in her doctors' treatment plan.\n\n\"My adult life has been defined by my faith in God, my love for humanity and my commitment to public service. As a member of Congress, I've been honored to be one of the leaders in the fight for justice and equality for all; especially the disadvantaged and the dispossessed. Today, my fight is more personal, but I will approach it with the same faith and the same courage.\"\n\nJackson Lee served the 18th Congressional District for 30 years, calling it \"one of [her] greatest honors.\"\n\nFormer Houston Mayor Sylvester Turner issued this statement:\n\n\"I am deeply saddened by the death of my dear friend and colleague, Congresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee. From City Hall to the Halls of Congress, Sheila Jackson Lee has served her constituents well. She has written and passed key legislation and has stood on the floor of the United States House of Representatives speaking passionately for the interests of her district and the country she loved. She has worked with and advised Presidents of our great country, met with global leaders, and has been embraced by world renowned artists. But her work on the ground, in some of the poorest and under-resourced communities; the channeling of billions of federal dollars back to her district; her presence at someone's bedside, giving words of comfort to families who lost loved ones; her appearances at places of worship and events showcasing the global diversity of our City; and her uncanny ability to be everywhere, working every day for those who needed a champion, made her truly exceptional.\"\n\nTurner continued:\n\n\"When she was elected to the United States House of Representatives she stood in the shadow of Barbara Jordan, Mickey Leland and Craig Washington. Without question, she rose to the occasion and served with great distinction. Even if you disagreed with her politics, you had to respect her work ethic. We can honestly say Sheila Jackson Lee left it all on the field. Rest in peace my sister. Thank you for all you gave us. And, thank you to her family for sharing her with us. We will not forget her sacrifice or yours. Sheila - to God be the glory for the good you have done. It was truly a job well done!\"\n\nhttps://x.com/sylvesterturner/status/1814499497361224115?s=46&t=kSXIjsOCglfUL0Vib5Dicg\n\nJackson Lee recently reintroduced a sweeping criminal justice reform bill named for George Floyd ahead of the fourth anniversary of his police murder in Minneapolis.\n\n\"Far too many lives have been lost or forever changed due to unacceptable incidents of police brutality throughout our nation,\" Jackson Lee told reporters on May 24 during a press conference announcing the reintroduction of the George Floyd Justice In Policing Act, which has languished in legislative limbo for years because of Senate Republicans' filibustering. \"We cannot allow another American to be deprived of his or her humanity, dignity and constitutional right without taking action.\"\n\n*\n\nThis is a developing story. Please continue to check NewsOne for updates as we honor the life a political titan Congresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee.\n\nSEE ALSO:\n\nRep. {"uri": "8234476709", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "04:34:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T04:34:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T04:33:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.thedailybeast.com/rep-sheila-jackson-lee-dies-at-74-after-pancreatic-cancer-diagnosis", "title": "Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee Dies at 74 After Cancer Diagnosis", "body": "The long-serving Democratic congresswoman went public with her health battle in June.\n\nRep. Sheila Jackson Lee (D-TX), a longtime congresswoman who served three decades in Congress, has died at the age of 74, her family announced in a statement Friday night.\n\n\"Today, with incredible grief for our loss yet deep gratitude for the life she shared with us, we announce the passing of United States Representative Sheila Jackson Lee of the 18th Congressional District of Texas,\" the statement read.\n\nHer family did not note a cause of death, however, Jackson Lee confirmed she was diagnosed with pancreatic cancer just over a month ago, in early June, and was undergoing treatment.\n\nAt the time, she wrote that she would approach her cancer battle \"with the same faith and the same courage\" as the fight for justice and equality for all. She added that \"the road ahead will not be easy\" but had \"faith that God will strengthen me.\"\n\nFirst elected to the House in 1994, Jackson would go on to be a serving member of Congress for 30 years. She was also a member of the Congressional Black Caucus and served on the House Judiciary, Homeland Security and Budget Committees.\n\nIn the statement, her family described her as a \"fierce champion of the people,\" as well as a \"local, national and international humanitarian.\"\n\n\"Her legislative victories impacted millions, from establishing the Juneteenth Federal Holiday to reauthorizing the Violence Against Women Act,\" the family added.\n\nJackson Lee, who represented Texas' 18th District, defeated former Houston City Councilwoman Amanda Edwards in a March primary, one of her tightest races to date.\n\nJackson Lee's Democratic colleague, Rep. Adriano Espaillat (D-NY), was on the air with CNN as the news broke, describing her as a \"national hero\" for her work on progressive social and racial issues.\n\nRep. Jasmine Crockett (D-TX) meanwhile said she was at \"a loss for words so I'll just say rest easy,\" in a social media tribute.\n\nFormer mayor of Houston, Sylvester Turner, said he was \"deeply saddened\" at the news while Texas Gov. Greg Abbot (R) wrote, \"She was a proud Texan and a tireless advocate for the people of Houston. Her legacy of public service and dedication to Texas will live on.\"\n\nAlso among the tributes Friday night were Sen. Ted Cruz (R-TX), who said Jackson Lee was \"a tireless advocate for Houston.\" He added he \"will always cherish our friendship & the laughs we shared throughout the years.\"\n\nJackson Lee's family finished their statement by adding how \"she impacted us most as our beloved wife, sister, mother, and Bebe (grandmother).\"\n\nFuneral arrangements are pending. Jackson Lee is survived by her husband Elwyn Lee and their two children.", "source": {"uri": "thedailybeast.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Daily Beast"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8234767425", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "09:32:31", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T09:32:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T09:27:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-13654055/UPDATE-4-Sheila-Jackson-Lee-strong-Democratic-voice-US-Congress-died-family-says.html", "title": "UPDATE 4-Sheila Jackson Lee, strong Democratic voice in US...", "body": "By Surbhi Misra\n\nJuly 19 (Reuters) - U.S. Representative Sheila Jackson Lee, a prominent progressive voice in the Democratic Party who was outspoken on African American and women's rights, has died, her family posted on X late on Friday.\n\nJackson Lee of Texas announced last month she had pancreatic cancer and was undergoing treatment. She was 74, according to U.S. media.\n\n\"The road ahead will not be easy, but I stand in faith that God will strengthen me,\" Jackson Lee, the chief deputy whip in the House of Representatives, said in announcing the diagnosis.\n\n\"A fierce champion of the people, she was affectionately and simply known as 'Congresswoman' by her constituents in recognition of her near-ubiquitous presence and service to their daily lives for more than 30 years,\" her family said in the statement.\n\nThe 15-term representative, a graduate of Yale College and the University of Virginia Law School, was active throughout her career in promoting legislation aimed at addressing social justice, economic inequality and public health concerns.\n\nJackson Lee, who represented parts of Houston, introduced legislation in the House to make \"Juneteenth\" a federal holiday commemorating the end of the legal enslavement of Black Americans.\n\nThe holiday marks the day in 1865 when a Union general informed a group of enslaved people in Texas that they had been made free two years earlier by President Abraham Lincoln's Emancipation Proclamation during the Civil War.\n\nJackson Lee was a vocal proponent of police reform in the face of Congressional roadblocks after the 2020 police killing of George Floyd, a Black man whose death sparked nationwide protests.\n\nFellow Democrat Brendan Boyle, ranking member of the House Budget Committee on which she served, called her \"a fierce advocate for the people of Houston and for racial and economic justice everywhere.\" He said in a statement, \"The Congresswoman will be truly missed by all of us who served alongside her.\"\n\nJackson Lee also served on the judiciary and homeland security committees.\n\nShe received tribute from some Texans at the other end of the political spectrum.\n\nGovernor Greg Abbott, a conservative Republican, posted on X that his wife \"Cecilia and I will forever remember Congresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee adding that her legacy of public service and dedication to Texas will live on.\"\n\nU.S. Senator Ted Cruz posted: \"I'm deeply saddened by the passing of my friend &amp; colleague Sheila Jackson Lee. She was a tireless advocate for Houston.\"\n\nShe considered leaving Congress in 2023 in a bid to become Houston's first female Black mayor but was defeated in a runoff.\n\nA false claim was used to ridicule her in a widely shared Facebook post in March 2020 that asserted she had said \"homicide is the leading cause of murder\". Reuters found no evidence she ever made such a statement. Sheila Jackson Lee passes away following a fight with cancer - Internewscast Journal", "body": "Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee, D-Texas, has died at the age of 74 after a battle with cancer, her family announced on Friday.\n\n\"Today, with incredible grief for our loss yet deep gratitude for the life she shared with us, we announce the passing of United States Representative Sheila Jackson Lee of the 18th Congressional District of Texas,\" her family said in a statement.\n\n\"A local, national, and international humanitarian, she was acknowledged worldwide for her courageous fights for racial justice, criminal justice, and human rights, with a special emphasis on women and children,\" the statement said.\n\nJackson Lee announced in June that she had been diagnosed with pancreatic cancer and was undergoing treatment.\n\nThe longtime congresswoman served in the House since 1995 and leaves a legacy of pushing for legislation related to civil rights.\n\nJackson Lee was the lead sponsor of the Juneteenth National Independence Day Act, and she pushed for the Sentencing Reform Act of 2015, as well as the George Floyd Law Enforcement Trust and Integrity Act.\n\n\"This is America's holiday. And America's holiday is not just for Black people,\" Jackson Lee said of Juneteenth in a 2023 MSNBC interview. \"It is about freedom, and it is about democracy.\"\n\nThe Texas Democrat introduced legislation for the reauthorization of the Violence Against Women Act, which President Joe Biden signed in 2022.\n\nJackson Lee was born in Queens, New York. A graduate of Yale University and the University of Virginia Law School, she worked as a lawyer in private practice and as a staff counsel for the House Select Committee on Assassinations.\n\nShe went on to serve in Houston's government as a member of the City Council and municipal judge before being elected to Congress, where she sat on the Judiciary, Homeland Security and Budget committees.\n\n\"She will be dearly missed, but her legacy will continue to inspire all who believe in freedom, justice, and democracy,\" her family's statement concluded. \"God bless you Congresswoman and God bless the United States of America.\"\n\nJackson Lee's family said that funeral arrangements for the congresswoman are pending.\n\nShe is survived by her husband, two children {"uri": "8234629148", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "07:17:38", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T07:17:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T07:17:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.breakingnews.ie/world/us-representative-sheila-jackson-lee-dies-aged-74-1652106.html", "title": "US representative Sheila Jackson Lee dies aged 74 | BreakingNews.ie", "body": "Long-standing US representative Sheila Jackson Lee of Texas, who helped lead federal efforts to protect women from domestic violence and recognise Juneteenth as a national holiday, has died aged 74.\n\nMs Jackson Lee, who had pancreatic cancer, died in Houston on Friday night with her family around her, her chief of staff confirmed.\n\nThe Democrat had represented her Houston-based district and America's fourth-largest city since 1995. She had previously had breast cancer and announced the pancreatic cancer diagnosis on June 2.\n\nAt the time, Ms Jackson Lee said: \"The road ahead will not be easy, but I stand in faith that God will strengthen me.\"\n\nBishop James Dixon, a friend in Houston who visited Jackson Lee earlier this week, said he will remember her as a fighter.\n\n\"She was just a rare, rare jewel of a person who relentlessly gave everything she had to make sure others had what they needed. That was Sheila,\" he said.\n\nMs Jackson Lee had just been elected to the Houston district once represented by Barbara Jordan, the first black woman elected to congress from a Southern state since Reconstruction, when she was immediately placed on the high-profile house judiciary committee in 1995.\n\n\"They just saw me, I guess through my profile, through Barbara Jordan's work,\" Ms Jackson Lee told the Houston Chronicle in 2022. \"I thought it was an honour because they assumed I was going to be the person they needed.\"\n\nMs Jackson Lee quickly established herself as fierce advocate for women and minorities, and a leader for House Democrats on many social justice issues, from policing reform to reparations for descendants of enslaved people.\n\nShe led the first rewrite of the Violence Against Women Act in nearly a decade, which included protections for Native American, transgender and immigrant women.\n\nMs Jackson Lee was also among the lead legislators behind the effort in 2021 to have Juneteenth recognised as the first new federal holiday since Martin Luther King, Jr Day was established in 1986.\n\nThe holiday marks the day in 1865 (June 19) that the last enslaved African Americans in Galveston, Texas, finally learned of their freedom.\n\nA native of Queens, New York, Jackson Lee graduated from Yale and earned her law degree at the University of Virginia. She was a judge in Houston before she was elected to Houston City Council in 1989, then ran for Congress in 1994. She was an advocate for gay rights and an early opponent of the Iraq War in 2003.\n\nTop congressional Democrats reacted quickly to the news, praising her commitment and work ethic.\n\nJames Clyburn of South Carolina called her \"a tenacious advocate for civil rights and a tireless fighter, improving the lives of her constituents\".\n\nJamie Raskin of Maryland said he had never known a harder-working legislators than Ms Jackson Lee, saying she \"studied every bill and every amendment with exactitude and then told Texas and America exactly where she stood\".\n\nFormer House Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California cited Ms Jackson Lee's \"relentless determination\" in getting Juneteenth declared a national holiday.\n\n\"As a powerful voice in the Congress for our Constitution and human rights, she fought tirelessly to advance fairness, equity and justice for all,\" she said.\n\nRepublican Texas governor Greg Abbott said he and his wife Cecilia will always remember Ms Jackson Lee, calling her a \"tireless advocate for the people of Houston\".\n\nHe said: \"Her legacy of public service and dedication to Texas will live on.\"", "source": {"uri": "breakingnews.ie", {"uri": "8234973321", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "12:39:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T12:39:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T12:39:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.wfaa.com/article/news/local/sheila-jackson-lee-death-reaction/285-ea90e62c-6299-4dad-9b55-49cb35f951f3", "title": "Politicians from both sides of the aisle react to death of longtime Congresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee", "body": "HOUSTON -- On Friday night, Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee's family issued a statement announcing the death of the longtime lawmaker.\n\nKnown by her constituents as simply, \"Congresswoman,\" Jackson Lee served the public for more than 30 years.\n\nLast month, Jackson Lee announced she was fighting pancreatic cancer. In a statement at the time of the announcement, Jackson Lee said she was undergoing treatment to battle the disease \"that impacts tens of thousands of Americans every year.\"\n\nRELATED: 'I stand in faith that God will strengthen me' | US Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee announces pancreatic cancer diagnosis\n\nJackson Lee was born on Jan. 12, 1950, in Queens, New York. She served on the Houston City Council from 1989 to 1994 and was elected to the United States House of Representatives in 1995.\n\nFuneral arrangements are pending.\n\nAfter the announcement of her death, condolences poured in from both sides of the political aisle.\n\nGreen spoke to KHOU 11 anchors Len Cannon and Mia Gradney after learning of Jackson Lee's passing:\n\n\"Words cannot fully express the impact of Congresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee. The word 'tireless' gets thrown around in politics, but there's no one I've ever met with that kind of work ethic who could compare Congresswoman Jackson Lee. Her work didn't only benefit the Houstonians she represented for decades; it helped make our nation better for all Americans. Saying she will be missed is an understatement. My condolences to her family and to all who loved her. Thank you, Congresswoman, for your dedication to our city, county, state and country.\"\n\n\"A leader in our community and nation's Capital for over 30 years, Congresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee was well known for being a fierce champion for the voiceless in our community.\n\n\"Congresswoman Jackson Lee was our fighter for our community, following in the footsteps of Houston political giants, the late Congressman Mickey Leland, Congresswoman Barbara Jordan, and former Congressman Craig Washington. As the people's champion, she used her commanding voice to fight for civil rights, women's rights, affordable and accessible healthcare, immigration reform, racial justice, human rights and equality.\n\n\"Congresswoman Jackson Lee never hesitated to lead the charge on issues important to working-class families, the poor and communities that felt forgotten or overlooked. She was the epitome of what it meant to be a servant leader.\n\n\"Congresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee was my friend, mentor and someone I could always call for guidance. Rest in power, congresswoman.\"\n\n\"My friend, ally, and long-time political partner, Congresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee, passed from this world and into the pantheon of legendary Texas leaders. For nearly 30 years, she tirelessly represented the people of her congressional district.\n\n\"Through crises and disasters - as well as triumphs - Sheila's ceaseless and unwavering dedication to those she represented served as an inspiration and source of strength to me in my career. She exhibited this dedication every day through her deeds, actions and accomplishments. She was a beloved mother, grandmother, and confidante who leaves behind a legacy of single-minded commitment to our community.\n\n\"Holding dear the memory of those who pass before us is the greatest homage we can pay to those we love. And I know Sheila Jackson Lee will dwell fondly in our memories for years to come.\"\n\n\"I am deeply saddened by the death of my dear friend and colleague, Congresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee. From City Hall to the Halls of Congress, Sheila Jackson Lee has served her constituents well. She has written and passed key legislation and has stood on the floor of the United States House of Representatives speaking passionately for the interests of her district and the country she loved. She has worked with and advised Presidents of our great country, met with global leaders, and has been embraced by world renowned artists. But her work on the ground, in some of the poorest and under-resourced communities; the channeling of billions of federal dollars back to her district; her presence at someone's bedside, giving words of comfort to families who lost loved ones; her appearances at places of worship and events showcasing the global diversity of our City; and her uncanny ability to be everywhere, working every day for those who needed a champion, made her truly exceptional.\n\n\"When she was elected to the United States House of Representatives she stood in the shadow of Barbara Jordan, Mickey Leland and Craig Washington. Without question, she rose to the occasion and served with great distinction. Even if you disagreed with her politics, you had to respect her work ethic. We can honestly say Sheila Jackson Lee left it all on the field. Rest in peace my sister. Thank you for all you gave us. And, thank you to her family for sharing her with us. We will not forget her sacrifice or yours. Sheila - to God be the glory for the good you have done. It was truly a job well done!\"\n\n\"It is with profound sadness that I acknowledge the passing of Congresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee, a devoted leader, a proud-fellow Houstonian, and someone who I was proud to call a friend.\n\n\"Although we had our political disagreements, there were many moments with her, both public and private, that showed me that bipartisanship and service to country first can still bring members of Congress together.\n\n\"In these divided times, Congresswoman Lee and I were able to partner on several legislative initiatives for the city of the Houston. Her steadfast commitment to serving the people of Houston and her tireless work have left an indelible mark on our community and our nation.", "source": {"uri": "wfaa.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8234625460", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "07:14:13", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T07:14:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T07:13:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.expressandstar.com/news/world-news/2024/07/20/us-representative-sheila-jackson-lee-dies-aged-74/", "title": "US representative Sheila Jackson Lee dies aged 74", "body": "The Texas representative helped lead efforts to protect women from domestic violence.\n\nLong-standing US representative Sheila Jackson Lee of Texas, who helped lead federal efforts to protect women from domestic violence and recognise Juneteenth as a national holiday, has died aged 74.\n\nMs Jackson Lee, who had pancreatic cancer, died in Houston on Friday night with her family around her, her chief of staff confirmed.\n\nThe Democrat had represented her Houston-based district and America's fourth-largest city since 1995. She had previously had breast cancer and announced the pancreatic cancer diagnosis on June 2.\n\nAt the time, Ms Jackson Lee said: \"The road ahead will not be easy, but I stand in faith that God will strengthen me.\"\n\nBishop James Dixon, a friend in Houston who visited Jackson Lee earlier this week, said he will remember her as a fighter.\n\n\"She was just a rare, rare jewel of a person who relentlessly gave everything she had to make sure others had what they needed. That was Sheila,\" he said.\n\nMs Jackson Lee had just been elected to the Houston district once represented by Barbara Jordan, the first black woman elected to congress from a Southern state since Reconstruction, when she was immediately placed on the high-profile house judiciary committee in 1995.\n\n\"They just saw me, I guess through my profile, through Barbara Jordan's work,\" Ms Jackson Lee told the Houston Chronicle in 2022. \"I thought it was an honour because they assumed I was going to be the person they needed.\"\n\nMs Jackson Lee quickly established herself as fierce advocate for women and minorities, and a leader for House Democrats on many social justice issues, from policing reform to reparations for descendants of enslaved people.\n\nShe led the first rewrite of the Violence Against Women Act in nearly a decade, which included protections for Native American, transgender and immigrant women.\n\nMs Jackson Lee was also among the lead legislators behind the effort in 2021 to have Juneteenth recognised as the first new federal holiday since Martin Luther King, Jr Day was established in 1986.\n\nThe holiday marks the day in 1865 (June 19) that the last enslaved African Americans in Galveston, Texas, finally learned of their freedom.\n\nA native of Queens, New York, Jackson Lee graduated from Yale and earned her law degree at the University of Virginia. She was a judge in Houston before she was elected to Houston City Council in 1989, then ran for Congress in 1994. She was an advocate for gay rights and an early opponent of the Iraq War in 2003.\n\nTop congressional Democrats reacted quickly to the news, praising her commitment and work ethic.\n\nJames Clyburn of South Carolina called her \"a tenacious advocate for civil rights and a tireless fighter, improving the lives of her constituents\".\n\nJamie Raskin of Maryland said he had never known a harder-working legislators than Ms Jackson Lee, saying she \"studied every bill and every amendment with exactitude and then told Texas and America exactly where she stood\".\n\nFormer House Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California cited Ms Jackson Lee's \"relentless determination\" in getting Juneteenth declared a national holiday.\n\n\"As a powerful voice in the Congress for our Constitution and human rights, she fought tirelessly to advance fairness, equity and justice for all,\" she said.\n\nRepublican Texas governor Greg Abbott said he and his wife Cecilia will always remember Ms Jackson Lee, calling her a \"tireless advocate for the people of Houston\".\n\nHe said: \"Her legacy of public service and dedication to Texas will live on.\"", "source": {"uri": "expressandstar.com", {"uri": "8234510393", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "05:13:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T05:13:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T05:12:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/world-news-longtime-us-rep-sheila-jackson-lee-of-texas-who-had-pancreatic-cancer-has-died-6123829.html", "title": "World News | Longtime US Rep Sheila Jackson Lee of Texas, Who Had Pancreatic Cancer, Has Died | LatestLY", "body": "Washington, Jul 20 (AP) Longtime US Rep Sheila Jackson Lee of Texas, who helped lead federal efforts to protect women from domestic violence and recognise Juneteenth as a national holiday, has died. She was 74.\n\nLillie Conley, her chief of staff, confirmed Friday night that Jackson Lee, who had pancreatic cancer, had died.\n\nAlso Read | Bangladesh Unrest: Curfew Imposed, Internet Disabled Amid Student-Led Anti-Government Protests, BSF Steps Up Security Checks at Indian Immigration Check Post (Watch Videos).\n\nThe Democrat had represented her Houston-based district and the nation's fourth-largest city since 1995. She had previously had breast cancer and announced the pancreatic cancer diagnosis on June 2.\n\n\"The road ahead will not be easy, but I stand in faith that God will strengthen me,\" Jackson Lee said in a statement then.\n\nAlso Read | China: Woman Finds Video of Her Breast Implant Surgery on Popular Social Media Platform, Sues Hospital for Secretly Filming Her.\n\nJackson Lee had just been elected to the Houston district once represented by Barbara Jordan, the first Black woman elected to Congress from a Southern state since Reconstruction, when she was immediately placed on the high-profile House Judiciary Committee in 1995.\n\n\"They just saw me, I guess through my profile, through Barbara Jordan's work,\" Jackson Lee told the Houston Chronicle in 2022. \"I thought it was an honor because they assumed I was going to be the person they needed.\"\n\nJackson Lee quickly established herself as fierce advocate for women and minorities, and a leader for House Democrats on many social justice issues, from policing reform to reparations for descendants of enslaved people. She led the first rewrite of the Violence Against Women Act in nearly a decade, which included protections for Native American, transgender and immigrant women.\n\nJackson Lee was also among the lead lawmakers behind the effort in 2021 to have Juneteenth recognized as the first new federal holiday since Martin Luther King, Jr. Day was established in 1986. The holiday marks the day in 1865 that the last enslaved African Americans in Galveston, Texas, finally learned of their freedom.\n\nA native of Queens, New York, Jackson Lee graduated from Yale and earned her law degree at the University of Virginia. She was a judge in Houston before she was elected to Houston City Council in 1989, then ran for Congress in 1994. She was an advocate for gay rights and an early opponent of the Iraq War in 2003.\n\nJackson Lee routinely won reelection to Congress with ease. The few times she faced a challenger, she never carried less than two-thirds of the vote. Jackson Lee considered leaving Congress in 2023 in a bid to become Houston's first female Black mayor but was defeated in a runoff. She then easily won the Democratic nomination for the 2024 general election.\n\nDuring the mayoral campaign, Jackson Lee expressed regret and said \"everyone deserves to be treated with dignity and respect\" following the release of an unverified audio recording purported to be of the lawmaker berating staff members.\n\nIn 2019, Jackson Lee stepped down from two leadership positions on the House Judiciary Committee and Congressional Black Caucus Foundation, the fundraising of the Congressional Black Caucus, following a lawsuit from a former employee who said her sexual assault complaint was mishandled. {"uri": "8234447421", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "03:59:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T03:59:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T03:59:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.houstonpublicmedia.org/articles/obituary/2024/07/19/494185/congresswoman-sheila-jackson-lee-dies-at-74/", "title": "Houston Congresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee dies at 74 | Houston Public Media", "body": "Congresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee, a Democrat who represented much of Houston in Congress for nearly 30 years, has died, according to a statement released by her family Friday night. She was 74.\n\n\"Today, with incredible grief for our loss yet deep gratitude for the life she shared with us, we announce the passing of United States Representative Sheila Jackson Lee of the 18th Congressional District of Texas,\" the statement read.\n\nJackson Lee had announced in early June that she had been diagnosed with pancreatic cancer but was continuing to campaign for what would have been her 16 term in office. At the time of her death, she was one of the two longest-serving members of the Texas congressional delegation, along with Austin Congressman Lloyd Doggett.\n\n\"Known for her relentless advocacy, the congresswoman dedicated her life to public service, advancing civil rights, healthcare reform, and disaster recovery,\" said Texas Democratic Party chairman Gilberto Hinojosa in a statement. \"And in the spirit of Sheila Jackson Lee's legacy, we will march forward in our fierce commitment to fighting for justice, equality and opportunity for all.\"\n\nJackson Lee's legislative accomplishments included establishing the Juneteenth federal holiday and reauthorizing the Violence Against Women Act.\n\nFormer Houston Mayor Sylvester Turner also paid tribute to Jackson Lee in a statement, saying, \"her work on the ground, in some of the poorest and under-resourced communities; the channeling of billions of federal dollars back to her district; her presence at someone's bedside, giving words of comfort to families who lost loved ones; her appearances at places of worship and events showcasing the global diversity of our City; and her uncanny ability to be everywhere, working every day for those who needed a champion, made her truly exceptional.\"\n\nJackson Lee, born in Queens, New York, represented Texas' 18 Congressional District longer than anyone since the district was established more than a century ago. She was only the fourth member to hold the seat since the district was redrawn to represent Downtown Houston in 1972 - preceded by Barbara Jordan, Mickey Leland, and Craig Washington.\n\nJackson Lee served Houston in elective office for close to 35 years, first as a Houston City Council member before winning election to the U.S. House in 1994. For much of her tenure in Congress, she faced minimal opposition for reelection. Last year, she made an unsuccessful bid to succeed Turner as Houston's mayor, ultimately losing to John Whitmire in a runoff. She then pivoted to reclaim the Democratic nomination for her congressional seat, beating back a fierce challenge by former Houston City Council Member Amanda Edwards.\n\nJackson Lee is the third member of the Congressional Black Caucus to die of pancreatic cancer in just over four years, following Congressmen John Lewis and Alcee Hastings.", "source": {"uri": "houstonpublicmedia.org", "https://cdn.houstonpublicmedia.org/wp-content/uploads/2024/03/05223820/Image-3-1500x1125.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9748703", "eventUri": "eng-9748703", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.1137254901960785, "wgt": 189, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8234598815", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "06:49:26", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T06:49:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T06:48:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://247ureports.com/?p=236210", "title": "Sheila Jackson Lee, long-serving Democratic congresswoman and advocate for Black Americans, dies at 74", "body": "Sheila Jackson Lee, a longtime Democratic congresswoman from Texas who was an outspoken advocate for Black Americans for decades, has died. She was 74.\n\n\"Today, with incredible grief for our loss yet deep gratitude for the life she shared with us, we announce the passing of United States Representative Sheila Jackson Lee of the 18th Congressional District of Texas,\" her family said in a statement Friday.\n\nJackson Lee announced in June that she had been diagnosed with pancreatic cancer. At the time, she acknowledged that \"the road ahead will not be easy\" and said she had \"faith that God will strengthen me.\"\n\nHer family remembered her as \"a fierce champion of the people,\" saying that \"she was affectionately and simply known as 'Congresswoman' by her constituents in recognition of her near-ubiquitous presence and service to their daily lives for more than 30 years.\"\n\nBorn on January 12, 1950, in Queens, New York, Jackson Lee was among the first women to graduate from Yale University and served as a Houston municipal judge and a city councilwoman before she was first elected to represent Texas' 18th Congressional District in 1994, unseating a Democratic incumbent in the primary for the Houston-area seat.\n\nDuring her congressional tenure, Jackson Lee was an outspoken advocate for progressive interests and Black Americans. She was one of the sponsors of legislation to establish Juneteenth as a national holiday, frequently spoke out against police brutality and advocated federal legislation to prosecute police misconduct.\n\nAlthough she was unsuccessful in some of her most ambitious aims, Jackson Lee remained an advocate for racial justice, particularly in the wake of George Floyd's killing at the hands of police in 2020.\n\n\"We will not stop until the nation knows Black lives matter, and reparations are passed as the most significant civil rights legislation of the 21st century,\" Jackson Lee said at a march in Washington in 2020.\n\nAt the time of her death, she was a chief deputy whip for House Democrats and a vice chair of the Congressional Progressive Caucus. She formerly served as whip of the Congressional Black Caucus.\n\n\"Congresswoman Jackson Lee was a patriot and a fighter to the very end. Words cannot express the sense of loss our Caucus feels for our beloved friend. She will be deeply missed by all who knew her,\" Congressional Black Caucus Chairman Steven Horsford and members of the Congressional Black Caucus said in a statement following her death.\n\nJackson Lee's tenure in Congress was not without controversy. Her ties to Enron - her district included the corporation's headquarters and it was a major contributor to her early congressional campaigns, The New York Times reported - were scrutinized in the aftermath of the company's failure in the early 2000s, though she denied taking it easy on the company.\n\nAnd in 2019, she resigned as chairwoman of the nonprofit Congressional Black Caucus Foundation and stepped down from a House Judiciary subcommittee chairmanship after a lawsuit that alleged she fired a staffer who reported sexual assault by a supervisor at the foundation. At the time, Jackson Lee declined to \"discuss specific details about internal personnel matters\" but otherwise denied the allegations, and the lawsuit was ultimately dismissed by a federal judge in February 2020.\n\nLast year, Lee sought the Houston mayorship, earning endorsements from former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, former President Bill Clinton, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton and Harris County Judge Lina Hidalgo. She lost in a runoff to Texas state Sen. John Whitmire, a fellow Democrat.\n\nFollowing that loss, Jackson Lee filed to seek a 16th term in Congress, and in March, she won a competitive Democratic primary over former Houston City Council Member Amanda Edwards, a former intern.\n\nHouse Democratic Leader Hakeem Jeffries said in a statement that House Democrats and the city of Houston \"mourn a giant,\" remembering the congresswoman as \"an accomplished legislator, passionate public servant, loving mentor and wonderful friend to so many of us in the Congressional Black Caucus and House Democratic Caucus family.\"\n\n\"I am grateful for her fearless advocacy, fierce determination, formidable service and legacy of leadership,\" Jeffries said.\n\nCalling her death a \"tremendous loss,\" Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer wrote on X that the congresswoman \"fought so hard throughout her life to make our country a better place for all.\"\n\n\"I have never known a harder-working political leader than Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee, who studied every bill and every amendment with exactitude and then told Texas and America exactly where she stood,\" Maryland Rep. Jamie Raskin said on X.\n\nOn CNN's \"Laura Coates Live,\" fellow Texas Rep. Al Green remembered Jackson Lee as \"someone in Congress that was always, always working to bring about a just resolution to any problem,\" adding that she helped him become a better congressman.\n\nIn Congress, she developed a reputation for grabbing a seat close to the entranceway in the House chamber for the president's annual State of the Union address so she could engage with the commander in chief. It wasn't for the photo opportunities, she insisted to The Huffington Post in 2016, it was also an opportunity to quickly conduct business with presidents.\n\nAs to why she was able to gain regular access to such a prized perch, she said, \"Because of so many good friends, I am welcomed in that seat.\"\n\nFuneral arrangements are pending, according to the family.\n\n\"Her legislative victories impacted millions, from establishing the Juneteenth Federal Holiday to reauthorizing the Violence Against Women Act. However, she impacted us most as our beloved wife, sister, mother, and Bebe (grandmother),\" her family said Friday. \"She will be dearly missed, but her legacy will continue to inspire all who believe in freedom, justice, and democracy.\"\n\nThis story has been updated with additional details.\n\nCNN's Chandelis Duster contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "247ureports.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The 247 Ureports"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/African_Americans", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "African Americans"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sheila_Jackson_Lee", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Sheila Jackson Lee"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Congressional_Black_Caucus", "type": "org", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Congressional Black Caucus"}}, {"uri": She was 74 and had also previously had breast cancer.\n\n\"A fierce champion of the people, she was affectionately and simply known as 'Congresswoman' by her constituents in recognition of her near-ubiquitous presence and service to their daily lives for more than 30 years,\" her family said in the statement.\n\nJackson Lee quickly established herself as a fierce advocate for women and minorities, and a leader for House Democrats on many social justice issues, from policing reform to reparations for descendants of enslaved people.\n\nShe led the first rewrite of the Violence Against Women Act in nearly a decade, which included protections for Native American, transgender and immigrant women.\n\nJackson Lee was also among the lead lawmakers behind the effort in 2021 to have Juneteenth recognized as the first new federal holiday since Martin Luther King Jr Day was established in 1986.\n\nShe was a judge in Houston before she was elected to Houston city council in 1989, then ran for Congress in 1994. She was an advocate for gay rights and an early opponent of the Iraq war in 2003.\n\nJackson Lee routinely won re-election to Congress with ease. The few times she faced a challenger, she never carried less than two-thirds of the vote.\n\nJackson Lee was one of a handful of congressional Black Caucus members who were arrested in Washington DC in the summer of 2021 while protesting against delays in passing legislation to protect voting rights.\n\nShe was demonstrating outside the Hart Senate office building alongside other protesters at the time of her arrest.\n\n\"Any action that is a peaceful action of civil disobedience is worthy and more - to push all of us to do better,\" Jackson Lee, whose state is one of the hardest places to Sheila Jackson Lee passes away at 74", "body": "HOUSTON (KIAH) -- U.S. Representative Sheila Jackson Lee has died at the age of 74. A statement from the family of Congresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee was posted online Friday evening.\n\n\"Today, with incredible grief for our loss yet deep gratitude for the life she shared with us, we announce the passing of United States Representative Sheila Jackson Lee of the 18th Congressional District of Texas.\"\n\nLocal historical career\n\nShelia Jackson Lee started her political career in Houston. She served as an at-large member of the Houston City Council 1990 to 1991.\n\nThroughout her longtime career, she always had offices in Houston and advocated proudly for Houstonians and Texas. In 2023, she ran for mayor of Houston and lost against John Whitmire. In early June of this year, the Congresswoman announced she had pancreatic cancer.\n\nHere is a look at many moments in the Congresswoman's career.\n\nRepresentative Jackson Lee leaves a historic mark on American politics. Her longtime career and free-spoken advocacy remains an important legacy.\n\nMany are reacting online to the news of her passing.\n\nWe extend our deepest condolences to her family, friends and community.\n\nCongresswoman Jackson Lee achieved a remarkable legislative record in the Congress for Houston and for our country. As a powerful voice for our Constitution and human rights, she fought tirelessly to advance fairness, equity and justice for all.\n\nShe was a tireless advocate for Houston.\n\nCongresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee was a fierce advocate for Houston and her constituents.
