{"uri": "8230788862", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-17", "time": "23:28:26", "dateTime": "2024-07-17T23:28:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-17T23:25:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.364705890417099, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/lee-retires-almost-40-years-231200133.html", "title": "Lee retires after almost 40 years as a code inspector", "body": "Jul. 17 -- David Lee experienced the worst of the worst possible conditions in almost four decades with the city of Decatur.\n\nLee saw rats, roaches, fleas, bedbugs and more infestations. He saw holes in walls, floors and ceilings, black mold and mildew, leaking sewage pipes and frayed electrical wires.\n\nLee, who retired June 28, worked for six mayors and seven department heads in code enforcement during his 37 1/2 -year career. He helped create the city's ordinance for dilapidated homes and weed abatements.\n\nCommunity Development Manager Allen Stover said Lee \"birthed\" the city's code enforcement division upon his hiring in 1990.\n\nHired by then-Mayor Bill Dukes, Lee started Dec. 27. 1990, at a time when code enforcement was a \"new concept.\" His experience in law enforcement and building construction made him \"a good fit\" for the position, he said.\n\n\"I was hired for a job that did not exist here, or, for that matter, in most places in the country,\" Lee said.\n\nWally Terry was Lee's boss as director of development for about seven years until Terry retired in 2020.\n\n\"The city is losing a lot of institutional knowledge,\" Terry said. \"He's got a little black book that gives him connections throughout the city. David can make one phone call and never leave his desk when I would be running around all over town.\"\n\nTerry said people don't realize how many codified issues the Community Development Department began during Lee's tenure that only Decatur has, in addition to the International Building Code.\n\n\"David has so much care for our community,\" Terry said.\n\nLee said he doesn't know how many houses the city demolished or forced to be torn down during his tenure.\n\nHe estimated he averaged about 10 notices per day. Most notices led to a correction by the homeowner. However, owners often couldn't afford the repairs, refused to comply or didn't respond to a registered letter from the city.\n\n\"When I started, every street corner in Northwest Decatur had a crack dealer with a clenched fist standing on it,\" Lee said.\n\nHe said they tore down houses in almost every neighborhood in the city.\n\n\"They're not all because of age and deterioration,\" Lee said. \"Some were because of fires or storms.\"\n\nThe city budgeted $60,000 in fiscal 2024 for demolitions and, based on an average of 100 per year, budgeted $8,500 for weed abatements.\n\nThe owner must repay the city, or the city places a lien against the property. However, the city often doesn't receive the money for years or there's never a payback.\n\n\"It's amazing now to drive through town and reflect on the changes that this department had to affect,\" Lee said. \"Not just because of the buildings that we caused to be demolished, but because of the positive changes.\"\n\nLee said one of the toughest parts of his job was dealing with the people who were often at the lowest point in their lives.\n\n\"It's not something you ever really want to have to do but it's necessary, for lack of a better term, for the greater good,\" he said. \"We've never torn one down that didn't need to go. We give people every opportunity to do something with their house.\"\n\nHe said he's had to wipe black clouds of fleas off his jeans after leaving a house.\n\nLee said he takes off his clothes in his garage if he's been on an inspection, puts them in a garbage bag and fills the bag with bug spray to make sure he kills the bugs before taking the garments in the house or wearing them again.\n\nLee said his only regret as he goes into retirement is the city never passed rental registration or rental licensing.\n\nThe city has struggled for years with absentee landlords. This creates the most work for Lee and his fellow code enforcement agents because it requires them to go on a private investigator-like search for the homeowner.\n\n\"Requiring people to have local, accessible contact would be a game-changer,\" Lee said.\n\nHe said a lot of the absentee homeowners \"don't want to be found,\" and it seems like \"it's becoming more and more prevalent.\"\n\nLee said the city got close a few times to passing an ordinance, but then something happened to stall the process.\n\nTerry, who worked with Lee and the Planning Commission on the rental issue in 2017, said he shares Lee's regret.\n\n\"It still needs to be done,\" Terry said. \"And (Lee) doesn't have to give up on it. He can now advocate for it as a private citizen.\"\n\nPolice dispatch's NCIC was the only city computer when Lee started his job. This forced him to go across the street daily to the Morgan County Courthouse to do his search for homeowners.\n\n\"About three years in, we were able to get an IBM terminal that was connected to the county system,\" he said. \"They had to bore a hole under the street and run a big cable for it.\"\n\nNow Lee and the city's four code inspectors have become experts in internet property searches.\n\nLee said his best and most successful search was finding a woman who lived in the United Arab Emirates and owned a home in Decatur.\n\nHe said he sent a court notice to UAE, and, through long-distance correspondence, she took care of the Decatur home's issues, signed a rights waiver pleading guilty (allowed at the time by the courts) and paid her fine.\n\nLee said he doesn't ever remember losing a court case.\n\n\"It's not necessarily to my credit,\" he said. \"It's just that if it's not a good case I didn't take it to court.\"\n\nOne of them was the old water tower next to the Gordon Drive overpass.\n\n\"A lot of people didn't want it torn down, but it sprung a leak,\" Lee said.\n\nLee said Stonegate, a crime-ridden housing project off Old Moulton Road, was probably the largest demolition his department conducted during his career.\n\n\"The job was just a lot more involved than many people thought it would be,\" Lee said. \"There was asbestos and lead paint, so we had to do remediation before the demolition could start.\"\n\nBut Lee remains proud of the Stonegate work.\n\n\"People lived there right up to the time we started the demolition,\" Lee said. \"But everybody who lived there wound up in a better place.\"\n\nIn the 1990s, the late Joe Terry owned as many or more rental houses in the city than anyone else. Many were not in good condition, so Joe Terry was often at odds with Lee and the city, and they ended up in court several times.\n\n\"Our unsafe policies and procedures had to undergo a colonoscopy the likes of which I did not even realize was possible,\" Lee said of the Joe Terry court cases.\n\nLee said he will never forget \"orchestrating the demolition\" of 10 Terry-owned houses on a Saturday.\n\nLee said Joe Terry died not long after that day on his attorney's steps. He said he believes Joe Terry \"was on his way to file another suit against us.\"\n\nStover said the efforts of Lee and the rest of their department compare well with their neighbors in Athens, Madison, Huntsville and Hartselle and other cities in the state.\n\n\"Do we have issues? Absolutely,\" Stover said. \"Do have some areas that need some work done? We do. I don't think anybody would say we don't.\n\n\"But I would put our city and the way our city looks against anybody in the state. I think Community Development has been a big part of that, and David deserves part of the credit. The department as a whole has done a magnificent job of keeping it looking like it does,\" he said.\n\nMayor Tab Bowling said he appreciates Lee's contribution to the city's beautification.\n\n\"He tried to keep our city cleaner via code enforcement,\" Bowling said.\n\nStover said Lee joins a long list of experienced employees in the Building, Police and Fire departments who have recently retired or who soon will.\n\n\"We've got folks in Community Development who are capable of replacing David, but we still lose just a wealth of knowledge,\" Stover said.\n\nNow that he is retired, Lee said he has \"years' worth of projects\" around his home. He plans to spend time with his granddaughter, and he will continue restoring a 1972 pickup truck that he bought in high school.", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "news/Business", "label": "news/Business", "wgt": 92}], "image": "https://s.yimg.com/cv/apiv2/social/images/yahoo_default_logo-1200x1200.png", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9748703", "eventUri": "eng-9748703", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-07-17", "textStart": 0, "textEnd": 7}, {"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-06-28", "textStart": 322, "textEnd": 329}, {"amb": false, "date": "-12-27", "textStart": 683, "textEnd": 690}], "sentiment": 0.0117647058823529, "wgt": 93, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-07-426277009", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "17:08:37", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T17:08:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T17:08:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.3490196168422699, "url": "https://eu.press-citizen.com/story/sports/college/iowa/wrestling/2024/07/18/spencer-lee-olympics-wrestling-japan-trip-iowa-hawkeyes-wrestling/74407603007/", "title": "How a trip to Japan got Iowa wrestling's Spencer Lee ready for the Olympics", "body": "How Spencer Lee says he is feeling ahead of Olympics, how he's fitting in the new wrestling room at Iowa\n\nIOWA CITY -- There's an alternate timeline of Spencer Lee's wrestling career that could have ultimately played out.\n\nFollowing a stunning loss in the 2023 NCAA semifinal to Purdue's Matt Ramos to stop him from becoming a four-time collegiate champion, there was a case to be made that Lee had left everything out on the mat he could. Three NCAA titles, two Dan Hodge Trophies, a Cadet World title and a pair of Junior World titles had cost him him ACLs and deteriorated his knees to a point where Lee wondered whether he had anything left in the tank.\n\nLee has never been one for excuses. His \"excuses are for wusses\" quote following winning a title with no ACLs in his knees became a tagline for the Hawkeye wrestling program. But even he wondered if it was maybe time to step away.\n\nFollowing that loss in March, Lee finally committed to taking his long-desired trip to Japan as an escape from it all.\n\n\"I just needed to not think about wrestling,\" Lee said during a press conference Thursday.\n\nLee was a longtime admirer of Japanese culture. Not only for its dominant wrestling, but Japanese culture in its entirety. In Japan, he stayed in Tokyo while visiting Kyoto, Osaka and other major towns along the way.\n\n\"I really enjoyed the peacefulness,\" Lee said. \"Just to walk around and have a lot of time to think.\"\n\nWhile he was wanting to avoid wrestling, he still made sure to meet up with an old friend in Takuto Otoguro, an Olympic gold medalist in 2021. The two met and became friends in the 2014 World Championships and stayed in touch throughout their careers.\n\nWhen Lee spoke with Otoguro, Otoguro mentioned how hard it was prepare for another Olympics. Now that he had reached the pinnacle, what comes next was a big question. When Otoguro began training again after some time away, he told Lee he still loved it when they were in Japan, so he would try once again.\n\nWhen Lee returned from his wrestling hiatus, he felt refueled, which is exactly what Iowa coach Tom Brands was hoping for. When Lee floated the idea to him, Brands and the staff \"spurred\" him to take some time to make the heart grow fonder.\n\n\"You're fanning the flames,\" Brands said. \"Making him burn hot inside.\"\n\nLee would then go on to perhaps look the best he has in some time, rolling through Senior Nationals to qualify for the Olympic Trials in December 2023, defeating the United States' best at the Trials and then qualifying the 57-kilogram weight class for the US in Istanbul and going undefeated in that run.\n\nAcross the sea, Lee's friend Otoguro failed to qualify for the Olympics himself, but told Lee he would be seeing him soon, making Lee realize the bigger picture of why it made sense to continue on.\n\n\"He messaged me and told me that he would be on the team in 2028,\" Lee said. \"For me it was like, 'I get it.' Just because you reached that pinnacle, it doesn't mean you're done with your potential.\"\n\nToday's version of Lee is a revival of what Lee was prior to all those knee injuries, before the stunning loss in his senior season. His time away in a country he longed to visit one day helped him realize there was still another level he was capable of reaching if he could find a way.\n\nNow, Lee heads to his mother's home country of Paris. He's been practicing his French with the France wrestling delegation in Colorado to impress his mother and family who all were born and raised in France, all while working on his stellar par terre offense that helped him roll through the qualifying process. In total across Senior Nationals, the Olympic Trials and the Last Chance qualifier, Lee wrestled in 11 matches, outscored his opponents 107-25 with five technical falls and a pin in that time.\n\nUltimately, Brands' prodding of Lee to take some time away paid off big time for all parties, but they are turning toward the next step of this process to try to win gold. A former gold medalist himself in 1996, he's not trying to push Lee to emulate what he did, but rather to exceed what he accomplished in Atlanta 28 years ago.\n\nLee will be looking to Drake Ayala, Pat Lugo and Brandon Sorensen to help as training partners. At this point, current and former Hawkeyes training with the Olympians has become a tradition, like Lee did as a teenager with Daniel Dennis furing his Olympics run in 2016.\n\nFor Ayala, it's a massive opportunity to build upon his successful sophomore campaign when he reached the NCAA finals. Having dealt with injuries of his own the past two seasons, he's getting a shining example of what it will take to reach his pinnacle.\n\n\"He left a little undone as well,\" Brands said. \"This is part of that for him but there's also an unselfish part of that as well. He's the right guy along with Lugo and Sorensen to go with Spencer because of their relationship.\"\n\nNow the \"zero hour\" is upon Lee and the Hawkeye Wrestling Club, a term Brands borrowed from Dan Gable as they prepare to try to get Iowa's sixth gold medal from the Olympics. Brands says he has no need or desire to place pressure on Lee ahead of the Olympics, but Lee's urgency to get out and reach the pinnacle is at an all-time high in his career.\n\n\"You're talking about a guy who's a super high-octane competitor, you're talking about a guy who gets up for the best events that are in front of him and here we are,\" Brands said. \"It's time to perform.\"\n\nEli McKown covers high school sports and wrestling for the Des Moines Register. Contact him at Emckown@gannett.com. Just because you reached that pinnacle, it doesn't mean you're done with your potential.\"\n\nToday's version of Lee is a revival of what Lee was prior to all those knee injuries, before the stunning loss in his senior season. His time away in a country he longed to visit one day helped him realize there was still another level he was capable of reaching if he could find a way.\n\nNow, Lee heads to his mother's home country of Paris. He's been practicing his French with the France wrestling delegation in Colorado to impress his mother and family who all were born and raised in France all while working on his stellar par terre offense that helped him roll through the qualifying process. In total across senior nationals, the Olympic Trials and the Last Chance qualifier, Lee wrestled in 11 matches, outscored his opponents 107-25 with five technical falls and a pin in that time.\n\nUltimately, Brands' prodding of Lee to take some time away paid off big time for all parties, but they are turning toward the next step of this process to try to win gold. A former gold medalist himself in 1996, he's not trying to push Lee to emulate what he did, but rather to exceed what he accomplished in Atlanta 28 years ago.\n\nTo try and exceed what he did in Paris, along with what prior Hawkeyes have done in Dan Dennis and Thomas Gilman, they'll be looking to Drake Ayala, Pat Lugo and Brandon Sorensen to help as training partners alongside Lee. At this point, current and former Hawkeyes training with the Olympians has become a tradition, like Lee did as a teenager with Dennis furing his Olympic run in 2016.\n\nFor Ayala, it's a massive opportunity to build upon his successful sophomore campaign when he reached the NCAA finals. Having dealt with injuries of his own the past two seasons, he's getting a shining example of what it will take to reach his pinnacle that he can achieve.\n\n\"He left a little undone as well,\" Brands said. \"This is part of that for him but there's also an unselfish part of that as well. He's the right guy along with Lugo and Sorensen to go with Spencer because of their relationship.\"\n\nHowever, now the \"zero hour\" is upon Lee and the Hawkeye Wrestling club, a term Brands borrowed from Dan Gable as they prepare to try and get Iowa's sixth gold medal from the Olympics. Brands says he has no need or desire to place pressure on Lee ahead of the Olympics, but Lee's urgency to get out and reach the pinnalce is at an all-time high in his career.\n\n\"You're talking about a guy who's a super high-octane competitor, you're talking about a guy who gets up for the best events that are in front of him and here we are,\" Brands said. \"It's time to perform.\"\n\nEli McKown covers high school sports and wrestling for the Des Moines Register. {"uri": "8233435902", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "11:48:19", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T11:48:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T11:47:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.3137255012989044, "url": "https://www.entertainmentdailyuk.com/news/the-1-club-lee-mack-clap-back-prince-william-snub/", "title": "\"I don't tell you how to be the future King\": Lee Mack in clap back at Prince William following 'snub'", "body": "The 1% Club Host Lee Mack previously clapped back at Prince William after the royal made a brutal joke about him.\n\nComedian Lee is a firm favourite with fans, thanks to stints on shows like Not Going Out and Would I Lie To You? He is also back on screens this weekend (July 20) for The 1% Club.\n\nSo it's no surprise that Lee has rubbed shoulders with a slew of celebs over the years, including royals.\n\nBut one incident back in 2012 saw the future King make a brutal jibe about Lee that he needed to \"get some new jokes\".\n\nAppearing on The Graham Norton Show in 2020, Lee recalled the awkward incident, which took place when Lee hosted the Queen's Jubilee Concert in 2012.\n\nLee said: \"He [William] came up and he said \u2012 you get to go to the Palace afterwards \u2012 and his opening line to me was: 'You need to get some new jokes.'\n\n\"And I went: 'Listen, I don't tell you how to be the future King.' And he laughed and said: 'I'm only joking, I'm a big fan of Not Going Out' \u2012 my sitcom \u2012 and I thought that's so exciting.\"\n\nBut things then took another awkward turn for Lee.\n\nThe actor revealed how as he was about to talk to him more, singer Cheryl arrived. And according to Lee, William snubbed him for a second time as the royal was \"far more interested\" in talking to her.\n\nLee said: \"And I was just about to talk to him and then Cheryl Cole started talking to him and he was far more interested in her and I had to wander off.\"\n\nIn other Lee Mack news, back in June it was confirmed that his sitcom, Not Going Out will be returning for series 14.\n\nBut fans will have to wait a while to watch it, as the show won't air until 2025.\n\nThe Lee Mack comedy is the UK's longest-running sitcom (currently on air) and recently celebrated its 100th episode over Christmas 2023.\n\nThe 1% Club airs on Saturday (July 20) at 8:00pm on ITV.\n\nJOIN ED!'s ANT AND DEC NEWS CHANNEL ON WHATSAPP - IN THESE 4 SIMPLE STEPS USING THE INVITE LINK HERE\n\nRead more: The 1% Club host Lee Mack gave up alcohol after reading a book that 'changed my whole attitude'", "source": {"uri": "entertainmentdailyuk.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Entertainment Daily"}, "authors": [{"uri": "joey_crutchley@entertainmentdailyuk.com", "name": "Joey Crutchley", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lee_Mack", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Lee Mack"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_1%_Club", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "The 1% Club"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Not_Going_Out", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Not Going Out"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William,_Prince_of_Wales", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "William, Prince of Wales"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Would_I_Lie_to_You?_(game_show)", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Would I Lie to You? {"uri": "8235172805", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "15:58:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T15:58:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T15:56:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://www.ktbs.com/news/national/biden-praises-longtime-us-rep-sheila-jackson-lee-of-texas-who-died-of-cancer/article_ae1536c4-78c0-5190-9475-6442cc1d43b6.html", "title": "Biden praises longtime US Rep Sheila Jackson Lee of Texas, who died of cancer", "body": "FILE - From left, Majority Whip James Clyburn, D-S.C., Rep. Al Green, D-Texas, Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee, D-Tex., Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., Rep. Joyce Beatty, D-Ohio, Rep. Maxine Waters, D-Calif., Rep. Barbara Lee, D-Calif., and members of the Congressional Black Caucus celebrate the passage of the Juneteenth National Independence Day Act, at the Capitol in Washington, June 17, 2021. Longtime U.S. Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee, who helped lead federal efforts to protect women from domestic violence and recognize Juneteenth as a national holiday, has died Friday, July 19, 2024, after battling pancreatic cancer, according to her chief of staff.\n\nLongtime U.S. Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee of Texas, who helped lead federal efforts to protect women from domestic violence and recognize Juneteenth as a national holiday, has died. She was 74.\n\nLillie Conley, her chief of staff, confirmed that Jackson Lee, who had pancreatic cancer, died in Houston Friday night with her family around her.\n\nThe Democrat had represented her Houston-based district and the nation's fourth-largest city since 1995. She had previously had breast cancer and announced the pancreatic cancer diagnosis on June 2.\n\n\"The road ahead will not be easy, but I stand in faith that God will strengthen me,\" Jackson Lee said in a statement then.\n\nJackson Lee was \"a towering figure in our politics,\" President Joe Biden said in a statement Saturday. \"Always fearless, she spoke truth to power and represented the power of the people of her district in Houston with dignity and grace.\"\n\nBiden said Jackson Lee's spirit was unbreakable.\n\n\"I had the honor of working with her during her nearly 30 years in Congress,\" Biden said. \"No matter the issue -- from delivering racial justice to building an economy for working people -- she was unrelenting in her leadership.\"\n\nBishop James Dixon, a longtime friend in Houston who visited Jackson Lee earlier this week, said he will remember her as a fighter.\n\n\"She was just a rare, rare jewel of a person who relentlessly gave everything she had to make sure others had what they needed. That was Sheila,\" he said.\n\nJackson Lee had just been elected to the Houston district once represented by Barbara Jordan, the first Black woman elected to Congress from a Southern state since Reconstruction, when she was immediately placed on the high-profile House Judiciary Committee in 1995.\n\n\"They just saw me, I guess through my profile, through Barbara Jordan's work,\" Jackson Lee told the Houston Chronicle in 2022. \"I thought it was an honor because they assumed I was going to be the person they needed.\"\n\nJackson Lee quickly established herself as fierce advocate for women and minorities, and a leader for House Democrats on many social justice issues, from policing reform to reparations for descendants of enslaved people. She led the first rewrite of the Violence Against Women Act in nearly a decade, which included protections for Native American, transgender and immigrant women.\n\nJackson Lee was also among the lead lawmakers behind the effort in 2021 to have Juneteenth recognized as the first new federal holiday since Martin Luther King, Jr. Day was established in 1986. The holiday marks the day in 1865 that the last enslaved African Americans in Galveston, Texas, finally learned of their freedom.\n\nA native of Queens, New York, Jackson Lee graduated from Yale and earned her law degree at the University of Virginia. She was a judge in Houston before she was elected to Houston City Council in 1989, then ran for Congress in 1994. She was an advocate for gay rights and an early opponent of the Iraq War in 2003.\n\nTop congressional Democrats reacted quickly to the news Friday night, praising her commitment and work ethic.\n\nRep. James Clyburn of South Carolina called her \"a tenacious advocate for civil rights and a tireless fighter, improving the lives of her constituents.\"\n\nRep. Jamie Raskin of Maryland said he had never known a harder-working lawmaker than Jackson Lee, saying she \"studied every bill and every amendment with exactitude and then told Texas and America exactly where she stood.\"\n\nFormer House Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California cited Jackson Lee's \"relentless determination\" in getting Juneteenth declared a national holiday.\n\n\"As a powerful voice in the Congress for our Constitution and human rights, she fought tirelessly to advance fairness, equity and justice for all,\" Pelosi said.\n\nRepublican Texas Gov. Greg Abbott said he and his wife Cecilia will always remember Jackson Lee, calling her a \"tireless advocate for the people of Houston.\"\n\n\"Her legacy of public service and dedication to Texas will live on,\" he said.\n\nJackson Lee routinely won reelection to Congress with ease. The few times she faced a challenger, she never carried less than two-thirds of the vote. Jackson Lee considered leaving Congress in 2023 in a bid to become Houston's first female Black mayor but was defeated in a runoff. She then easily won the Democratic nomination for the 2024 general election.\n\nDuring the mayoral campaign, Jackson Lee expressed regret and said \"everyone deserves to be treated with dignity and respect\" following the release of an unverified audio recording purported to be of the lawmaker berating staff members.\n\nIn 2019, Jackson Lee stepped down from two leadership positions on the House Judiciary Committee and Congressional Black Caucus Foundation, the fundraising of the Congressional Black Caucus, following a lawsuit from a former employee who said her sexual assault complaint was mishandled.\n\nIn a statement, Jackson Lee's family said she had been a beloved wife, sister, mother and grandmother known as Bebe.\n\n\"She will be dearly missed, but her legacy will continue to inspire all who believe in freedom, justice, and democracy,\" the statement said. \"God bless you Congresswoman and God bless the United States of America.\"\n\nAssociated Press writer Lou Kesten contributed to this story from Washington.", "source": {"uri": "ktbs.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KTBS"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@ktbs.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": {"uri": "8235174695", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-20", "time": "15:59:30", "dateTime": "2024-07-20T15:59:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-20T15:58:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5568627715110779, "url": "https://spokesman-recorder.com/2024/07/20/congresswoman-sheila-jackson-lee/", "title": "Democratic Congresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee dies at 74 | Minnesota Spokesman-Recorder", "body": "Democratic Congresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee, one of the longest-serving members of the Texas delegation, has died at the age of 74. In June, Jackson Lee announced her diagnosis of pancreatic cancer, yet she showed little indication of letting it interfere with her plans to run for a 16th term this November.\n\nThe fiery congresswoman disclosed her diagnosis in a written statement shortly after winning renomination in a fiercely contested Democratic primary. Known for her unwavering commitment to social justice, she was a fervent advocate for reparations for African Americans and a vocal critic of the twice impeached and 34 times convicted felon and former President Donald Trump. Unlike some of her colleagues, she did not join the calls for President Joe Biden to step aside from the 2024 race.\n\nAs recently as Wednesday, July 19, Jackson Lee continued to champion President Biden's re-election campaign. \"Something that does not get talked about enough: we were able to bring down homicides in Houston with federal investment,\" she wrote on X. \"After President Biden signed the American Rescue Plan, we brought $50 million to the city to take on crime -- and it worked! Local/federal partnership saved lives.\"\n\nShe added, \"This House Democrat believes Joe Biden has served us well and has the best plans for the future. I am laser-focused on beating Donald Trump and delivering for America because that's what matters.\" Jackson Lee also reminded her followers that America saw one of the most significant homicide spikes ever in Trump's last year in office. \"He threw his hands in the air and did not know what to do,\" she asserted. \"Since he left, I am proud that our American Rescue Plan has done the very important work to bring these numbers down! Federal/local partnerships worked.\"\n\nJackson Lee's legislative achievements are significant and wide-ranging. She played a crucial role in the passage of the Violence Against Women Act. She was a senior House Committee member on the Judiciary, Homeland Security, and Budget Committees. She was the first female ranking member of the Judiciary Subcommittee for Crime and Federal Government Surveillance, serving as Chair during the 117th Congress.\n\nAmong her notable legislative efforts were the Sentencing Reform Act, the George Floyd Law Enforcement Trust and Integrity Act, The RAISE Act, The Fair Chance for Youth Act, the Kimberly Vaughan Firearm Safe Storage Act, Kalief's Law, and the American RISING Act. She also introduced the Juvenile Accountability Block Grant Reauthorization and Bullying Prevention and Intervention Act and the Federal Prison Bureau Nonviolent Offender Relief Act.\n\nA staunch supporter of women and children, Jackson Lee championed the Paycheck Fairness Act and the Pregnant Workers Fairness Act. She authored the Triple-Negative Breast Cancer Research and Education Act.\n\nJackson Lee was widely recognized for her effectiveness and influence. Congressional Quarterly named her one of the 50 most effective Members of Congress, and U.S. News and World Report listed her among the ten most influential legislators in the U.S. House of Representatives. She was a founder, member, and chair of the Congressional Pakistan Caucus and the Congressional Children's Caucus. She was chair of the Congressional Black Caucus Energy Braintrust and the Justice Reform Task Force co-chair.\n\nA Yale University alumna, Jackson Lee earned her B.A. in Political Science with honors and later received a J.D. from the University of Virginia Law School. She is survived by her husband, Dr. Elwyn Lee, an administrator at the University of Houston; her two children, Jason Lee, a Harvard University graduate, and Erica Lee, a Duke University graduate and member of the Harris County School Board; and her two grandchildren, twins Ellison Bennett Carter and Roy Lee Carter III.", "source": {"uri": "spokesman-recorder.com", "dataType": "news", "title":
